Reviews.title: Great for the money but no BIOS update yet - EDIT: BIOS update now available
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2020
Reviews.text:
Update: BIOS update now available as of May. Overall OC still hard-capped around the same limits, but overall stability seems improved at higher clocks w/ new BIOS.
-----
I found this for $280 in April 2020, and while the RT 5600 XT represents a great performance-to-cost card, this Gigabyte Windforce model specifically does not yet have the AMD boosted BIOS update available (while their "Gaming" model does). I've contacted their support and they said there's no timeline to having it either. Yes you can OC it easily to the would-be boosted benchmark, but not beyond it (easily, anyway).

Had I known I would have spent the extra $10-20 on a different 5600 Xt with upgraded BIOS availability and maybe some RGB, but such is life. Otherwise performance wise it's great... been able to pull average 70-80 fps at very high settings in RDR2. When OC'd fans can push 2500 rpm to keep the temps in check, but if you're not OC'ing noise or high temps won't be an issue at all.

Reviews.title: Good Card - Drivers are bad
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2020
Reviews.text: I like the card but ATI has issues with the drivers an if you try to tweak them you might have issues. The first week the ATI drivers killed my box. Had to reinstall, since then I have done no tweaking and it's working well. disappointed that I can tweak it a bit to get a better frame rate.

Reviews.title: Great Card!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2020
Reviews.text: I don't normally write reviews but I had to for this card. This gpu is fantastic. I put this card in a ghost S1 case with with no case fans and it doesn't go above 75 degrees. Plays many games at 1440p over 60fps with no problems. Also incredibly quiet. Fans don't kick on till 60 degrees and when they do they are not terribly loud. Only bad thing is that idle Temps are high, about 49 to 55 degrees, but that could of course be due to the fact I have no case fans. Definitely recommend this gpu.

Reviews.title: chagne your power output
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2020
Reviews.text: When I got this graphics card I kept getting blue screen or green screen of death I ended up finding out that it was the power mode it was set to the AMD power mode and it was taking up a lot of juice just a run games or run your computer so go to control panel go to power options and if it's set a Amd ryzen balanced change it to high performance mode and your problems will be fixed if you get the problems I had

Reviews.title: Recommended Graphics Card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2020
Reviews.text: If you are looking for a mid ranged graphics card that's just 10% more powerful than the gtx 1660 ti and for around the same price, this one is for you. Gaming at 1080p is awesome! But if you monitor did not come with display adapters you will have to buy extra ones because this card does not come with them.

Reviews.title: This card impressed me.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2020
Reviews.text: You will get Vega 56 to 64 like performance without the horrid fan noise. I bought this 5600xt for a system that I donated to a family, and they are loving it. This card overclocked like a champ, however maybe that was due to the fact that the BIOS wasn't updated. Not sure. I will buy this card again for future builds.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2021
Reviews.text:
I rather like the actual card, my beef is with the vBIOS that was on it when I got the thing. I wound up needing to use onboard graphics on my computer to flash the darned thing so that it would be detected. If I didn't have onboard graphics or another graphics card lying around, I'd have been pretty screwed.

Good hardware, but be aware you may have to flash it.

Reviews.title: Get a nice monitor
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2020
Reviews.text:
Get a good 1440p 144hz+ monitor to do it justice. Makes the whole gaming experience so much better. Wasted 5 months of this cards potential by using a old 1080p 60hz monitor...
Regularly gets 90+FPS maxed out 1440p on games like control or Horizon 4.

Reviews.title: REALLY good for basic gaming, but the fan noise is killing me.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2021
Reviews.text:
Pros:
- It has SERIOUSLY impressed me for gaming as we as general use. I can Skype with my fiance with our 2 1080p cams, play Minecraft at almost max settings AND screen share at the same time with no issue.
- Easy peasy install. Just click in.
- Trusted name.
- Low profile.

Cons:
- No drivers, but if you know what you're doing that's easy enough.
- I installed it into my Optiplex 3010 low profile rig January 6th, and March 20 it started making a horrible grinding sound. I checked and my RPMs were down to 400, but temp was okay. Opened up the rig and saw that it was wired in such a way that a wire was hitting the fan. I am going to try to correct the issue, update will be posted when I reach a conclusion.

All in all, I'm super impressed with this little card. Valheim doesn't really run on it at the lowest settings, Skyrim (the original release) plays pretty well at medium settings. Definitely recommend for a budget gaming rig if you aren't trying to accomplish stunning graphics. It's a good card. Weirdly came with a DVI to HDMI adapter even though it has an HDMI port, but I like free stuff so. My only real gripe is the fan issue I'm currently having, but hopefully I can manage to fix that.

Reviews.title: Developed a Fan Noise before I had it a Year
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2022
Reviews.text: The video card itself is wonderful. It does such a good job but after about 8 or 10 months, it started growling at me. I HATE video cards with fans in them because the fans are ALWAYS going out in them. Once upon a time, I had an old AMD video card and the fan worked well but that was the last time that ever happened. Video card manufacturers need to spend less on how many Bit Coins they can crank and more on how to improve their cooling methods. Did I say, I hate video card fans?

Reviews.title: A Pretty Decent Graphics Card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2020
Reviews.text: This is a pretty decent graphics card, overall. It's not going to blow you away or anything, but works just fine for everyday usage, like watching videos and browsing the internet. Definitely not a card to get if you plan on playing games, since the specs are low compared to the "gamer friendly (AKA more expensive/powerful)" graphics cards out there. Not saying you can't play any games at all using this card, though. Depending on the game, you would have to play at low to mid settings with this card. Of course, there will be games that you won't be able to play using this card, for obvious reasons. Anyway, I bought this card because I was on a tight budget and needed to save money. I mainly watch movies and browse the internet on my PC, so this card works just fine for those tasks. This will tide me over until I have enough money to get a better one.

Reviews.title: Great card for a great price
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2020
Reviews.text:
Snagged this budget card to make my old hp 8300 handle small tasks and games for my son and it has done nothing but impress me out of the box.
Running the stock hp motherboard running and i-5 3470.
8gb ram
Stock 250 psu
And now this card upgraded from a gt 710 2gb ddr3.

Now ive seen alot of people saying this cant game and wouldnt recommend it for that which is ehhh and slightly misleading imo.

I dont do any video editing or fancy stuff like that i usually just boot up to play games and pay bills or watch shows but i digress, this graphics card so far has handled everything ive thrown at it and been manageable, dont grab this and think "cool im gonna go pro on a budget", but definitely grab this if youre looking for something to get started, i have gotten the following to be playable so far.
Fallout 3 - 40+ fps - med settings under full load (mirv tested)
Fallout NV - 40+ fps - med settings under full load
Wreckfest - 30-35 fps - med settings which could bump up.
Friday the 13th - 40+ fps - med settings.
Skyrim - 40+ fps - med settings (tweaked).

Again, i may have just won the scilicon lottery with mine but for a small cheap and worthwhile budget card, this is it for me.

Reviews.title: Great placeholder while waiting for prices to stabilize.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2021
Reviews.text: I purchased this graphics card because it was cheap, and I needed a placeholder until inflation decreases and I can finally purchase the GPU I really want. My fiancé and I were able to install this one with minimal effort. At first my display would not turn on. Taking the CMOS battery out and putting it back in to reset it fixed the issue, and it now works as it should. It isn’t the greatest, so far I have only played Plague Inc. and it is quite blurry and hard to read the small text, but it was to be expected. Definitely not built for gaming, but I’m just glad I was able to get a GPU so I can use my PC while I wait for something better. And I am thankful it can at least play some smaller games. I would recommend this one for anyone in the same boat as I am.

Reviews.title: Good value for the price
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2019
Reviews.text:
The listing for this graphics card contained the words "DDR5" and that caught my eye . The price was good.

I've used the card to extend the life of an ageing system with i5 processor and on-board graphics. The card's worked well. It's lifted the graphics, and it's quite quick. I don't use it for games -- just routine like word processing, spreadsheets, Gimp-style photo editing, watching video, chatting on Skype. It's been fine for these. Soon, I'll potter about with Open Source programs as I take an exploratory dip into home video editing, though one of those knowledgeable friends reckons this video card will likely be under-powered for that. Might be good enough for a learner, though. We'll see.

This is a small compact card, and might suit a mini-ITX system. If you plan to use it with an older monitor check the links (DVI, etc), but don't give up without checking converter plugs. The card was easily installed, and benefited from updating its driver.

Reviews.title: Not impressed or happy with this card!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2020
Reviews.text:
I had an internal video card with 1gb and it finally started giving out, I found this one for $50 with 2gb and great reviews. Got it installed nice and easy but have been having nothing but problems with it. The colors are all off, I ran the setup to config everything from brightness, contrast, color etc and it seemed to work, then Boom everything changed and goes dark on the desktop and bright on the web, doesn't make sense. Tried fixing things again and keep getting the same thing, ones too dark and the other is way too bright. Not to mention All my text on everything is way blurry, I ran the clear text feature and it didn't fix anything. I'm running Windows 7 (no I'm not changing either) and it worked just fine on the main video card, so I can't figure out why the text won't clear up on a new "better" card.
Yes I'm not majorly computer tech savy, so if anyone has any ideas or tips I'd appreciate the help as I don't have anyone else to ask. Oh and I also noticed my screen keeps jumping and slightly resizing, seems like it goes from the right fit it was set at to jumping slightly bigger then jumps back to size again, any idea why this is happening?

Reviews.title: So I would like to start off by saying I had no plan ...
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
Reviews.text:
So I would like to start off by saying I had no plan on getting the ZOTAC card just because I have never purchase from this company and second I was worried I would make a big mistake. So after selling off my EVGA GTX 980Ti with a EK water block my plan was to purchase a gaming laptop and wait for the new PowerColor RED DEVIL Radeon RX 480. I was going to plan and grab two since the price were low on those cards but I kept going to the ZOTAC site looking at those GTX 1070 cards. The beautiful craftsmanship, the size of the cooler, the dual 8-pin connectors and the RGB lighting. Made this card a winner in my book, everything that I wanted was on this card. Worried as I never purchase a ZOTAC graphic card before or let along anything form them. I was hopping I didn't made a big mistake on my purchase and I tell you what. I didn't make a mistake.

So, I did my order on July 22, 2016 and card was here that Monday of the 25th. What I liked about the card was the massive cooler that it had plus the dual 8 pin power connectors. Owning a Thermaltake Core X9 case i needed to make sure that I had a massive side card to make it look like it belongs there. Not only that I needed to be air cool so the cooler was important as the case normally ran everything water cooled. But I wanted to see how well a kid of that size did on a case like I have right now. In the past I had issues with massive card not being able to get enough air to stay cooled making them to loud and hot. I didn't wanted to repeat that mistake but this time I have a huge case that should provide enough air flow to cool not only one but two of these cards.

So far I like how this card sits on my ASUS Sabertooth X99 motherboard and as you plug this card in. It will be flushed with the shielding of the motherboard but no fair. You can still remove the card by going on the back-plate side and pushing the lever that hold the card in place down and you can safely and easy remove it. The card RGB are amazing too and specially when you have a case like mine you get to enjoy the beauty of those fans and RGB lights on the card.

So after running it for a while I decided to test multiple games on it to see how they all perform with ultra to epic settings. Note EPIC settings emulates 4K graphhics. You can see that in games such as Overwatch from Blizzard. As Far as the game titles use to test this card here is a list of them.

-Game List- (Test done @ 1080p - 60Hz) LCD LED IPS 25" monitor
Battlefield 1 (NEW) tested game with all settings Maxed.
Alien: Isolation
ARK: Survival Evolved
Bionic Commando
Deus EX: Human Revolution
Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition
DiRT 3 Complete Edition
Hitman: Absolution
Lost Planet 3
Overwatch - (Epic Settings emulated 4K)
Remember Me
Rocksmith 2014
Street Fighter V
Strider
Tomb Raider
World of Warcraft

Pros:
* A very powerful graphic card
* Quiet graphic card
* Amazing software tools, and RGB features
* Huge cooler 3 fans design
* Dual 8-pin power connectors
* Some overclocking can put this card near if not right there with the GTX 1080.

Cons:
* To heavy for some motherboard if not secured right.
* To long for some cases so make sure you measure your case prior to buying this card.
* Some people may not like the yellow theme on the back of the card if they are working on a theme that may not require to have yellow.

-System Spec-

Reviews.title: Installation was very easy. Many people have commented on how heavy this ...
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
Reviews.text:
This review is for the ZOTAC GTX 1070 AMP! Edition.

The dimensions in the product description are incorrect. The correct length of this 2 fan card is closer to 11 3/4 inches. My mid-tower case, a 9 yr old Tagan CS-A Curbic, is 18.9" long ( the length that matters in relation to the card length ) and only has 12" from the back of the case to the HDD cages, allowing me to use this card but it's rather a tight fit with only about 1/4 to 1/2 inches to spare. If you are planning on getting this card or the AMP EXTREME ( a longer 3 fan card ) be advised to check your case layout before ordering. The outside case dimension is going to need to be around 19"+ unless you have a case specifically designed for newer full size graphics cards ( ie cases from the last 2 yrs or newer ) or have drive cages that can be removed or moved around. Most new cases have listing for the maximum graphic card length.

I'm very impressed with this card so far only having it 3 days. Installation was very easy. Many people have commented on how heavy this card is and thought it may damage their motherboards. My experience is if you have a full size ATX MB ( mother board ), and use the correct layout and maximum number of MB stand offs, sag shouldn't be an issue. My old graphics card HIS RADEON HD 4890 was 2 inches shorter but had the power connectors on the end of the card adding 2" to the card length. This new AMP! card has the power connectors on the top of the card, so you may also want to check your case width to make sure it will fit. Sorry I didn't measure the height of the card so I'm not sure if the listing here is correct, Amazon shows 4.3" but NewEgg shows 5.83". It's close to 5" if I remember correctly. My case is 7.6" wide and I didn't have an issue with the power connectors hitting my 180 mm side case fan. The card requires 2 8 pin power connectors, but it includes 2 adapters for 6 pin connectors. In my case I had dual 4890s in Xfire so I had 4 of the 6 pin connectors to use, so you will need either 4 of the 6 pin, 2 of the 8 pin, or a 8 pin and 2 6 pin connectors; hopefully on different power supply rails. Also as a side note I'd suggest plugging in the power connectors before putting the card into the PCI-E slot. If you put the card in first it requires a good bit of force to plug in the connectors, which are on the part of the graphics card that extends past the edge of the MB and isn't supported. If you have a Micro-ATX board or don't have enough mother board stand offs you may damage your mother board if you insert the card before plugging in the power connectors !

You don't need to use the installation DVD, you can get the drivers and Firestorm software off the website. Someone already mentioned you want the FireStorm_V2.0.0.006E not the Chinese FireStorm_V2.0.0.009C which is the first one listed; scroll down to the correct version. The temperatures of the card are very good. I'm using the default clock and memory speeds. My room temp is 72 F, or 22-23 C and the card idles at desktop at 29-32 C. From what I've been able to read off the internet, idle temps of under 40 C are recommended, and closer to 30 C is better. Temps will be based off ambient room temperature, and in my case are 10 C higher than room temperature. The "auto" temperature control may or may not be able to keep the card under 40 C depending on the cooling properties of your case, since it keeps the fans off until higher temperatures are reached. Using the Firestorm app, I went to settings and checked launch at windows startup option. Then I clicked on the advance button for fan control, to set a fan profile on the user define setting window. I changed the default graph and set the graph to 10% fan speed for temperatures of 40 C or less, and left the graph the same for over 40 C. This has the fan set to 10% while on the desktop and keeps my temps at 30 C, and as soon as I start a game it goes to 50% fan speed and adjusts up as temperatures increase. The most demanding game I have is GTA 5. I used nVIDIA GeForce experience software to set the games optimal settings and I'm running at 1920 x 1080. Using a VERY old, ie. 2009, I-5 750 processor I get 60 - 80 FPS, much more enjoyable than my 30 FPS with much lower settings with my old 4890's. The card stays between 40 to 52 C which keeps the fans at about 50% speed. I can't say how quiet the fans are since my case fans make more noise than the AMP! does at 100% fan. The Firestorm app worked well to change the lighting effects, and since my case doesn't have a side window I simply set the STATIC LOGO to off.

As far as over clocking goes, I can't really comment since I don't require it. All the games I have I run at 1920 x 1080 and frame rates are from 60 to 300 FPS, ie. Diablo 3, CIV 5, etc. If you are going to run at 1080 resolution, I don't think you are going to need over clocking on any current games to get playable frame rates. Some games, like GTA 5 are more CPU intensive, so if you use an extremely old CPU like mine you can still play games at 60 FPS+, just know the CPU will slow them down. All the reviews I've read say it's pretty much the same at 1440 resolution if you have a newer generation I-5 or better CPU. If you are going 4K you need a GTX 1080.

I hope this review helps if you wondered about card length, MB sage, or temperatures. If I have anything else to report later I'll do an update.

Reviews.title: Updated: Recieved A Faulty Unit / GoW4 Promo Shutdown?
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2016
Reviews.text:
Update - 3/5:
Oddly enough I've seen a decline in performance since I received my replacement card. The boosted core clock speed out of the box won't reach the same speeds even while put under the same tests now, and there's inconsistency while running games, one moment everything is fine and then the framerate will just drop. I haven't even been pushing the card, for the most part I've been playing a few games such as Depth, Team Fortress 2, Minecraft, and Vermintide at 2560x1080. I have completely removed my drivers before performing an install of Nvidia's latest drivers and no luck. I also monitor temperatures regularly and every checks out. I have also tinkered with Rivatuner to see if capping my framerate would help, no luck there either.
I'm curious to know if the issues I'm having are a result of my card having Micron memory, and if it is, why doesn't Zotac have a BIOS update available? Other brands have released them to fix the issue.

Note: I've begun to notice some substantial coil whine while playing games like Dead Island Remaster.

I'll tinker some more and take a look around. If I end up figuring out what's causing my issue or find that I have to RMA my card, I'll be sure to update my review again.

Updated Review - 4/5:
I had received my replacement yesterday and so far, so good! So far, VR games are running better on this than they were on my GTX 760s, DOOM runs great on Ultra/Nightmare at 2560x1080, and I can say Killing Floor 2 is easily maxed out at that same resolution! I'll write up more once I get to test it some more!

Note: This is the first time I think I'm actually angry with Amazon. I can't be upset with them over receiving a faulty product, as things happen and it's not their fault, however, the fact their support won't make any comment in reply to my attempts to reach out to them about the GoW4 promotion is not only frustrating but also upsetting. I have also attempted to reach out to Nvidia and they were of no help, they clarified some things but didn't provide any actual assistance or hope. I have also reached out to Zotac, maybe they can help! *Fingers Crossed*

Update: Unfortunately Zotac wasn't helpful. :(

Original Review - 2/5:
First off, I'll just say if I do decide upon a replacement and receive one that works I'll certainly update my review. From specs to aesthetics the AMP! Extreme edition card is beautiful!

However, the beautiful aesthetics and performance were buried by hours of troubleshooting with no success... I purchased this as I intended to upgrade from my dual GTX 760s so that I could begin my journey into realm of VR and enjoy those pesky games what held me back before. Well, the hype was cut short as the unit I had received doesn't want to cooperate in the slightest. One second it's causing my monitor to flicker as if it were a light fixture at a rave party, the next second it appears to be working fine and then locks Windows down to a complete halt. Sometimes I can get into a game but the second I either close out or alt-tab the system locks up! It was extremely frustrating.
After plenty of troubleshooting, I've come to the conclusion that I've received a faulty card. This is definitely a knocker as this is the first Zotac card I've purchased and it sets me back as I have to wait for a replacement if I decide to go that route and can't enjoy the beautiful HTC Vive sitting on my desk... (Edit: I connected my GTX 760s back up and I'm playing VR games with my Vive relatively fine with a few hitches here and there. The most noticeable graphical glitches popped up during H3VR, Nvidia's VR Funhouse, as well as The Lab.)

Other Notes: The lighting on the card itself looks great, however, colors appear to be off. Yellow appears to be a lighter green, white appears to have a tint of blue, etc. while using Firestorm off of the included disc. Unfortunately, I hadn't the opportunity to see if the issue was resolved with a newer version of Firestorm as when I attempted to access Zotac's website earlier today it was down.
During troubleshooting, I was able to start the Time Spy benchmark for a few minutes before a system lock-up. During that time, I noticed that the temperature and clock speeds were great while the card was doing its job. I was impressed until it locked up...
It's also a bummer that Amazon shafted people including myself in regards to the Gears of War 4 promotional code. Upon contacting their support about it, I have received generic emails back that have no correlation to the promotion.

"New update" This Card only uses 250 watts Max I have a EVGA 500 watt bronze Power supply its powering up my whole system I also Overclocked my GTX 1070 Amp Extreme and used 5 Bench marks My max temperature was 65 degrees Celsius I had MSI Kombustor running for 45 mins and right when I Closed Kombustor down the temperature instantly dropped back to temperature below 38 Celsius LOl so yeah these fans are very awesome they will get loud but NO game Will EVER stress your GPU to that level or get high Temperatures so your fans will never reach those's levels or loud sounds they are meant to run very fast and loud to keep your GPU from catching on fire. for the most part youll never ever hear them only if your running multiple programs down loading videos music or some other crazy things we do on the internet streaming while playing your games or what ever the fans don't get loud if your only playing the game or doing both streaming and gaming with music playing again THEY DONT GET LOUD if your only doing that, but if your doing extreme overloads that only bench marks and stress test do then YES. the fans do get loud so that your GPU wont catch on fire

Reviews.title: ZOTAC GeForce GTX 1070 AMP! Extreme
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2016
Reviews.text:
First of all I have been waiting for Nvidia's Pascal for quite some time, and I tried jumping on the GTX 1080 at launch, but had no luck due to supply shortages, and after 2 weeks when the GTX 1070 came out, I concluded that the 1070 was the better choice price/performance wise, so here we go..

Initial impressions on the card, after unboxing I was Amazed at the size of this thing, honestly it's HUGE, no it's rather GiGANTiC I kept reading how people were saying that the Extreme is very big I always thought they were exaggerating, I never thought they were actually this BIG, and that of course thanks to the extra large hefty 3 fan cooler, I also had to remove one of the HDD cages on the NZXT Phantom 530 case, a Full tower large case, to fit this card in place which just shows how large this card is.
The Carbon style ExoArmor and Backplate Looks really cool and they do blend quite nicely together with my build, the added LED is a nice touch as well.

Pros:
- Nice Aesthetics, Carbon fiber touch, Backplate and LED lightning is really cool
- Excellent build quality
- The Fans are quite even at around 60-70%
- Great Performance on Titles like The Witcher 3, Getting 63-81 FPS On Ultra everything minus hairworks @ 1440P resolution
- Superb Cooling, at first it did idle at around 45C which I though was quite high, and that's with the Fans stopped and at a high room temperature since it's summer here (temps where I live are around high 30's to 40's C), so I used a custom Fan curve in MSi Afterburner and now it Idles around 32-34C @32% fan speed. When the Air conditioner on and room temps @ around 24-25C the Card idles at around 26-27C @27% fan speed with the custom fan curve, Load temps running The Witcher 3 never exceeded 58C @48% fan speed, which I believe is outstanding !!
- Out of the box Boost to 1976 MHZ While playing The Withcer 3

Cons:
- A large and heavy Card, but you should already expect that if you're going with the Extreme, it's 2.5 slots width and might require you to remove the opposite HDD cage even in large cases as in my case (NZXT Phantom 530)
- Due to the weight, it sags quite a bit, but that's probably OK !

System Specs:
- Gigabyte GA-Z170X-Gaming7 MotherBoard
- Intel Skylake 6700K @stock with Cryorig H7 Cooler
- G.skill TridentZ 3200Mhz DDR4 16GB RAM
- EVGA 850GQ PSU
- Acer XB271HU 1440P 165hz IPS G-Sync Monitor
- NZXT Phantom 530 Case

Other thoughts:
An amazing Card all in all, excellent cooling capacity, nice looks and great performance, would definitely recommend buying this card, even over a 1080 as it's the better price/performance rival !!

Reviews.title: Titan X performance for less than half the price? Sign me up
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2017
Reviews.text: When I saw the gtx 1080 when it first released, I realized two things. One, I wanted this card. Second, I didn't have the patience to save up for it. That's when this bad boy comes in. The GTX 1070 is a beast at $449 (or at least that's what they cost when I bought them, thanks 1080Ti). I originally had the 1070 ftw but bought 2 zotac founders cards because of sli. Every game I play with just one card card can be run at 4k max settings (except for anti aliasing), usually hovering around 60 if not going over, with some titles dipping into the mid 30s if you're in a really intensive part of a map or whatever, i.e project cars at night with rain and stuff. While this card can do 4k, 1440p is still the sweet spot for this beast. That was before overclocking. I don't know if my cards are golden (I say "cards" because I'm running 2 in sli) but to me +215 on the core and +500 on the already faster than usual gddr5 is pretty good. Speaking of sli, it's not a nightmare. It doesn't always work but when it does, it works very well (I'm using the sli hb bridge if it helps). Using pcars as a reference, at night with rain on circuit de 24 heures du mans with no other cars to eliminate cpu bottleneck, both cards in sli manage north of 100fps at 4k max settings except for anti aliasing and fxaa because 4k doesn't need that. That's impressive in my books. So performance is great, but what about the card itself? It's a high quality item and it knows it. The shroud is beautifully finished, with the illuminating GeForce logo reminding everyone that you're pro mlg, just as long as your case has a window. The backplate is also nicely done, and the patterns look cool. Half of the backplate is removable to allow better airflow in sli. I haven't removed the plate yet but I plan to. In fact, i ought to, the top card gets kind of toasty as my motherboard doesnt have pcie slot spacing that leaves room between the 2 cards. The card comes with a driver cd which is nice for first time installs, as well as installation of firestorm, zotac's overclocking utility. I personally prefer precision but firestorm isn't too far behind. It also comes with (I think 2) 2x6 pin to 8 pin connector(s?). Overall, the 1070 is amazing value, and the Zotac 1070 founders is a good version of this card. Maybe I'll buy a 3rd and see how much further I can get in 3dmark firestrike :)

Reviews.title: Amazing card, excellent build quality.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2016
Reviews.text:
I purchased this video card after hesitating on if I needed it and waiting on a price drop. I had an Nvidia Geforce 970 GTX SSC from EVGA and I had purchased that card earlier this year and it was also very good for what I did. I was upgrading my monitor to a 1440p and needed the extra horsepower that a new Nvidia 10 series card would provide. Boy was I estatic that I upgraded and purchased the 1070 GTX from Zotac. Normally I purchase almost exclusive EVGA products but after reading the reviews on this card and comparing its specs to similar cards offered from other manufactures I settled on Zotac. I can't speak enough on the build quality of the card, its hefty and feels luxurious in your hand, the carbon fiber accents are perfect. This card is perfect for 1440p and will do 4k in a pinch and absolutely demolish anything in 1080p with max settings.

Not really a con but something to be aware of, the card itself is massive. I know that people have said that on the reviews but reading and seeing pictures do not do the card justice of seeing it in your hand. I compared my old EVGA 970 GTX to this and the Zotac 1070 GTX was easily about an inch and a half longer and it felt heavier as well. Be sure to utilize all the supports provided by the motherboard and you should be fine. I have a Corsair 600c case and I have plenty of room but just be aware and plan accordingly. I would also suggest going to Zotac's official site and downloading the software for controlling the lights on the card and fine tuning software instead of installing from the disk.

I think I have found my new go to video card manufacture for whenever I need to upgrade cards. I am Participating in ZOTAC Experience but even if I wasn't I would make a post about this card and company as I myself was hesitant when looking at Zotac products. I am happy that I made this purchase and love the new Nvidia 10 series cards!

Reviews.title: Huge size, huge performance!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2016
Reviews.text: The Zotac 1070 AMP! Extreme is a very large video card. It's also a really solid preforming video card! After setting it up and preforming benchmarks it preforms better than any other 1070 I've worked with. It's ability to overclock is fantastic and it's size is due to the cooling system they have created. The size is both great and a slight problem. It will really sag in your case due to all the armor and the cooling system. On the other hand, it has all this nice armor and a beefy cooling system that allows you to run at temps lower than other 1070 cards on the market, especially when overclocked. I'm also a fan of the aesthetics. It might be over the top for some but I like it. Zotac ships it with their firestorm software which is fine for setting fans, clock and memory speeds. The lighting is nice - but not it's not true RGB. The firestorm software allows you select from 8 colors and has minimal effects. Overall this is a solid video card - probably the best preforming 1070 on the market right now but it's huge and will sag. If you are looking for pure performance in a 1070 this is your card, if you care about aesthetics there are some issues with the sag and the lighting.

Reviews.title: Purchased for Alienware X51 R2 - Excellent performer!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2016
Reviews.text:
Purchased ZOTAC GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition for my Alienware X51 R2. The card is too large for an easy change out and required some slight case modifications that were relatively simple. I expected this so it was no surprise. The card is 10.5 inches long, and the 8 pin PCIe power plug sits at the very end of the card on the left side (right side or bottom of the Alienware X51 R2 Case. After some small modifications to the computer case only, the card squeezed into place. It runs perfect and is much cooler and quieter than the older card. It's not overclocked out of the box, but it doesn't need it. It's a monster and can handle the most extreme of games. There's room to overclock with the Alienware 330W PSU. It came with the Driver Disc, information card, and a PCIe 6x2 pin to 8 pin adapter. This card has a DVI-D (DL) port, one HDMI, and three DisplayPort connections. If you have a display that only supports VGA, you will need to get a DisplayPort to VGA adapter since DVI-D has no analog support.

For Alienware X51 R2 users, you will need to remove the front grill fan from the computer- you will not need it. Some cutting of the internal dust screen at the bottom of the computer case was needed to give room for the 8 pin PCIe power plug. This may be avoided if you also purchase a 6pin to 8pin power adapter with a right angle plug on the 8pin side.

Reviews.title: Its a FE so no different than my Nvidia branded FE's
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2017
Reviews.text: While I waited for the EVGA version of the 1070FE to become available, discovered when it did become available, that the price had shot up $50. I have been very happy in the past with the EVGA cards, I've owned just about every generation since the 400 series. But since I had gone with the Founders Edition for my two other computers, was happy to discover the Zotac GTX1070FE basically at the same price of the EVGA 1070FE when it was on my Wishlist. Since all FE are the same was happy to get the Zotac version. Never had any prior experience with Zotac but had read that they were generally held in good esteem. So no doubts so far. Have noticed I seem to have one card on the low end of the silicon lottery compared to the other card, but not really a big deal since the cards are used for distributed computing projects, a slight reduction in core clocks is not that important overall. The cards have already made a huge improvement in my recent average credit compared to my old GTX 970s. The cards went into my new Ryzen system and it has quickly eclipsed my other two computers to become my fastest cruncher.

Reviews.title: HD5770s and 6770s never came with 4GB of VRAM! AVOID!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2022
Reviews.text:
The vast majority of HD6770s did not come with a VGA port. The real ones also require a 6-pin power connector. Most cards that have an output layout like this are fake and, seeing reviews from people saying it won't run DX11, I'm inclined to believe this isn't even a 6770 as those did run DX11. The listed clock speed is about 200mhz lower than the original cards which, at best, points to these being faulty cards flashed with a different BIOS to operate at a lower clock speed. HD 5770s and 6770s (same card with 2 names) also NEVER came with 4GB of VRAM.

Again, this points to this being a card with a fake BIOS. I've tested another faked GPU claiming to be a GTX 960 4GB and the card even reported itself as such to the computer. In actuality it was a GT640 with 1GB of VRAM. When a game would try to utilize the reported 4GB of VRAM that didn't exist, it would cause the computer to crash.

Best case scenario here, you get a GPU that was originally released in 2009 (as the 5770, again, identical to the 6770...AMD just renamed the same card 2 years later) which has not received driver support since 2015, running at 76% of it's original speed (which may be how it gets away without a 6 pin power connector...but I doubt it) and have to spend some time dialing in settings to avoid games using more than 1GB of VRAM so the computer won't crash. In other words KEEP SHOPPING!

Reviews.title: Great budget card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2022
Reviews.text:
Old man Dad on a budget here. Purchased this to upgrade from onboard graphics when stadia was announced that they were cancelling.

Slapped it in, loaded up Elder Scrolls Online and can say I'm pleased with the card. I run it on the high setting no problem. It can handle ultra but the framerate drops below my comfort but it can run it.

For a budget card it works well for me. Would recommend.

(I'm running a 10th gen core i5 with only 16gb of ram...still the card performs better than expected)

Reviews.title: I NEEDED A CARD TO CRUISE AROUND THE INTERNET WITHOUT ISSUE AND THIS IS IT!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2022
Reviews.text:
I just needed a basic video card to cruise around the internet without being stifled by lame performance of a cheap video card. While this card is a tad expensive it is not priced at the ridiculously insane prices of the middle to high end gaming video cards in 2022. This GPU has done the job of letting me go anywhere on the internet without video lag.

I had a more expensive NVIDIA GPU in my system with otherwise state of the art hardware. The newest most power Ryzen 9 \ 5900 CPU, fast memory and a 750 watt power supply. The NVIDIA GPU ran like hot garbage on my Ubuntu system. Ubuntu has a nasty sepia color scheme that saturates the entire OS and everything in it. It is not only ugly but painful to look at due to my vision issues.

I did not know for sure at the time but, I hoped a new video card from someone other than NVIDIA might perform better. Turns out this AMD designed GPU got rid of the nasty sepia tint. This video card creates a simple un-tinted OS that is a pleasure to use. The card is not BIG and uses only the power supplied by the GPU slot.

The card has some energy saver garbage installed that turns the card off if you power down your monitor. I took a star off for the energy saver mess. There really are no other issues. This is a great card to use on a Linux\Ubuntu system that is not used for hard core gaming.

Reviews.title: Great for what it is
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2022
Reviews.text:
I recently built my first gaming pc in 20 years. I ordered everything but the graphics card, and when I went to research and price them... Whoa! Man have things changed in 20 years! Needless to say I needed something until I could afford a good graphics card. Enter MaxSun Radeon RX550. This card actually impressed me. Not only was I able to get my system up and running, I was also able to play a few of my favorite games, like BeamNG.drive. Granted, the settings were on Low and some on Medium, and the FPS wasn't optimal, but it was definitely playable.

While I wouldn't recommend this as a primary card for gaming, it makes a great backup.

Reviews.title: It does what I needed it to do
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2022
Reviews.text:
At my workplace I needed this half-height graphics card for a PC running a graphics intensive application that was practically unusable using the on-board graphics on the PC. Installing this card resolved the performance issues. I was pleased enough with that purchase that I bought one for my home computer to resolve some lag issues when playing 4K video on my old PC. This card resolved that issue, too. I don't know how this product benchmarks against the completion. I didn't do any testing like that. I simply had performance issues with applications that needed a graphics card performance boost. The price was right on this graphics card and I found that it worked fine to resolve those issues.

The only issue that I had was that the package came with no English instructions, no drivers and no software. I am an IT technician by trade, so I had little trouble finding the right drivers and software online. On one PC, Windows Update found the drivers, but I still had to download and install the correct version of the Radeon software. On the other PC I had to download both the drivers and software. So, this wasn't much of a problem for me, but it may be more than a novice PC users can deal with.

This product did what I needed and I've had no problems with it either at home or at work. It gets a 5 star rating from me even though I would have expected better instructions for installing the product and obtaining the correct drivers & software.

Reviews.title: Works Great. No Extra Power Needed.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2022
Reviews.text: I needed a low profile video card for a small form factor computer that didn't require it's own power source, and didn't cost a fortune. This one fit all 3 requirements. It was a simple install and the software was easy to find and download.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on August 29, 2022
Reviews.text:
Diese Grafikkarte ist absolout NICHT VR fähig ! Wer VR möchte MUSS mehr investieren !

Dennoch möchte ich diese Grafikkarte einmal für ihre erstaunliche und herausragende Leistung loben.
Hier hat MAXSUN alles richtig gemacht!

Ich habe einen Rechner mit ordentlich Leistung und natürlich auch mit einer entsprechenden Grafikkarte um damit die Valve Index VR-Brille zu betreiben. Ich bekam ein ausrangiertes Fujitsu Esprimo C710 mit USB3.0 und einem betagten aber ausreichenden Prozessor und suchte nun nach einer Low Profile Grafikkarte, die dabei auch noch schlank und bestmögliche Leistung bringen sollte.

Mein verrückter Plan:
Wenn an meinem Rechner was abraucht, sollte der kleine Esprimo das Ganze überbrücken.
Mit 32GB RAM und der MAXSUN Radeon RX 550 ist mir das sehr gut gelungen.
Wir reden hier natürlich von minimalistischen Grafikeinstellungen ABER BeatSaber, Phasmophobia (SinglePlayer), Pistol Whip und Blade & Sorcery sind durchaus spielbar und die Karte wird dabei nicht übermäßig heiß. Half Life - Alyx hingegen lagt sehr deutlich (wie es auch zu erwarten ist)

Dies ist keine Kaufempfehlung für VR, es soll aber verdeutlichen, was die kleine Karte auf dem Kasten hat.
Denn hier schlägt sie die vergleichbare GT 1030 um längen. Für Titel wie Diablo III und Co ifinde ich die RX 550 völlig in Ordnung und sie macht dort auch eine echt gute Figur.

Fazit: Es gibt natürlich deutlich stärkere Grafikkarten, egal ob AMD oder NVIDIA aber wer bei dem aktuellen Auf und Ab der Grafikkartenpreise eine günstige und verhältnismäßig starke Grafikkarte sucht, weil er sich gerade keine große leisten kann oder wie bei mir für einen kleineren Zweitrechner, sollte hier gut bedient sein.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on September 7, 2022
Reviews.text:
Hab wirklich lange und intensiv nach einer neuen, bezahlbaren und vom Preis nicht so abgehobenen Grafikkarte gesucht. Hier passt das Preis/Leistungsverhältnis für mich gerade noch so. Wir zocken wenig wenn dann Strategiespiele, Autorennen usw eine unserer Anforderungen war die Grafik entscheidend zu verbessern ohne Unmengen Geld zu investieren. Also neuer Monitor, Grafikkarte und ein zusätzlicher Speicherblock. Das Ergebnis kann sich mehr als sehen lassen!!!
Kein geruckel mehr und eine schön saubere Grafik, das beste die Grafikkarte wird bei uns nicht mal warm, läuft also alles sauber. Für 160€ kann man bei der Karte nichts verkehrt machen!

Reviews.title: A solution to a problem.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2022
Reviews.text:
A family member had their monitor burn out and a 4K monitor was bought. Sadly, the built-in video card in the older computer was not strong enough to support the max resolution.

This video card did exactly that. And it is fine for a computer that is used for surfing, basic desktop work, etc. But once you want to watch a full-screen 4K video it struggles. Badly.
To be fair here, the 10-series were not built for 4K. But it needs to be said: it is one thing to do static work on 4K resolutions; once you go to a high-quality media display this is not the card you are looking for.

So this card does what it needs to do - and it will perform fine for most things in resolutions under 4k. It is affordable and available. But don't buy this one for high-quality gaming or intensive video or animation work.

Reviews.title: Excellent "budget" GPU for 1080p gaming PCs. Also works decently for 1440p!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2017
Reviews.text:
This EVGA 1050ti provided much better performance than expected. The 1050ti is a great GPU for budget gaming builds or when you have a limited power supply. There is no 6 or 8 pin power plug on this card, just plug it into the motherboard and you are done. This bothered me at first, I wasn't sure it would be getting enough power. But it turns out that wasn't an issue at all. This thing sips power, and if you run the Precision OC or MSI Afterburner software, you will see the GPU cruises at just a couple hundred mhz until it's needed for gaming, where it goes close to 1800mhz, and can be overclocked close to 2000 (but I just leave it at the default, it works great). Although this 1050ti SSC has a higher clock speed out of the box than the smaller base model 1050ti cards, if you want to do any extreme overclocking, you may have better results with the 1050ti FTW, which does have a power connector on the card and allows for a higher current draw.

Overall, I had excellent results with some of my older games. CS:GO and Skyrim regular edition (no mods) ran at a steady 130-150fps at almost the highest settings, and by turning down things like shadow detail and reducing the anti aliasing, I was able to get the framerate very close to matching the 165hz of my Dell S2417DG monitor at 2560x1440 resolution! That is very impressive, but they are older games so high framerates are expected. I tried the new DOOM game, which is well optimized from what I understand. at 1080p settings, I was getting a steady 60fps on fairly high settings. The trick with this card is to know where to compromise. If you want Ultra quality at 4k with the newest games at a high frame rate in 2017, this card isn't for you. But with a couple video settings tweaks, you can really get some nice looking performance from this 1050ti SSC.

As of the time of this review, 1060 and 1070 GPUs are still greatly overpriced, and the jump to a GTX 1080 is pretty steep if you are trying to build a "budget" gaming PC. Once 1060 prices come back down to earth, that may be a better option, but for now I have been very impressed with the 1050ti. For 1080p gaming, I would recommend it for any budget build. I do want to note that I was using an i5-6600k (not overclocked) and I never saw my CPU pegged at 100% during these tests. If you decide to use something like a G4560 CPU (which is amazing for the price), you may not get quite the same performance on some games, depending on how CPU dependant they are. I apologize for not being able to test this card with a slower processor, all I had available was my Z170 motherboard and the i5-6600, and I'm also running 16gb G.SKILL 3000mhz ram and a Corsair gold rated 550w power supply. Fairly hefty specs, but as I mentioned earlier, I didn't want to pay double the price of this 1050ti for a GTX1060 6gb. This GPU gives great performance for the price, and I'm very impressed with it so far.

Reviews.title: Awesome Video Card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2017
Reviews.text:
Pros
Price
4GB of DDR5 Dedicated Video RAM
Nicely Packaged
Incredible Graphics
Quiet (I got the single fan one)

Cons
Not sure I found any but if you want dual monitors be prepared to use different cables for each monitor or I suppose purchase some sort of Y cable for either DVI, Display Port or HDMI port. This Card only has one connector for each of these cables which for me is not an issue.

Review -
I received this card two (2) days ago and I promptly installed it and test it. I work in IT so I didn't need to read the instructions but it comes with a Display Driver Disk, a little installation instruction manual, a quick start fold out sheet and a pretty fancy metal sticker. All documentation comes in English, German, Spanish, French, Portuguese and 3 different Asian languages (I am guessing they are Japanese, Korean and Chinese).

I didn't have to change my power supply since mine is able to handle 450Watts but you should know you would need at least a 300Watts Power Supply. In fact, before you buy any Video Card you should go to the manufacturer and see what it requires and adjust accordingly (either buy a new Power Supply or buy a different card). However, I don't know any systems that carry a 250Watts Power Supply anymore all of them are either 300 or 350Watts and if you bought or built a Gaming Rig I'm sure you went insane with the Power and got the biggest thing you could afford.

PCIE Connector and mine didn't require any additional power other than the one provided by the Motherboard which made swapping out cards extremely easy. I installed the Drivers provided by EVGA and then I launched my NVIDIA GEForce Experience and Updated the Driver to the latest (my previous card was also an NVIDIA card). It took me longer to unplug all the cables and break my computer open and put it all back than it did to install the card and the drivers.

Noticeable improvement in Video on Games and Performance. I tested it against a recently purchased Game which is still in Beta (Star Citizen) which was very Jerky and requires a minimum of 2GB or RAM (I had just below 2GB at 1.7GB with my old one). Not only did it render it beautifully the performance improvement was evidently. I also test it with Mass Effect 2 (which my old card could handle easily) and the improvement in video detail was amazing (my wife who is not a gamer could tell the improvement immediately even though she's only seen the screen periodically here and there). I tested it against SWTOR and I increased all the Graphics settings to high (which was nice to see the effect) and it handled beautifully.

I have not done any Arena style gaming yet so I cannot speak on its performance on PVP and Arena Style games. However, it handles fine in fights, zero lag or any issues that I have found.

I am very happy with this purchase so far. I was fretting between the EVGA, MSI or GIGABYTE one and looked at all the overclocking specs until I went cross eyed. In the end I chose one that fit my budget below $160 and to be honest for the level of gaming I am doing (no VR obviously) it doesn't matter all the overclocking. The bottom line is 4GB of dedicated DDR5 RAM just for Video.

If you are fretting look at three things
1. Get a card with minimum 128bit Memory Bus
2. Get at least 4GB
3. Price

Reviews.title: A very well balanced videocard.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2019
Reviews.text:
What I like about the 1050Ti is that it strikes an excellent balance of things. It runs very cool and quiet while still performing excellently. You probably don't want to use this for anything like VR, but for normal ~1080p gaming or whatever it's great. It's extremely low power and very efficient, so your power bill won't go up just from playing games.

But there's not much point in reviewing a specific GPU since that's not a specific product but a range with variance. As for the actual product itself overall I'm fairly satisfied. I don't like flashy LEDs and such inside my computer so I wish it didn't do stuff like that, but it's overall not bright and not too bad (I still clipped the LEDs though.) One thing that annoys me about this entire range of eVGA products (eg 1060, 1080, etc etc) is a very odd choice they seem to have on the cooling: they turn the heatsink fins up and down instead of left and right. What this ultimately means is that the rear output is fake and pointless. All the heat from the videocard exhausts above and below it. That means some pools towards the bottom of the case to be recycled (unless you have one of those turbine fans mounted below taking up a slot) and some goes towards the CPU. Now, this is a pretty efficient line, so it doesn't put out a lot of heat (especially the 1050 -- even the Ti version) but how hard really would it have been to simply have the fins go left and right so at least some would exhaust out and the rest would be caught up in the normal fuller airflow? It's just a silly and pointless design mistake that shouldn't have been made even on these cooler cards since it wouldn't have cost anything extra simply to have the fins turn the other way. Since the fins turn the way they do it effectively blocks any air from actually going out that way.

The other thing that annoyed me was the connector choices. One DVI, one HDMI, and one DisplayPort (why?) I would rather two HDMI or two DVI than a DisplayPort connector, but I think the most optimal solution would have been to include an adapter. Unfortunately I end up with the wrong monitor as "primary." It's fine within the OS itself, but the BIOS, bootup menus, initial setups, etc etc all end up on the wrong monitor. Given that the second half of the card is not _ACTUALLY_ a rear exhaust, they may as well have used that area to spread out the connectors more and maybe provide an extra along the way.

Now, all that said, it's overall a good card. The fan is very good and quiet with plenty of CFM and the heatsink makes quite good contact. The general build quality feels pretty good and I think this card will last a good long time. Even with the LEDs it doesn't actually look bad (I've seen some very questionable design choices out there, so this can be a consideration even if one doesn't care much about looks.)

Reviews.title: Terrific Budget Card That Performs As Good As It Costs
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2017
Reviews.text:
SHIPPING AND PRICE:
The price is very reasonable for what you get out of the card in terms of performance (More about that later). It took around 2-3 weeks and $4-8 to get the card to me in Australia in the outer suburbs of Wollongong.

INSTALLATION:
The installation was almost idiot proof, i use an Alienware X51 case since i have had this PC for over two years and have had no money to build my own PC at the time i got the PC (I was 13). It is has no need for power pin connectors, it only draws power from the PCI slot which, in my situation with the extremely small case is great. The only thing i needed to do was remove the black graphics holder so the card doesn't hang (Don't worry about that if you have another case, this is only a problem for us poor Alienware users ).

The next part was the part i have never had to do before since this is my first time upgrading my PC with something significant, the software installation. At first i tried playing games and the computer would just lag like hell in the games, after ten mins of confusion and thinking i realised i needed to insert the installation disk to put in the new software for the card, after around 10-30 mins of installing, it was ready to be gamed on. :)

PERFORMANCE AND SOUND:
It is literally dead silent, my computer use to sound like a jet and now its a toned down jet (still a jet due to CPU cooler). Also the performance, for me at least was day and night (Coming from a crappy Dell GeForce GTX745).

Coming from barely running "Next Car Game: Wreckfest" with 20-30fps on low settings to all the way to 50-60fps on fully maxed out settings on 1080P (you could say it was a massive leap for me). https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u3rCE8Ivv4A&t=26s

Playing Unturned on Medium settings with 20-40 fps depending on many factors, now i can play it with settings maxed on 40-70 fps.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zR2YLdTmvmU

Counter Strike: Global Offensive use to run at around 40-70 fps on the "Canals" map and now runs perfectly at 120-150fps easily.

OVERCLOCKING:
(Your results may vary, every card has a different maximum OC )
Now, i can already hear from my fellow #PCMASTERRACE "Why OC a card that is already OC stock?" well let me explain.
Coming from a graphics card that i got forced to push to the max to even play many games on low settings mainly, it is sort of a habit i have developed. Now, i can't help to brag but after testing out the games on stock without an OC, the card ended up being better then a FTW card when i overclocked it. Do i recommend overclocking this card? Yes, but when you are doing so, please do not tell the MSI or EVGA overclocker to use that OC on startup until you know that OC is stable enough. Also remember not all cards are made equally, someone out there could of pushed the card an extra 400Mhz but you can only do 140Mhz.

COOLING:
There is no debate about cooling, even in my case, with an OC, the card stays very cool no matter the situation.

CONCLUSION:
It is currently the best budget gaming card for this price point. The graphical power is the same or even a little more then what you paid for, it doesn't suck much power at all, doesn't require an power PIN connector and is dead silent. In my eyes i dont see any cons.

Well.....

Maybe one...

Where is the RGB lighting??

Reviews.title: Stand-in replacement for GT 620
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2017
Reviews.text:
So, I upgraded from a GT 620 to this GTX 1050 ti, making it my first game-grade card. This was also the first GPU I've ever installed, but I was able to do it without using a manual. In terms of difficulty, it's between RAM and HDD in difficulty but closer to RAM. The hardest part was researching the available cards.

My top reason for choosing this card is that it is the top-performing card that I was prettily sure would run on my current power supply and fit in my system. I'm using the same 300 W power supply that came with my rig and I have a core i5 (quad), two HDDs, a USB hub, and one monitor attached. I haven't noticed any increase in temperature or noise, and I haven't experienced any unexpected shutdowns. Since installing the card, however, I did notice that DWM (Desktop Window Manager) would occasionally become unresponsive in Windows 7, forcing me to forcefully restart the system, though I can't say with certainty that the card was the culprit or that it only happened after installing the card. Either way, since updating the GPU driver, the problem has never resurfaced.

My old GT 620 was somewhere between an Wii U and Xbox One in terms of power, while the 1050 is beyond the PS4 Pro. It's worth noting that NVidia states that this GPU does not support VR, though this was not a deal breaker for me. I found it interesting that some predecessors in the 900 series had VR support, but those cards also seemed to require external connectors, which was a deal breaker for me, since I planned to play console-style titles in the future. So, it looks like they had to sacrifice VR support for power consumption.

One of the best features of recent NVidia GPUs is Share (i.e. ShadowPlay), a feature which allows gamers to record and broadcast their gaming sessions. In the past I've tried using CamStudio to record gameplay, but it had some issues with flickering and recordings inexplicably stopping. Share addresses these problems and there is no noticeable hit to performance. Well, under Windows 7 there is a 4 GB file-size limit for video files, since Share uses Windows Media Foundation, but the nice thing about the recorder is that it will just create a new video file to continue recording. This does ultimately require long sessions to be stitched if you’re planning to share your footage, but that can be done easily with any video editor. With desktop capture enabled, which is what I use, you can capture anything on screen, even non-games. The GUI for Share could be a somewhat more intuitive, but it mostly stays out of my way. I simply use Alt+F9 to start and stop recording. One important caveat of Share is that visual styles needs to be enabled for recording to work. Consequently, the emulator Gens cannot be recorded full screen because it disables visual styles when in full screen; it will, however, work if the emulator window is stretched to fill the screen.

I am satisfied with my purchase. It's great being able to game at max settings.

Reviews.title: The Card is Great! Disappointed in Geforce!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2017
Reviews.text: First of all This is not a negative review on EVGA or Amazon! I am very happy with all the EVGA products and Amazon! But, I was a little disappointed in this new GTX-1050 Ti! Over the EVGA GTX-960 I was using! Nothing is wrong with ether card! There is just NO difference! in going to the new GTX-1050 Ti, There is NO difference in Color, Fram Rates, Speed, Nothing? At least noticeable! Or making it worth spending the money for the upgrade? And NO its not my PC, it is very capable of run any Video cards on the market or any combination of cards. Its a Gigabyte GA-990FXA-UD4 With an AMD 8 core Black, CPU Running at 4200 GHz, 16GB RAM, 2 SSHD 1 TB Drives and 1, 2 TB Drive, 850 Watt PS I have external drives for Backup, Flatron D2342 LG Monitor that does 3D and very high resolutions. I feel the real problem is Geforce! Always telling you the you should or need to upgrade! Always updating sometimes 2 times a month? And yet leaving some older cards like in Laptops that you can not upgrade! With NO support at all! And these cards work just fine with todays games and I am sure not going to buy a NEW Laptop every 6 months to keep up with the requests of Geforce! I am very disappointed in that Medea organization! They seem to just be pushing people to buy new and better video cards when the ones they are using work just fine! At this point I will continue to use the GTX-1050 Ti for now, But I am going to try getting an AMD new card and seeing how that goes! I believe Geforce has gotten to big for there britches and are shoving new Medea down consumers thoughts whether they want it or not! Look at there adds when they do an upgrade! If you want to keep up with your games you need to buy this newer card! NO you do NOT! Do some research before buying a new card and see what you find out! If your getting 100 to 150 Frame rates and everything is set to maximum? And your are seeing great detail and great colors even clear underwater? You do not Need an new Video Card! If you do you will Not see any difference in your gaming performance for sure!? Again this is not any marks against EVGA or Amazon! I would give the card a +5 if it was something that I really needed to spend my money on! And it was not! And So, I am disappointed in this perches! I am sure some techie will have a bunch of technical writing to say I am doing something wrong and that's just fine! I have been a lead Tech for a major Bank in my city for 20 some years now retired! But I still build computers for customers and repair them, I know a little about a PC! (o; The card is a +5 no doubt, This is my disappointment in Geforce! Thanks for reading, Rick D.

Reviews.title: Works pretty well, but driver updates stop working after a while.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2019
Reviews.text:
Pros: Works well, decent graphics, no noise problems.

Cons: Forced to create Nvidia account through Nvidia Geforce Experience software in order to update driver. Using Geforce software to tweak games always puts graphics too high. After several updates the Geforce software fails its updates and thus won't allow driver updates.

I bought it for my Windows 7 64-bit desktop tower with quad-core CPU and 12 GB of RAM, to play Overwatch at medium to high graphics and it does its job pretty well. If I run on high graphics (sometimes on medium too) I do occasionally get a Windows prompt when I exit the game about the computer performing slowly and asking if I want to switch to the basic desktop window settings. I get a consistent 60-70 Frames-Per-Second (FPS) and despite the windows warnings I haven't seen any problems with performance. I get the warnings more often if I am also running a background app such as Discord (just an example, it's the only app I might actually want to run along with the game) in the background and so I tend to either exit that app when play or run the game on medium graphics when I need Discord. Although I still don't have any major problems when I do run them both at the same time. The main issue I have is with Nvidia drivers and Nvidia Geforce Experience software. They worked fine for a few months. I installed all the updates, driver and Geforce, but then all of the sudden the Geforce software just wouldn't update. I claims it has one, but when I got to update it just says the update failed. I uninstalled and reinstalled Geforce but it still won't update the software yet still keeps saying there's an update out there, and of course now there is a driver update which can only be installed through the Geforce app. Leaving me with no where to turn. I had this problem with my old Nvidia graphics card (except the driver updates would actually crash the computer and leave me booting into a black screen forcing me to revert to a restore point). Apparently this is a common problem with many Nvidia drivers of all different graphics cards and Nvidia seems to never do a damn thing about it. It's infuriating, but my graphics card still works so I've honestly just given up on updating it for now.

Reviews.title: Fine card, lousy packageing.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2017
Reviews.text:
After about two weeks, no problems to report. Replaced a fanless Nvidia card that wasn't enough to run a 4K monitor. I don't game and probably won't try to overclock. I can't hear any difference in sound level from the old card but I'm not pushing it. It runs a 4K and a 1600 x 1200 monitor fine. The installation was automatic, Shut down, replaced the card and restarted. After a delay while the driver reconfigured, I was able to set up the monitor orientation and haven't really done much since. Obviously, I would have had to install the drivers if they hadn't been there already. An adapter to a standard HDMI would have been a nice touch.

Minor gripes, why it's 4 instead of 5 stars. A manual that's so generic it's a waist of paper and time to try to find any information about my particular card. I actually wasted several minutes looking for the power connector illustrated in the manual that this card doesn't have. If there had been a problem, it wouldn't have helped. The box is no help. Neither will tell me if the non-standard HDMI connector is a mini or a micro, no information about total resolution, just a list of proprietary buzz words that I'm not fanboy enough to care about.

While I was shopping and running my monitor in HD, I made the mistake of wasting a Sunday afternoon going to a Microcenter to see what they had. They had lots of cards, there was not one with enough information on the package to tell me if it would drive a 4K, and preferably more monitor set up. If I'm going to have to look up everything on the net anyway, I prefer to do it at home where I have a nice big display. I didn't feel like trying to find the one guy in the store that might have known what was what. Presumably, I should have memorized all of the various specs so I could pick one out. Or I could go home and check Amazon for the occasional listing that had usable specs, maybe half of them. This is an old story with Amazon, the great majority of sellers have not the faintest idea what they are actually selling. It doesn't seem to occur to them that this cost them sales.

Reviews.title: Simply flawless
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2018
Reviews.text: The sheer amount of work and effort put into this graphics card is reflected in its performance. The AI technology innovation opportunities created by this product are endless. This is the breakthrough technology needed for the future of complex AI computing. The double precision coming out at 7.8 Teraflops and deep learning at 125 Teraflops. This also clocked in the highest score ever on the open CL Geekbench test at 417807. Im currently using my card to run games (dont@me) and when I did boy were they awesome. The graphics are as smooth as a babies butt rubbed with butter. The new Roblox update looked gorgeous and took full advantage of this beast of a GPU. After I tried this, I decided to test its performance on Minecraft. Boy oh boy...this was an absolute champ. I was able to spawn about 20,000 pigs and run around for countless hours hearing their delicate little grunts. I could see the little details in the pixilated Minecraft grass, so lush and thick. The sky rendered so perfectly I almost shed a tear. This graphics card stole my heart. Simply breathtaking. This is by far the best graphics card for use as a eGPU for the MacBook Air. Unfortunately my monitor had massive screen tearing and I misplayed as the mouse was not keeping up. The cards flickered like a candle as they floated across the screen. I then upgraded my monitor to 240hz and you would not believe it, I can now see the air molecules pushing back on the cards as I move them from the Tableaux to their foundation homes. This GPU is the future of Solitaire and I will be recommending it at worlds in Helsinki.

Reviews.title: Awesome Card... For $249-$259 don't get gouged with currently listed price!!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2016
Reviews.text:
#1 I bought this at my Local Fry's for $259. The Currently priced unit on amazon is $349 ($90 more than retail) I paid $10 more than AMD's Reference card. (although I think this unit is a FAN STICKER away from Reference.

#2 I am using x58 Motherboard (Rampage III Formula w/Xeon X5680 clocked @ 3.5Ghz) which is PCI-E 1.1 Compliant, not 3.0.
Result? RUNS AWESOME!

#3 I Ran Steam's VR Qualifying program. I came in Lower Mid Green with a Congratulations! So I'm VR Ready.

#4 I upgraded from an R9-270X and my FPS's in some games have Quadrupled!! But mostly doubled or more. And Paid, today, for the RX480, for just about what I bought the 270x a couple of years ago for almost the same amount. So Major upgrade for me.

#5 I do NOT hear the fan, but I know it's running. (But again, I have a LOT of fans in my case, included the 270x in bottom PCI-E slot (for 2nd monitor until I change over from DVI monitor to DP. Then I'll yank it and upgrade my 2nd computer from it's GeForce 560TI.

#6 I'm using the NEW Radeon Crimson drivers that have Fixed the Power Pull from motherboard. All seems fine, but I don't have anyway to determine what it's draw is.

#7 All in all, currently this is the most powerful, Mid-Price-Range card out there. And DX12 Test was Awesome! Until the GeForce 1060 probably. But this came out first. I've Used Both AMD and nVidia back and forth a lot over the years. So No fanboy of either. I'm just a geek with a budget and no patience for waiting until the next.. next... next... things come out. I was quite happy with my R9-270X but I do want to go VR and this was the first card in my price range to launch.

Go to either Guru3d dot com or tomshardware dot com to see this puppy's benches. Yeah, it's slower than GeForces 1070 and 1080, but for what I do and my price range, it's perfect!! And VR ready.

edit: Just noticed the CPU-Z image I posted shows it has 4GB RAM. But it is the 8GB model and it shows that in the GPU-Z image.

Reviews.title: Great card - extra setup might be required
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2020
Reviews.text:
Unboxed the video card to find that it was in excellent condition. You could tell that it had seen light use and the seller cleaned the fans.

Remember when people used to mine for cryptocurrency? The RX 480 was popular back then, so you might be getting one that was pulled from a mining rig.

If your card boots, but even after installing the latest AMD graphics drivers you get an error in device manager (error code 43 / the Radeon software can’t find your card), the last owner probably flashed the card for mining and you will need to flash it with the stock vbios. There are several YouTube videos that explain how to flash Radeon cards.

Reviews.title: Great Value
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2016
Reviews.text:
The RX 480 is a hell of a card for the price you pay. Is it a 1070 or 1080? Not even close. Is it close to a 980ti? Yes! Which is amazing for the price tag. AMD is making PC gaming affordable for the masses with their new cards, and its awesome.

Should you buy the RX 480 over the 1060? I'd say it comes down to your brand preference, along with the games you play and how long you plan on keeping the card. The 1060 slightly outperforms the RX 480 in many current DX11 games, however, the RX 480 outperforms the 1060 in almost every DX12 games, making it likely to be the better performer in the future. So if you plan on keeping your new card for 2+ years, I'd go with the RX 480 as it is likely to better utilize DX12 in future games.

All in all, this a great card. I would suggest you buy an aftermarket version though, as the reference cards just dont cut it compared to the similarly prices aftermarket ones.

Pros:
Great FPS per dollar, all around amazing value
AMD Freesync for monitors, which is cheaper than Nvidia's Gsync.
Reference card looks sleek

Cons:
slightly high power draw (updates have improved this).
Does run a little loud under full load, but this is expected of a reference card. Buy an aftermarket version for something quieter.

Reviews.title: 980ti killer for 250. Cant go wrong!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2016
Reviews.text:
AMAZING card, but i did not buy on amazon, i paid 250 after shipping for my card on day one. Wait for sellers to restock and do not be fooled by price gougers!!!!
First I want to say, there are a lot of Nvidia fans hating really hard on this card. Thats good. It means they like it.
Second, a lot of people are complaining that you cant OC the card. That is wrong.
The card is practically plug and play everything 1440p Ultra with no issues, and with a little tweaking of card settings, you can actually increase efficiency and lower temps by limiting the power consumption by 10%.... only after you have done that, would i mess with voltage or amperage or frequency or fan speeds.
I have also seen power consumption tests and charts ranging from -50% to +50% and the card had no overheating issues using the stock fan speed settings.
Third, the card is uber sleek and surprisingly quiet, and is just down right sexy.
Lastly I will leave you with,
This card is the best gpu investment dollar for dollar. Period. Breaking it down to performance per dollar and comparing it to other competing cards, it just makes sense to go with Top Tier performance for low end prices.
I AM HAPPY I WENT WITH AMD ON THIS ONE!
