Reviews.title: Works great
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2022
Reviews.text: I use this graphics card for X-Plane on an older Intel 4790 that only supports DDR-3 memory. The program demands a lot of video resources, which the GD-1030 supplies. I cannot run at the highest frame rates, but it runs quite well. I am very satisfied with this graphics card.

Reviews.title: A solution to a problem.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2022
Reviews.text:
A family member had their monitor burn out and a 4K monitor was bought. Sadly, the built-in video card in the older computer was not strong enough to support the max resolution.

This video card did exactly that. And it is fine for a computer that is used for surfing, basic desktop work, etc. But once you want to watch a full-screen 4K video it struggles. Badly.
To be fair here, the 10-series were not built for 4K. But it needs to be said: it is one thing to do static work on 4K resolutions; once you go to a high-quality media display this is not the card you are looking for.

So this card does what it needs to do - and it will perform fine for most things in resolutions under 4k. It is affordable and available. But don't buy this one for high-quality gaming or intensive video or animation work.

Reviews.title: Probably was a return
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2022
Reviews.text: Some of the previous reviewers had opined that there cards might have been returns. I received an open box (no factory tape on the folds) and no documentation on the inside. No disk, manual, or anything for that matter other than the card. Obviously a return. Forewarned is forearmed and I had already gone to the Maxsun website and downloaded the latest drivers. I installed the card and, in fairness, works as advertised. The vendor just needs to ensure that the documentation is in every box. I also haven't registered it (no disk asking me to) but will do that on the website. Arrived on time.

I upgraded my dell with 16 gig (from 8), SSD (from HDD), and now this video card which blows the doors out for the graphics performance I was getting before, for video rendering. No addtional power supply needed, either. It seems happy with my 224w. Very happy. Thanks again!

Reviews.title: Calling all base model alien ware x51 users
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2021
Reviews.text: Okay so to start , can you run gears 5 on 4k absolutely not. Can you run in a stock Alienware x51 without upgrading your power brick and running extra power ? Absolutely yes! Fits right in slim designed case , total install time was 10 min if that. I have looked high and I've looked low for a form fitting card for the x51 without a massive power overhaul. This card is not what I call "gaming" ready but the price point should sell you that. Overall it's slim will definitely fit in a modular case and does the trick of you are looking to do anything that's graphic hungry. Minus of course Fortnite at 60fps consistent. The value is peek. The extra 2gb of room helps to. Hope this is your final review to read before pulling the trigger. I did , great product in an oversaturated market currently

Reviews.title: Perfect for the price in today's market!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2022

Though in Beam.NG, visual settings have to be set to Low for decent-good FPS. It keeps at a decent temperature (35-45°C) while being run at 100% consistently. If you're looking for a good GPU for 3D dense programs such as Second Life, this one is more then capable with the sacrifice of FPS (25-30 at High, 10-15 at Ultra graphics settings).

Reviews.title: Great bang for buck
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2021
Reviews.text: I bought it for my budget build. The whole PC cost about $500, and I get minimum 60fps on most titles I play. Although 60fps is nothing to write home about, I’m able to access steam titles and play games with my friends I otherwise would not be able to. For a budget option, this is definitely a good buy. I had my skepticism because of some poor reviews, but those reviews are frankly incorrect. It came as expected, on time, and snapped into place without any hassles. This is the graphics card for a low level gamer such as myself. Games like Fortnite, Beamng, raft, NBA2K, and more fun fairly smooth. No complaints. You get what you pay for. If you want more performance, spend more. If you’re happy with a micro ATX Ryzen 3 system, buy this graphics card.

Reviews.title: ASUS GeForce GTX 1650 is a good graphic card.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 4, 2021

After replacing with a new 600W PSU, the computer still shows a sign of very fast spinning fans when viewing high resolution video...

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Japan on June 6, 2021
Reviews.text:
ZOTACのロープロファイルの中古gtx1650 GDDR5が、ファンも回らずパソコンに認識できず故障していたため返品した。その代行品としても購入した。
メモリがGDDR6を採用していたことと、今まで使用していた、ロープロファイルのグラボは補助電源がないため、動作が不安定であったりファンが自動的に回転数しなかったりと不具合が多かった。また、余りグラボにお金を掛けたくなかったため、この商品は最安値で購入できて補助電源コネクタ付きだったため自作パソコンのグラボに選択した。
ドライバーやソフトとインストールして、FF15ベンチで試してみたがNVIDIAのアプリや無料のオーバークロックソフトの設定を変えないと途中で動作が止まってしまったりと不安定だった。
また、オーバークロックも故障回避のため、ATI radeonのアプリよりも高速化ができない仕様になっていた。ファンが一回り大きいため、オーバークロックの設定を最大にしてもGPU発熱が50℃程度しか上がらなかった。
画質に関して、オンボードグラフィックやradeonのように特殊な色合いや配色がされないため、動画やゲームの画像に赤みがかかってボヤけたりクッキリした画像が現れないため、PCのデスクワークのような標準作業のようなグラボとしても使用できる。
残念だったことは、ビデオファイルやDVDの画質がこのグラボをパソコンに指しても鮮明にならない。また、画質向上は無理だった。
発売からだいぶ経ったため、高速なグラボでもななくなってきた。GPU速度に不満があり、もう少し処理が速くならないかとイライラしてくる。特に動作が重いゲームのFF15などのベンチマークではFPS値が極端に下がる。動画ファイルを4Kなど高解像度にエンコードをするとエンコードに時間がかかるなど使い勝手が悪い。そのため、グラボの買い換えを考慮する必要が浮かんできた。

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Japan on May 12, 2021
Reviews.text: 静音性は気にしない人は、気にならない人は大丈夫なくらいです。画質も良いです。ゲームはAPEXをやっていますが、だいたいフレームレート100ヘルツくらいはでます。

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Japan on March 27, 2021
Reviews.text:
去年の年末に15,000円くらい（割引込）で購入しましたが、今の価格はちょっとナイ。

HWMonitor 1.43だと何故か消費電力が2倍（最大180W🤣）に表示されますが、GPU-Zだと90Wに収まります。
補助電源があるぶん、ナシのものより動作は安定していてイイと思います。

RTX3050(ti)までの繋ぎにと思い購入しましたが、暫く（年内？）メインになりそうな予感・・・

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Japan on February 13, 2021
Reviews.text:
補助電源ケーブルは付属しません。
商品説明に書いてないのでご注意ください（当たり前だからかな？よくわかりません）
なんにせよ本商品を買うときは、おうちPCの、電源BOXのPCIeコネクタ種類を確認して、それとつなげるPCIe電源ケーブルを用意しましょう。そうしないと、ワクワクで取り付けて電源入れた直後に「補助電源つけろや」てメッセージ出て悲しみに包まれます。僕のように。

それと当製品、補助電源コネクタがマザボの反対側向きにくるので、これをお勧めします↓。
『アイネックス PCI Express用電源変換アダプタ C字型 6ピン上ラッチ用 PX-PCIE6CO』
僕もそうですが、PCあんま弄らない方へ。PCの内部スペースは想像の1/2ぐらいしかなくて、補助電源のケーブルは想像の3倍カチカチです。
僕のPCケースは外幅18センチで、友人にデカさをイジられるくらいどっしりですが、
上のアダプタ無しでは取り付け不能までありました。

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Japan on May 13, 2021
Reviews.text:
RTXのみならずGTX1050Tiあたりまで高騰してしまいました。1050Ti / 1650 / 1660と試しまして、『DX12でゲームプレイ』には1650である本アイテムが下限です。

■HD画面でDX12対応。
DX12対応だけならもっと安くて古いのも対応だけはしてますが、プレイアブルかどうかでいうと1050Tiでは足りませんでした。1650である本アイテムでは1920 x 1200でDX12のミドル設定位まで十分プレイアブルです。2560 x 1440または1600画面で（はさらにお高い）GTX1660のレンジとなります。

■ベンダー提供ドライバ必須。nVidiaでは不足。
nVidiaのドライバはOC / ファン制御ができませんので、ベンダー提供のドライバ必須です（そうでなければファンがうるさいです）。本アイテムはASUSのGPU Tweak2が付属していますが、ASUSホームページにはGPU Tweak3が公開されています。またMSIのAfterburnerは非MSIボードでも利用できます。

総じて1920 x 1200で満足して使っています。RTXデビューを図っていましたがマイニングが収まっても供給量が決定的に足らないようで、もう1年くらい先になりそうです。

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Japan on December 31, 2020
Reviews.text:
省エネ、価格重視で購入しました。
元がオンボードだったので画質・動きの滑らかさ向上を十分感じられました。
音は殆ど気になりません。
自分の環境ではCPUファンの音の方が目立ってます。

総合的には十分満足しています。
上には上があるという事で★４つです。

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Japan on January 9, 2021
Reviews.text:
CPUにグラフィック機能が無いので追加購入しました。
無事組み立て完了!

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Japan on February 11, 2021

値段を考えれば致し方ないが、
色が赤っぽい。
仕事でもクワドロ使っているため
余計に違和感。

3D性能は格段に良くなっている
はずなので、財布が寂しい今は
文句は言わず納得すべし。

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Japan on February 22, 2021
Reviews.text: 写真の編集で使用。画質は、いい。負荷がかかると、連動してファンうるさい。

Reviews.title: Works but installation problems ocurred
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2014
Reviews.text:
I have a HP e9150t Desktop with an Intel Core i7 and 8 GB of RAM running Windows 7 64-bit. It came with a Radeon HD 4650 graphics card to which I hooked up 2-23" LCD monitors. I wanted to add a 3rd monitor so I purchased this graphics card to add to my existing configuration.

After all the setup problems the graphics card is driving the 3rd monitor just fine and everything is good but be aware of various problems I encountered getting to this point.

After installing the card and powering up the system windows recognized the new card. While it was attempting to install the drivers the 2 existing monitors went black (and the new monitor was not functioning yet - no drivers installed at this point). After about 3 minutes the my 2 original monitors came back. I should have stopped there.

Since I generally don't fully trust windows, before I enabled the 3rd monitor I used the included CD to install the ATI/AMD specific software and drivers. After about 5 minutes of installation the monitors went black again. This time they all were still black about 45 minutes later. So I pulled the plug on the PC and restarted.

Once restarting the system it recognized 1 monitor as a generic adapter/monitor (i.e. resolution all messed up). After going into Device Manager I noted the yellow warning triangle on the graphics cards. I had windows update the driver for my original 4650 and that brought back both of my original monitors (although I had to reboot). Then I went back to Device Manager and had Windows update the driver for this card (5450). After a reboot I was able to go into Control Panel > Screen Resolution and Detect the 3rd monitor.

So now I have 3 monitors up and working but no sound. When I hover over the speaker icon it says "No speakers or headphones are plugged in" which i new wasn't correct but since I had to pull the case off I double checked all connections and scratched my head. A google search turned up the following link [...]. Apparently its fairly common for graphics card to assume you don't want to use the on board audio and your speakers but instead want to use their audio piped to the monitor through the HDMI connection. After following the directions in the article (and another reboot) I was able to get the sound back.

Don't know why this had to be so difficult but be warned.

Reviews.title: It gave me more than what I expected, at a very reasonable price.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2013
Reviews.text:
In my particular case, I was beefing up a computer--a Dell Optiplex small form factor 'hotbox' for my brother. (You can stop laughing now...)

I've toyed with the thought of moving it to a tower case, but in the end, I just couldn't find a solution to the various problems that arose from the fancy.

I wanted it to be more potent, and so I got an extra fan, a cooler processor, and this card in hopes that it would at least help my brother do half of his graphics editing projects, and hopefully some beefing up games on the side--he likes both. My criteria for purchase was: "Had to be low profile, had to be cool. Had to use very little power. Oh, and dimensions."

Man, was I stunned...! It can play Left 4 Dead and Team Fortress 2 at max settings (1280X1024 though) with no hiccups, and some programs that didn't recognize the integrated graphics before, suddenly worked...! Even a beefy demo like Sonic Generations actually ran about 20 fps on the card, which is at least playable, and he's played through all of Mirror's Edge (Medium, I think?), all of which were essentially unplayable on the integrated chipset.

It's been in use fairly frequently for about 2 months now, and it doesn't show signs of suddenly collapsing or anything, (I was being way too careful benchmarking/testing the thing,) and even immediately after a heavy hour-long session of intense display and then powering of the machine, the heatsink itself was certainly hot to the touch, but I could still lay my hand upon it comfortably (about a 20 second delay from when I unplugged the computer) and the Catalyst software monitors never go significantly above 60 degrees C. More impressively, I read that this thing pulls 20W of power under its heaviest load, which is baffling how it manages to do what it does anyway with so little!

I'll echo what's been said before--you're better off to save up if you want a gaming card, but if it's just video editing/processing, and games typically older than, say, 2009 or so (not caring for max settings, just nice ones), you probably can't beat this price... If somebody's in a bizarre situation like mine, then let me assure him/her: people aren't kidding when they say that 'anything' discrete is better than integrated graphics. I just honestly didn't expect the wonderfully enormous difference...!

I guess my negatives would be the box art looks really goofy, (=D) and I have my suspicions the Catalyst software (newest version from the site, yes) is a little... stupid...? (I once somehow had two instances, at the same time... it was odd.) Also, setting up the low profile bracket, I had just BARELY enough tape to make the VGA port reach to the new bracket--which was on the card's underside in the incredibly stupid layout of this incredibly stupid case. Not really knocks against the product though.

Just have proper expectations about this thing though, if for some reason it's beginning to look nice, and be aware of a few of the 'loose heatsink' horror stories below in the lower star reviews...

Reviews.title: HD Upgrade for older PC's
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2013
Reviews.text:
Was tasked to upgrade a low profile 2U rack-mounted mission essential computer to push HD content out to an upgraded HD projection system.

The actual specs for the existing system, while older were not bad; Pentium 4 620 / 6GBs DDR2 RAM / 4 250GB SATA HDDs / Intel 915 chipset motherboard with two 1x and one 16x PCIe slots.

The culprit causing the bottle-neck was the anemic Intel IGP tied to the 915 chipset. It simply could not handle any high bandwidth content or video codec over 1024x576. Motherboard had one open PCIe x16. Shopped around and found this 64-Bit** passively cooled (and therefore quiet) Radeon HD 5450 with low profile adapters for under $25 dollars.

Card arrived on time and was installed in under 30 minutes. Downloaded and installed catalyst drivers from AMD... And BAM! Full fluid HD video on a 15' screen.

As an added bonus, since the card can push two displays, a 10 year 21" old touch screen CRT that had been collecting dust was hooked up. BAM! now the playback system can be easily accessed simultaneously from the control room.

Two other devices added were a Samsung Blu-Ray Drive and a USB 3.0 controller internal card reader combo device.

<<FYi>>

This computer is dedicated to video playback and occasional power point presentations. It uses an optimized 64-bit version of the Windows XP OS. The age and strength of the Pentium 4 620 CPU can barely handle today's intricate flash based feature rich web pages and forget about gaming** or multi-tasking. This Radeon HD 5450 video card upgrade is merely a stop-gap measure till a newer system is installed later.

Please note that while any CPU with the SSE3 instruction set is capable of processing HD content, the size and quality of such video is entirely dependent upon the CPU having access to a graphics card capable of delivering the visual data at 24 to 30 frames per second to the display device(s). Upgrading any computer to give a few more months or years of service needs to researched and planned out or will most likely end up wasting you money, patience, and time.

If you are planning an upgrade to an older machine, learn a little about your CPU first using "CPU Z" and visiting the web site: "CPU World"

Reviews.title: Excellent video card...but not use with older HDTV's
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2012
Reviews.text:
I have an old Dell Optiplex GX620 with a SFF chassis. I decided to re-purpose it as an low budget HTPC (for now) as I'm paying $300 a year to the cable company to rent a cable box and DVR. With this rig and Windows Media Center I have a much better user interface as well as a central hub for all my media needs. One of the things the GX620 is notorious for is the design flaw in the small form chassis that causes it to overheat easily. This usually causes the CPU fan to sound like a vacuum cleaner. So I upgraded to a core duo processor, added some RAM, and (after days of research) decided to get this video card. I basically only wanted to invest the absolute minimum to ensure the system runs safely and relatively smoothly. There were basically 3 criteria. 1)It had to be low power usage since the GX620 only has 275W available on its stock PSU. 2)It had to be a low-profile pci card because the chassis. 3)Again, because of the stock PSU not having any spare connectors this card couldn't have any fan. It had to have a passive cooling system which this one does with an attached heatsink. Plus it didn't hurt there was a $15 rebate on this card bringing my overall budget down.

At first I was concerned about it fitting. The card comes with different kinds of brackets depending on what kind of chassis you have. I installed the low-profile one and it snapped in without a problem. The HDMI has a clear, unobstructed path to connect. I plugged it into to my Olevia TV (LT32HV)in my bedroom where I've been testing WMC before setting it up in the living room. The first time everything loaded fine. Windows 7 recognized the card and automatically installed the drivers.When the system rebooted the BIOS screen showed up fine but when it was loading windows the image went black and my TV had an "invalid format" message. I rebooted several times and nothing.When I rebooted in safe mode the image showed but no matter what changes I made to the resolution I had the same issue when rebooting to regular Windows. I tried researching online and the consensus I got was that the TV's firmware needed updating since it was an older HDTV. This was disappointing especially since I cannot find that darn firmware anywhere.I honestly thought something was wrong with the card. So I decided to connect my HTPC to my livingroom Samsung 52" tv (where it's supposed to end up anyway) and everything worked flawlessly. The sound and video all came through the HDMI without making any changes or tinkering with settings. It looks marvelous. The card does get hot but that's what the heatsink is for.

Great value! Great graphics! Awesome price with rebate

Reviews.title: Works Great!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2012
Reviews.text:
I bought this card to replace a Radeon X600SE in a Dell Optiplex GX620 desktop. This computer is about half the size of a midtower so I didn't have a lot of room for the graphics card. I had to use one of the low-profile brackets which came with the card and switching them required a small screwdriver and a wrench. I have never done that before but it was pretty easy after a brief inspection.

Once I installed the Radeon HD5450, I placed the case cover back on but it wouldn't sit flush. Turns out that the 5450 is a bit wider than my original card by about 5 mm. The issue is that the cooling fins wrap around the top edge of the card; you can see it in the picture.

This isn't a deal breaker. I just left the case cover off and since it sits on my desk facing the wall, it's not visible.

This card should be able to play most games but don't expect too much. The Optiplex is hobbled by a weak processor (Pentium 4 3.0 GHz HT) but I have a Dell Zino with a dual core mobile Athlon II and a mobile 5450 that can play modern games. I just finished playing Dead Space 2 on it and I am starting Medal of Honor. I played 30 min of MOH and so far so good. I will try a few games on the Optiplex and I will update later.

Update: Age of Empires III runs well on the Optiplex. It's a bit smoother compared to the original video card. MOH ran acceptably on the Optiplex but there was the occassional lag and screen tearing. My guess is that it is the Pentium 4 processor that is holding back this game and not the graphics card. I played MOH on the Zino and the experience was a lot better despite it having a mobile HD5450.

Reviews.title: Dual monitor support on Dell works great
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2012
Reviews.text:
In the process of upgrading my Dell computers, I was looking for a video card that would

1) easy on the budget
2) quiet - no fan
3) improvement over onboard graphics on Win 7 rating
4) must support dual monitors

In all these areas, the Sapphire Radeon HD 5450 gets 5 stars. The price is on the low end of all video cards being sold. I like the fact that it uses a relatively small heat sink and no fan. Also, fan bearings can develop problems over time, get noisy, so from a reliability standpoint, the fewer moving parts the better. The Dell computers that I am upgrading are a few years old: Vostro 200, Inspiron 537s, and Dimension C521. The Vostro 200 is a full size case while the others are low profile. The video card ships with the full height bracket standard and two low profile brackets for VGA and DVI/HDMI are included.

As for dual monitors, I am using the Viewsonic HD 1080p LED flat panels with both DVI and VGA connectors. So the first monitor (left side) is plugged into DVI, the second monitor is plugged into VGA. Once you boot up the system, it will come up at 800x600 so the first thing to do is load the driver CD.

Reboot after loading the driver, and you will automatically have dual-monitor support. Very nice and easy. Liked it so much that I ordered more cards for the other computers in the office for upgrading.

The Dell Inspiron 537s Windows rating after the card installation:

Graphics: 4.6
Gaming Graphics: 6.1

A significant boost in performance, plus more RAM available to Win 7. I didn't copy down the ratings for the other computers Vostro and Dimension, but they were similar (computers were slower however).

Reviews.title: Everything I was hoping for!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2012
Reviews.text:
I have a Dell Inspiron 560s slim computer, and I have been trying to buy a video card for it for several months now. I ordered two others before this one, and I was very nervous about trying yet ANOTHER card. However, when it arrived I had absolutely no issues installing it into my computer!

My computer has 300 W power and on-board graphics, and I run Windows 7. I wanted to play some games (I am not a "hardcore" gamer by any means though) and use the Adobe Creative Suite. As an artist, I had been very frustrated at the lag on my bamboo tablet, and I need to be able to create my digital artwork both for work and fun.

This card did the trick! It fit in perfectly and has two low profile brackets. I just had to unscrew the long bracket and put the two smaller ones in. The vga connector wraps around to the second bracket nicely once it is disconnected from the high profile bracket, so my lid fits on perfectly. You can detach the vga connector entirely if you have a dvi or hdmi plug, but I have vga for my monitor.

Once it was in, I just turned on my computer and ran the disc. It had one error which it then corrected on its own, and then...success! I restarted my computer and it is working beautifully. My main concern was my artwork, but it is able to run games like Diablo III and Rayman Origins as well.

Overall, it was exactly what I was looking for and I highly recommend it for anyone with a similar system.

Reviews.title: Good Card for the Money, Not for High End Gaming
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2013
Reviews.text: I bought this card as part of my upgrade process which included taking an older Dell Optiplex 745 and turning it into a home theater PC. The onboard video was adequate for Standard Def, but fell short when it came to 720p or 1080p HD content. I added an 80GB OCZ Vertex 2 Solid State Drive to hold our 64bit Windows 7 Ultimate OS and other applications like XBMC, VLC Media Player, etc. The PC's secondary (storage drive) is a Western Digital 2TB Green drive which we chose for it's lower power consumption and massive storage space. This card handles 1080p content flawlessly and is now hooked up via HDMI to our 40" LCD HDTV. The drivers that came with it aren't completely useless, but they are definitely outdated. I suggest downloading the latest drivers from the AMD website. The latest drivers and Catalyst Control Center also include AMD OverDrive, which let you overclock the cards core speed and memory speed, allowing a little bump in performance. Not for serious gaming, but will handle games that we like (such as the Sims 3) very respectably, even at 1920 x 1080, which says a lot considering I paid $34 for this card and it had a $15 mail in rebate. I recommend this card to anyone looking to boost the performance compared to the on-board video and highly recommend it for home theater PC's.

Reviews.title: Decent performance, good price, single slot, low power
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2012
Reviews.text: It won't let you play the latest hard-core games at maximum render quality, but it is an ideal addition to our 2.5-year-old media PC. Finally, the system can record TV without frustrating freezes/skips of several seconds during the first few minutes of recording! It has also smoothed out Minecraft's graphics nicely. Unlike another reviewer, I've had no trouble playing HD video files with it, even 1080p and with the display resolution - to a TV - at 1920x1080. No power cable needed, so it was easy to install (barring the insane design of the rear panel slot covers on this PC). It works fine with the 300W power supply, even with a second hard drive installed in the tower used for recording - the highest-resource activity on the system, and it gets the onboard CPU fan going hard too. The card fits very nicely into the space of a single PCI slot, which was absolutely vital since the TV tuner is adjacent to it. Someone else pointed out that the low-profile heat sink wraps around the edge of the card, which is true, but since the PCIe 16x slot is at the top in our system, there's nothing at that height on that side of it so it isn't a problem. You should check that on your configuration. You will want to get the latest drivers, but it worked in basic mode first boot simply by moving the TV's HDMI cable to the new card.

Reviews.title: Great card for a great price
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2012
Reviews.text: This card works great, allows me to watch movies in 720p and 1080p and even lets me play a lot of games. I have played GTA IV with it. It doesn't run great, but it's playable. Had I been better informed and searched harder I probably would have bought something more powerful, but that isn't to say this video card is bad in any way. I will still find a great use for it. I would definitely recommend it. However, that being said, I see a lot of people recommending this card for HTPC (home theater pc) and I disagree with this. Maybe your scenario is different, but for me.. well I have a 47" tv that supports huge resolutions, and this video card doesn't work at the high resolution. It cuts off the right side of the picture with no way to fix it. I have used nvidia cards and they allowed me to alleviate this problem. I'm not sure if it's a fault of my tv or the video card manufacturers but I can tell you that nvidia control panel has better options for fixing this than the ATI Catalyst Center. I can still run my tv at 1280x800 and play videos, but it bugs me that I can't run the tv's native resolution (I think 1920x1080). If this video card is going into a work or office computer, you will probably never need to upgrade your video card ever again. I wish that's what I bought it for in the first place. I give 5 out of 5 because of the price to quality ratio.

Appena installata questa scheda grafica con appena 2 giga dedicati il pc sembra rinato. Dopo alcuni giorni nessun segno di instabilità o problemi di altra natura. Ricordatevi solo di aggiornare i drivers.

Euro
consiglio solamente per chi non pretende troppo

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Italy on July 30, 2021
Reviews.text:
Perdonatemi le divagazioni.
Ho letto recensioni pessime a causa del prezzo troppo alto... ma se decidete di acquistare una GeForce GT 1030 (o altre GPU) e siete consapevoli di cosa comprate, perché poi lamentarsi del prezzo?
Altre recensioni la definiscono "Ridicola" paragonata a una 1080 TI. Mi chiedo: era necessario comprarla per scoprirlo? Ci sono tanti siti che fanno benchmark; il problema è che c’è ben poco da ridere se ad un computer (molto vecchio) salta la GPU e non si ha più output video (come nel mio caso). A quel punto si hanno ben poche alternative.
1. Buttare tutto? No perché il PC, anche se obsoleto, è ancora un buon "muletto":
Cooler Master HAF 922
ASUS P7P55D-E
Intel Core i7-875K 4:Cores 8:Threads
Noctua NH-U12A
DDR3 Corsair 16GB dual channel
SSD Samsung 870 QVO 1TB
Segate Barracuda 7200RPM 1TB
Alimentatore Seasonic Gserie
OS Windows 7 (off-line) in partizione dedicata
Linux per collegamento a Internet

2. Acquistare una GeForce GTX 1050-Ti 4GB GDDR5 o superiore?
Assolutamente no! Già il PC è stato aggiornato nel tempo e non avevo nessuna intenzione di spendere troppo per aggiornarlo ancora.

3. Comprare solo MOBO, CPU con grafica integrata, e RAM?
No perché avrei comunque speso "un botto" per avere una sorta di "creatura di Frankenstein".

C’era la GeForce GT 1030 (merita 5 stelle per il solo fatto che a tantissimi ha salvato il... ci siamo capiti), che a 100 euro, pur con tutti i suoi limiti, mi ha ridato un output video:
Consuma 30Wat, si alimenta direttamente dallo slot PCIe 16x, ventola silenziosissima, non si scalda neppure se la metto nel forno.
Tutte le caratteristiche (Bus Width, ROPs, TMUs, Texel Rate ecc.) li trovate qui
hwbench.com/vgas o dove volete.

Avevo già scaricato i drive "471.41-desktop" e quando è arrivata l’ho messa nello slot PCIe 16x, installati i drive e varie utiliy e devo dire credevo fosse molto peggio.

Non è sicuramente adatta per giocare, o perlomeno non di certo con titoli recenti, ma sono comunque rimasto molto soddisfatto, per ora.

Posso utilizzare ancora il "muletto" e pensare con calma quando/come assemblare un nuovo computer.

Reviews.title: read my review
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2021
Reviews.text:
so I didn't buy mine on here and could never recommend anyone to buy it for the $1200+ that it's listed on here for. I bought mine for roughly 200 bucks more then MSRP from fb marketplace in brand new condition and I am very happy with it, with that being said, that was almost half the cost it is on here for. It has functioned flawlessly and has chewed up and spit out every game I have thrown at it max settings well over 60-100+++ FPS.

In new world paired with the Ryzen 5800x on high to max settings this card has never dipped below 60 FPS on a 3440x1440p monitor and has not exceeded 90-92c on junction temperature (hot spot) that is stock, I have not touched any settings, undervolting, overclocking, fan curves...etc but I knew to expect the great quality from Sapphire that I have enjoyed for two decades now. To those paying 1000+ for a 3070 on marketplace.. don't waste your time or money, if you can snag this badboy up for 650-750 off marketplace in like new or new condition go for it.. you will not be disappointed. Superb quality!!

On a side note.. I seen someone leaving a review about this card using a 6pin and a 8pin power connector instead of two 8pins and how now he has "a lot" of work ahead of him to fix that.... dude... What the actual f are you talking about???? You rated the card 3 stars because you're sooo lazy you can't spend a literal 2 whole minutes to reroute a cable???? it sounds like you're using sleeved extension cables and are being cheap about buying another one.... they cost like 20 bucks kek..not really sure how it's a "a lot" of work at all....

so anyways enough of that rubbish, if you can snag it for under 800 bucks on marketplace or somehow get extremely lucky to buy it on here for that price I would otherwise just wait...

Reviews.title: Great graphics card.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2022
Reviews.text: Runs most “AAA “ titles in 2022 on medium to high graphics.

Reviews.title: 3 Years later....
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2020
Reviews.text:
I never wrote a review like I intended when I bought this card back in January of 2017. I figured I'd write it after I saw how it worked on my system and totally forgot about it.
Fast forward to April 2020. The card still working without a glitch. There has not been a game or graphic intensive software that it hasn't handled like a champ. I went looking to see how much I paid for it. With tax it came out to $405. Today, the card is going for over $500!!! THREE YEARS LATER!!!! I nearly spit the whiskey I was drinking that was going to convince me to buy another to do an SLI setup. So much for that idea!! LMAO!!
So, with the proper drivers, monitor and supported software, this card can do 8k resolutions. I can't attest to that, as 8k monitors are still too rich for my blood at this time. But it handles my Samsung 32" and my Asus 27" monitors at max resolutions without a glitch. I can have a game on the 32" and whatever else on the 27". Not. A. Problem.
Mind you, it's paired with a 7 year old Intel I5 3570K (overclocked) with 16 GB of RAM on a Gigabyte Z77X motherboard. The system is OOOOOLD!!! But still rocks like nobody's business!!
I have had no reason to upgrade. At All.
If you own this card, hold on to it. If you want this card, try to find a better deal than $500+.
Highly recommended though.

Reviews.title: Amesome video card.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2017
Reviews.text:
This graphics card is quite the upgrade from my 1050. Not only is my framerate very high (above 80 for most games on ultra settings,1080p) but the card runs quiet and cool. Games like PUBG, Elder Scrolls, CSGO and Crysis all run like a dream. Not much difference between this Gigabyte 170 card and the MSi card, the msi card just card looks prettier and has a backplate. No difference in performance. If you want a better looking card, go with the msi 1070, but if you're like me and don't care about looks too much, the gigabyte card is the right choice since you'll save some cash.

I will write another review once i try out my system on a 1440p, 144hz monitor since this card can run that resolution very well also. This card is a little bit overkill for the 1080p, but since i plan on upgrading to running 1440p in the near future, that's why I paid more for this card instead of a 1060. As far as 4k, this card can handle it, it's just that you'll sacrifice your framerate and get more like 26-30fps. For 4k, definitely get a 1080 and some solid cooling.

Overall this card crushes any game I throw at it. Only cons would be that it doesn't look as pretty as the other 1070's.

Update: 5/5/2018. It’s been almost a year with this card and I must say I’m impressed. No issues whatsoever yet. I also upgraded to a 1440p 144hz monitor and I can still run any modern game with 80+ fps easily. I also overclocked this card slightly using MSI Afterburner and it does get a little but hotter but nothing major. Going to get the most bang for my buck with this card until the new Volta cards come out. If you’re looking to buy a graphics card, I’d strongly recommend to wait until the new cards come out. The prices right now are crazy expensive!!!

My system specs.
Intel i7 7700k
MSI Z270 m3 mobo
Gtx 1070
Phanteks Eclipse p400 Case
2x8 Corsair Vengeance LPX 3000
Corsair CX750m Psu

Reviews.title: - Easily averaging about 15-20fps more than my old 970 across ...
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2017
Reviews.text:
I'm likely the victim of the hype train here but I will try to remain objective. Here is some basic information: Upgraded from a "Zotac GTZ 970 AMP! Omega". My overall system specs (as relevent to the GPU) are as follows: Windows 10, with a Intel I7-4790K. I play exclusively on a 1080p, 60hz monitor with a projector hooked up occasionally as a second screen. Mostly play a heavily modded Skyrim, FO4, the Total War series, and things of that nature.

Pros:

- Easily averaging about 15-20fps more than my old 970 across the board. This means a relatively stable 60fps with v-sync in most titles. Only exception being ARMA 3 where I have yet to meet a system that can average 60fps (this comes close at a usual 45-50fps).

- Very quiet, some "coil whine" but its almost negligible.

- Compared to my old 970 it is tiny. Its a little longer, but is much less thick. I do not have a motherboard that supports SLI (only Crossfire - the AMD equivalent), but if I did this card would be ideal for it due to its small size.

Cons

- Runs hot, very hot. I can feel the case getting hot when I play pretty much anything for more than a half hour. If you look into it the 1070s seem to be designed to run hot so in fairness it probably isn't an issue with the cards if they are made to handle it, but it is a little alarming. It has yet to max out the fan usage on it's own, I've had to go and manually adjust the fan speed to see if that helps. On it's own I've never seen it go past 88% fan speed.

Overall I'm giving it a 4, but I have to admit its a solid improvement and I don't regret buying it.

Visually these cards are immaculate, care was taken to make sure that these looked as good as new. Every card is up and running, and staying within expected limits. Thank you!

Reviews.title: Great price/performance
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2017
Reviews.text:
Good compromise of price to performance. Currently about $180 cheaper than the GTX1080. You do not even need this strong of a card for normal PC things or streaming. This and the GTX 1080 are all about games and video editing. I do not do video editing. But here is my short version (opinions) related to gaming. The below opinions assume your CPU is quad core i5 or i7 from the last 3 or so years. I have no experience with these cards being used with dual core or older CPU's...\

1) if you want to do 4K gaming at 144Hz - get the 1080...no get the 1080ti
2) If you are happy doing 4K at 60HZ or less, and have G-Sync on the monitor - this will work, 1080 is better (more headroom)
3) If you are using 1440p, have G-Sync on the monitor, the 1070 will do 144Hz, and over 100 without G-Sync. Smooth as butter for all but super competitive FPS competition - no real need for 1080 unless pushing 3 monitors and want ultra settings on your games
4) If all you want is 1440p, single or dual monitor and are good with 100 frames or less on ultra settings, this is fine (which will likely be everyone but the hardest core gamers)
5) For anything 1080p, and I mean pretty much anything, this card is enough - maybe overkill

Reviews.title: As expected: perfectly adequate
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2017
Reviews.text:
This is one of the cheaper GTX 1070 models available. That's not to say it's bad, but it means my expectations weren't as high for this model. The package is really basic: just the card in an anti-static bag surrounded with some closed cell foam, a "Quick Guide" and a drivers/utilities disc for those who need it. There's no molex/pcie adapter or anything of that sort.

It cools adequately: temps aren't pleasingly low or uncomfortably high. I consider the noise level par for a card like this, which I would actually consider a positive here since some budget models can be a little iffy.

GPU-Z reports that my cards have Micron memory, which I assume applies universally to this model. For those interested, I personally got fairly good overclocks (one +650 and one +775) on the memory for these, which is useful if you're using them for some workloads, primarily cryptocurrency or compute-related. Obviously your mileage on overclocks will vary.

All in all, I'm content with these for the price that they can be bought for.

Reviews.title: Value for Money!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2019
Reviews.text:
As someone that is sensitive to noise;
Can be a bit coil whiney when it's running high Rpms on the fans.
An Aftermarket air cooler/water cooling solution maybe best if you are going for a pure silent setup.

Overall the performance for price has been stellar.
Only gripe is that Gigabyte has some of the worst fans on the market I think.
My Gf's EVGA GTX 970 is quieter and runs cooler, even though the 1070 is suppose to be more efficient.
An Aftermarket air cooler/water cooling solution maybe best if you are going for a pure silent setup.

Reviews.title: You get what you pay for.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2016
Reviews.text:
So let me run some spec by ya.

Cpu- amd fx6100
Gpu- zotac 1050ti 4g
Ram- 8gig
Os- win 7

Giving it 4 star because it says 4 gig but only run at 3. Test it out on all my game and it only run at 3 gig and not 4 gig.

Okay now for the good new. This card does not need a psu 6 pin plug. This card runs off the mobo power. I've played all kinds of games on this card the past few days and here the list.

Doom high 60 fps
Dying light max 60 fps
Skyrim se max 60 fps
Shugon total war med setting with huge army 40-60 fps ( the battle were nuts)
Overwatch ultra 60 fps drop here and there.
Metal gear the phantom pain max 60 fps.
Rome 2 empire med setting large army 60 fps. Drop only when battle have more then a army on the battle field.
Gta5 max 60 fps.
Planetary annaltion med 60 fps. Keep in mind this is on 4 planet system with 4 ai.
Metro last light redux max 50 fps
Metro redux max 50 fps.

I hope that give you a Idalea what the card can do for low end pc build. It's worth your money but they should tell you it's only 3 gig. Or that 1 gig is lock. Other then that this is a good card.

does it bet the rx470? Yes it does. Why you ask? Because you can run this on a 300 watt psu. Does it kill the rx 460. Yes it murder the card. Does it beat the 950? Yes it does. By 15-20%. If your replacing a gtx650 - gtx 750ti you are going to see a huge change like night and day.

Reviews.title: Great Budget GPU
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2018
Reviews.text:
The 1050ti seems to be a great value. It has a nice sweet spot of 4GB of vram and can handle most games at high 1080p. My system is a Dell system that did not come with a graphics card. The specs are:
- Intel Core I5 4460
- 12 GB ddr3 ram
- 2TB HDD
- Approx. 350 watt PS
My main reason for going with the 1050ti was because it didn't require any external power. My PC didn't come with any GPU power cables so it was perfect. This card from Zotac is relatively short lengthwise, but still looks nice with the dual fan design. The card was very easy to install, it is basically plug and play. It came from the factory with a small overclock. Zotac's software, Firestorm, is easy to use and helps to monitor the card during gameplay. I never ran into any power issues, but I never tried to overclock because my PSU is just over the required minimum to run the card.
Games that run respectably on high settings 1080p include: Deceit, CSGO, Overwatch, Forza Motorsport 7, Gmod, Rocket League, and Fortnite
Games that run respectably on medium settings 1080p include: Hunt: Showdown (usually mid 40s-low 50s), COD Black Ops 4, The Hunter Call of the Wild (w/ some settings on high)
Basically if it's a AAA title than it will run on medium with some high settings. Competitive and party games will run very smoothly with high frame rates at 1080p high. Of course I don't have a beast rig or anything, so if you put this card in a nicer system expect to have higher frame rates overall.

Reviews.title: I love this thing!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2016
Reviews.text:
I ordered this graphics card on Nov 28 (Cyber Monday) and it arrived on Sunday (who knew deliveries happened on Sunday, eh?). I returned home from work and there it was!! I installed it immediately, downloaded the most current drivers for it which installed automatically and updated my display instantly and BAM! Works BEAUTIFULLY!! (BTW - there's an instruction page with large letters inside the package that tells you where to download your drivers... couldn't have made it easier if they had included a CD in the package. No, really - it was just that easy!)

If you know how to open your system's case and plug a card into a slot on the motherboard, you can do this - so long as your system meets the specs of the card; which most newer systems will). There is no need for an additional power source - the card is powered by the motherboard (which was a huge selling point for me since my new system didn't come with a PCIe 6-pin power adapter).

Installation and setup was a breeze and now I have a crisp, clear display where videos run smoothly without a hitch! Looking forward to seeing how games on the highest settings run with this card.

I am tickled stupid about this particular upgrade to my system. Thanks for such an awesome transaction and a fantastic product!

Reviews.title: Cured DPC watchdog violation error for ARK MMO
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2019
Reviews.text:
Hubby's GC stopped working after this last Window's update. No amount of rollback, re-install of windows and/or graphic drivers fixed the DPC watchdog violation error he was suddenly getting trying to play his MMO. Online forums nor Unreal engine tech support helped. Apparently this is a known issue since at least 2014.
We ordered this GC Saturday night and it arrived before 9 am Sunday morning. Install was fast (3 mins) and pain free. Window's picked up on it right away and the correct drivers were installed. Less than 15 mins later he was back playing his game with zero issues. His rig is older - 2012 build - which is why we got this older card hoping not to kill the motherboard with something newer. Best feature, no power on board needed to run the card. Best value to squeeze the last remaining life out of his rig before we do a complete upgrade this summer :).

Reviews.title: Card=Great. Amazon=Letdown.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2018
Reviews.text: The card is solid for the money. My only complaint is with the Amazon listing. It clearly advertises the 1050 Ti OC Edition with a heatpipe cooler. I received the same product number listed, but it does NOT have a heatpipe cooler, merely a simple aluminum heatsink. Looking at the Zotac product page for this unit, Zotac does not advertise my SKU with a heatpipe cooler. So someone at Amazon got their SKU/ad features wrong. 5 stars for Zotac, minus one star for Amazon. With limited GPU stock these days I'm going to have a hard time finding a suitable replacement at a reasonable cost.

Reviews.title: Gets The Job Done!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2018
Reviews.text: I've owned this product for nearly 3 months now and it is still as quiet as it was when I first installed it and I haven't had any issues with it so far. It runs all of my PC games with no prob (I have most of the newer releases) and my Video Editing Software runs smoother. Although I still think the price is a bit high, It is now $30.00 less than what I paid for it so I would say this item is a worthwhile investment despite the price. I am pleased with my purchase & I would recommend this product.

Reviews.title: Amazing card, high price
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2018
Reviews.text:
An absolutely amazing card! I got the 1050 ti 4GB GDDR5 OC, and it runs things no problem. I mainly play video games such as PUBG, which I can run at ultra with an almost perfect 60 FPS! However, I play PUBG on high because there isn’t a big difference from high and ultra, and I’d rather have that extra performance and efficiency.

Four stars for high price

TL;DR
Runs PUBG at high with 80+ FPS
Very efficient and fans aren’t too loud
Don’t pay over $250 for this card unless you really need it or want it

Reviews.title: Sweeeet!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2019
Reviews.text:
I built my pc back in 2013 w/ the latest i5 cpu at the time along w/ a gigabyte mid-tier gaming mobo to mainly use for programming. I wanted to try to get back into pc gaming and installed this video card.
I was iffy my pc could handle pc games made in 2018. Totally glad it worked out. Able to play WWE 2K19 and Assassin's Creed Odyssey on this, game play is smooth. It's probably set to maybe mid to high settings, but honestly it plays just like as if I'm playing my PS3, so I got no regrets buying this card.

Reviews.title: Availability
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2018
Reviews.text: Crypto currency miners are buying up all the high end GPU cards out there. I needed a middle of the road GPU for a upgrade for my 11 year old PC. He was using a GTX 730 and this was a good bit more power for him. price was right, card runs cool and very quiet. Have not OC it yet, he mostly plays Minecraft so no need to really to OC. Also this card does not require any PSU power cords. Its powered via the PCI slot. That was a pluse because the PC has a modular PSU and I would have needed to buy more cables adding to the cost.

Reviews.title: Solid card that delivers
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2018
Reviews.text: I've had this card for some months now and it hasn't let me down. Windows 10 didn't want to let me overclock it manually any further and would complain that the card is unknown when I tried to run a game while overclocked, thus resorting to software rendering or worse, not running at all. I don't blame this card, though. Even without the extra overclocking, beyond factory, it holds it's own. I mostly play older titles, an MMO and Subnautica and it does the trick perfectly. Highly recommended if you can't get an affordable Radeon R570/580, which is very likely due to crypto-currency miners.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Spain on March 23, 2019
Reviews.text:
Temperaturas y nivel de ruido:
Poco ruido y temperaturas bastante bajas, puedes controlar la relación ruido-temperatura desde el software de Gigabyte al igual que con las demás gráficas de Gigabyte. Más ruido = mejores temperaturas. En general, con los valores por defecto, la gráfica no se calienta demasiado, aunque siempre configuro que vayan al 100% cuando sube de 60° y el ruido ahí se nota, obviamente.
A temperaturas bajas los ventiladores se paran, como las demás gráficas de Gigabyte, es un punto muy a favor aunque muchas gráficas lo hacen.

Potencia:
Por comparar diré que tiene la misma potencia o incluso más que la 1060 de Nvidia sin utilizar juegos con api vulkan, con juegos con vulkan la Rx580 le da un buen repaso a la 1060. Consume un poco más que la 1060 pero nada alarmante, son consumos normales.

Software y drivers:
Una auténtica cagada, lo mejor habría sido que no llevase el CD porqué los drivers que vienen ahí no funcionan bien y eso si te deja llegar a instalarlos. Me los bajé de la web y ahí todo perfecto y a la primera, lo iba a hacer de todos modos, pero de primeras lo monté en un sitio sin acceso a Internet. Así que en este punto, respecto a los drivers del CD muy muy mal.

Precio:
La he comprado por 200e es un choyo sinceramente, más teniendo en cuenta que a día de hoy hay una promoción en la que te regalan dos juegos AAA recién salidos a la venta que valen 60e cada uno.

En resumen, podrás jugar a cualquier juego a 1080p 60fps con todo en ultra por 200e (siempre que no haya cuello de botella en otro componente) , se mire por donde se mire es una ganga. Y no hagáis caso a algunos de los comentarios que he leído de este producto, hay gente que comenta sin tener ni idea.
Todas las anteriores gráficas que compré han sido de Nvidia, en mi pc de jugar habitualmente tengo una gtx1070, lo comento para que no creáis que soy un fanboy de amd. La Rx580 es una muy buena gráfica por el precio que tiene.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Spain on August 17, 2019
Reviews.text:
Le he puesto cinco estrellas y, sin embargo, estoy algo apenado con la compra. Lo explico, la tarjeta es muy buena y potente y por eso se merece las cinco estrellas, no obstante, cuando la vi por primera vez estaba en unos 174€ pero Amazon empezó a escalarle el precio inmediatamente hasta los 267€ que me costó a mi o los 287€ creo que vale ahora. Yo la compré para un centro de estudios donde se imparten clases avanzadas de programas de diseño asistido por computador, con lo cual la intención era comprar un número considerable de unidades para renovar gran parte de los equipos pero debido a este incremento de más de 100€ he tenido que considerar otras opciones y aunque sigo necesitando más unidades si Amazon sigue con este precio, simplemente no podré adquirirlas aquí muy a mi pesar.
En lo que respecta a la gráfica va estupendamente incluso en operaciones de texturizado, simulación dinámica o renderizados exigentes. Respecto a juegos no la he probado pero estoy seguro que los mueve sin problemas.
En definitiva, mi primer gran decepción con Amazon porque si quiero comprar aquí 10 ó 12 tarjetas me supone un desembolso de unos 1200€ más que respecto al precio original. En resumen, si no os importa pagar 287€ por esta tarjeta, es una gran compra en lo que a resultados se refiere. Decir también que en lo relativo a embalaje, rapidez, etc, Amazon impecable como siempre.

Actualizo:
Después de unos pocos meses de uso en diseño CAD, de repente ha dejado de responder. He contactado con Amazon y amable y ágilmente me han reembolsado el importe.
Tengo también otras tres tarjetas similares de Gigabyte, una RX570 y dos RX590. Estas últimas son las que estoy probando más a fondo a ver si fallan también, en cuyo caso pensaré que es un fallo generalizado de Gigabyte. Si siguen bien, es para pensar que ha sido un fallo puntual de la RX580.
Pasado un tiempo más comentaré cómo va.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Spain on April 21, 2019
Reviews.text:
Me ha llegado hoy y no he tenido mucho tiempo para probarla, pero lo poco que la he probado me ha encantado. Vengo de 2 RX 580 anteriores, una Sapphire de 4GB y una MSI Armor de 8GB.

La Sapphire, a pesar de que tiene muy buena fama, fue una completa basura. Coil Whine brutal, mal rendimiento, temperaturas muy altas...

Luego pase a la MSI. Esta funcionaba bien, pero tenia varios problemas. El primero es que no tiene backplate, esta todo al aire, los ventiladores esta atornillados a la placa sin ningun tipo de "proteccion". Esto provoca que de su propio peso se doble un monton, provocando daños en la ranura pci de la placa base y en la propia tarjeta de video. El segundo problema era que era tremendamente ruidosa. Pusieras el juego que pusieras, los ventiladores al mas minimo movimiento ya hacian ruido. Como te pusieras a jugar a algo mas o menos exigente, parecia que tu pc iba a despegar.

Finalmente, he comprado la Gigabyte (ya tuve una 1050ti de 4GB de esta emsambladora y fue genial, parece que esta va por el mismo camino).

Es bastante mas corta que la Sapphire y la MSI (algo que la gente con torres poco espaciosas agraceran), es MUCHO mas silenciosa (he estado jugando en silencio a juegos que con la MSI era un avion a reaccion), no se dobla, tiene luces RGB (que es una chorrada, pero se agradece) y cuenta con un led que te indica si le falta energia para funcionar.

Si no le pongo 5 estrellas es porque solo trae un hdmi (que si, que se puede comprar un adaptador dvi o displayport, pero la msi por ejemplo si traia 2 hdmi) y porque el precio sigue estando muy alto. Actualizare si tengo algun problema con la tarjeta, pero de momento, como he dicho, todo muy bien. Estoy muy contento, Gigabyte es una muy buena ensambladora.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on August 15, 2020
Reviews.text:
Erstmal zur Grafikkarte kann man für knapp 200€ kaum was Besseres bekommen. Leise brauche ich hier wohl nicht erwöhnen da im Ide die Lüfter aus sind und bei niedriger Drehzahl auch kaum hörbar sind. Die Leistung reicht für mich locker aus, die Karte bringt fast überall 60 fps auf mittleren oder bei etwas älteren Spielen sogar hohen Grafikeinstellungen. Bezüglich der LED-Beleuchtung kann ich nichts sagen denn ich habe ein Modell bekommen welches weder Logo mit Hintergrundbeleuchtung, noch die metallene Backplate besitzt. Und da gehen wir dann auch schon zu meiner Kritik am Support über.
Ich habe dem Support freundlich mein Problem geschildert, dass ich ein Modell bekommen habe ohne metallener Rückenplatte und LED-Logo (auch bekannt als Rev. 2) und dass ich ein Modell mit eben diesen Merkmalen erwartet habe weil es so auf den Produktbildern angegeben wurde. Chat verlief problemlos, man bot mir schnell an, die Karte umzutauschen. Soweit so gut, nur dass eben diese Karte genau die selbe Karte ohne LED-Logo und Backplate ist. Naja, die Leistung bleibt die selbe, ist nur die Optik, daher gebe ich mich dann wohl zufrieden mit der Karte, bevor ich wieder 4 Tage auf die gleiche Karte warte.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Spain on December 23, 2018
Reviews.text: Buena gráfica para lo que me costo(encima viene con dos juegos de regalo),mueve los juegos actuales a 1080p con todo en ultra a 60 FPS sin despeinarse,la he probado con juegos como el ultimo Tomb Raider y con juegos como como Gears of War 4 y otra serie de juegos,UN DETALLE IMPORTANTE: no valláis a instalar el software Aurus engine desde la pagina de Gigabyte por culpa de este software estuve apunto de devolver la la gráfica,este software tiene un bug que hace que los juegos no pasen de 15 FPS,según todos los test que se le pueden hacer a la gráfica funciona bien pero con el aurus engine instalado dan una puntuación muy baja,cuando estaba a punto devolverla ley a un usuaria que comentaba lo del programa y lo probe y resulta que ese era el fallo.Por ultimo decir que para que me enviaran el código de los juegos tuve que llamar a atención del cliente de amazon porque no recibía el coreo con el código.

Reviews.title: HD5770s and 6770s never came with 4GB of VRAM! AVOID!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2022
Reviews.text:
The vast majority of HD6770s did not come with a VGA port. The real ones also require a 6-pin power connector. Most cards that have an output layout like this are fake and, seeing reviews from people saying it won't run DX11, I'm inclined to believe this isn't even a 6770 as those did run DX11. The listed clock speed is about 200mhz lower than the original cards which, at best, points to these being faulty cards flashed with a different BIOS to operate at a lower clock speed. HD 5770s and 6770s (same card with 2 names) also NEVER came with 4GB of VRAM.

Again, this points to this being a card with a fake BIOS. I've tested another faked GPU claiming to be a GTX 960 4GB and the card even reported itself as such to the computer. In actuality it was a GT640 with 1GB of VRAM. When a game would try to utilize the reported 4GB of VRAM that didn't exist, it would cause the computer to crash.

Best case scenario here, you get a GPU that was originally released in 2009 (as the 5770, again, identical to the 6770...AMD just renamed the same card 2 years later) which has not received driver support since 2015, running at 76% of it's original speed (which may be how it gets away without a 6 pin power connector...but I doubt it) and have to spend some time dialing in settings to avoid games using more than 1GB of VRAM so the computer won't crash. In other words KEEP SHOPPING!

Old man Dad on a budget here. Purchased this to upgrade from onboard graphics when stadia was announced that they were cancelling.

Slapped it in, loaded up Elder Scrolls Online and can say I'm pleased with the card. I run it on the high setting no problem. It can handle ultra but the framerate drops below my comfort but it can run it.

Reviews.title: I NEEDED A CARD TO CRUISE AROUND THE INTERNET WITHOUT ISSUE AND THIS IS IT!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2022
Reviews.text:
I just needed a basic video card to cruise around the internet without being stifled by lame performance of a cheap video card. While this card is a tad expensive it is not priced at the ridiculously insane prices of the middle to high end gaming video cards in 2022. This GPU has done the job of letting me go anywhere on the internet without video lag.

I had a more expensive NVIDIA GPU in my system with otherwise state of the art hardware. The newest most power Ryzen 9 \ 5900 CPU, fast memory and a 750 watt power supply. The NVIDIA GPU ran like hot garbage on my Ubuntu system. Ubuntu has a nasty sepia color scheme that saturates the entire OS and everything in it. It is not only ugly but painful to look at due to my vision issues.

I did not know for sure at the time but, I hoped a new video card from someone other than NVIDIA might perform better. Turns out this AMD designed GPU got rid of the nasty sepia tint. This video card creates a simple un-tinted OS that is a pleasure to use. The card is not BIG and uses only the power supplied by the GPU slot.

The card has some energy saver garbage installed that turns the card off if you power down your monitor. I took a star off for the energy saver mess. There really are no other issues. This is a great card to use on a Linux\Ubuntu system that is not used for hard core gaming.

Reviews.title: It does what I needed it to do
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2022
Reviews.text:
At my workplace I needed this half-height graphics card for a PC running a graphics intensive application that was practically unusable using the on-board graphics on the PC. Installing this card resolved the performance issues. I was pleased enough with that purchase that I bought one for my home computer to resolve some lag issues when playing 4K video on my old PC. This card resolved that issue, too. I don't know how this product benchmarks against the completion. I didn't do any testing like that. I simply had performance issues with applications that needed a graphics card performance boost. The price was right on this graphics card and I found that it worked fine to resolve those issues.

The only issue that I had was that the package came with no English instructions, no drivers and no software. I am an IT technician by trade, so I had little trouble finding the right drivers and software online. On one PC, Windows Update found the drivers, but I still had to download and install the correct version of the Radeon software. On the other PC I had to download both the drivers and software. So, this wasn't much of a problem for me, but it may be more than a novice PC users can deal with.

This product did what I needed and I've had no problems with it either at home or at work. It gets a 5 star rating from me even though I would have expected better instructions for installing the product and obtaining the correct drivers & software.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on August 29, 2022
Reviews.text:
Diese Grafikkarte ist absolout NICHT VR fähig ! Wer VR möchte MUSS mehr investieren !

Dennoch möchte ich diese Grafikkarte einmal für ihre erstaunliche und herausragende Leistung loben.
Hier hat MAXSUN alles richtig gemacht!

Ich habe einen Rechner mit ordentlich Leistung und natürlich auch mit einer entsprechenden Grafikkarte um damit die Valve Index VR-Brille zu betreiben. Ich bekam ein ausrangiertes Fujitsu Esprimo C710 mit USB3.0 und einem betagten aber ausreichenden Prozessor und suchte nun nach einer Low Profile Grafikkarte, die dabei auch noch schlank und bestmögliche Leistung bringen sollte.

Mein verrückter Plan:
Wenn an meinem Rechner was abraucht, sollte der kleine Esprimo das Ganze überbrücken.
Mit 32GB RAM und der MAXSUN Radeon RX 550 ist mir das sehr gut gelungen.
Wir reden hier natürlich von minimalistischen Grafikeinstellungen ABER BeatSaber, Phasmophobia (SinglePlayer), Pistol Whip und Blade & Sorcery sind durchaus spielbar und die Karte wird dabei nicht übermäßig heiß. Half Life - Alyx hingegen lagt sehr deutlich (wie es auch zu erwarten ist)

Dies ist keine Kaufempfehlung für VR, es soll aber verdeutlichen, was die kleine Karte auf dem Kasten hat.
Denn hier schlägt sie die vergleichbare GT 1030 um längen. Für Titel wie Diablo III und Co ifinde ich die RX 550 völlig in Ordnung und sie macht dort auch eine echt gute Figur.

Fazit: Es gibt natürlich deutlich stärkere Grafikkarten, egal ob AMD oder NVIDIA aber wer bei dem aktuellen Auf und Ab der Grafikkartenpreise eine günstige und verhältnismäßig starke Grafikkarte sucht, weil er sich gerade keine große leisten kann oder wie bei mir für einen kleineren Zweitrechner, sollte hier gut bedient sein.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on September 7, 2022
Reviews.text:
Hab wirklich lange und intensiv nach einer neuen, bezahlbaren und vom Preis nicht so abgehobenen Grafikkarte gesucht. Hier passt das Preis/Leistungsverhältnis für mich gerade noch so. Wir zocken wenig wenn dann Strategiespiele, Autorennen usw eine unserer Anforderungen war die Grafik entscheidend zu verbessern ohne Unmengen Geld zu investieren. Also neuer Monitor, Grafikkarte und ein zusätzlicher Speicherblock. Das Ergebnis kann sich mehr als sehen lassen!!!
Kein geruckel mehr und eine schön saubere Grafik, das beste die Grafikkarte wird bei uns nicht mal warm, läuft also alles sauber. Für 160€ kann man bei der Karte nichts verkehrt machen!

Reviews.title: A solution to a problem.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2022
Reviews.text:
A family member had their monitor burn out and a 4K monitor was bought. Sadly, the built-in video card in the older computer was not strong enough to support the max resolution.

This video card did exactly that. And it is fine for a computer that is used for surfing, basic desktop work, etc. But once you want to watch a full-screen 4K video it struggles. Badly.
To be fair here, the 10-series were not built for 4K. But it needs to be said: it is one thing to do static work on 4K resolutions; once you go to a high-quality media display this is not the card you are looking for.

So this card does what it needs to do - and it will perform fine for most things in resolutions under 4k. It is affordable and available. But don't buy this one for high-quality gaming or intensive video or animation work.

Reviews.title: Nice upgrade
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2019
Reviews.text:
The HD6870 graphics card on my desktop was starting to show it's limitations as it doesn't process 4K video well, so I decided to upgrade to this card. I switched to Nvidia as I wanted to use some software that needed CUDA. I don't game much, so this card will be more than enough for my needs and should last a while.

The packaging was fantastic and the card was well-protected. Installation was easy and didn't have any hiccups. I realized as I was hooking up my monitors that it didn't have dual DP connections like I thought, but it's fine as I just used a DP cable and one of my old DVI cables I'd used with my previous graphics card. The card is nice and quiet during day-to-day operation as the fans don't turn on when they're not needed.

Reviews.title: Great price, great value
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 28, 2019
Reviews.text:
I haven't bought any PC components in more years than I care to admit, but after having a top end gaming laptop for several years and it no longer being able to run most newer games on potato settings, I decided to get a proper desktop. I originally planned to purchase the previous generation of this card (the 1060, I believe?) but by the time I got enough money it was more expensive than this one.

I can now run every game on the highest possible settings and let me tell you: It is WONDERFUL! I haven't tried to run any sort of VR or ultra high-def stuff with this (unsure if it's compatible or not), but it's a great card for the price. Also, the lack of noise is great. I don't think I've ever heard it, even during highly intense graphics operations.

Reviews.title: Good price to performance gaming card.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2019
Reviews.text:
I needed a graphics card that didn't break the bank for my SFF bedroom gaming system. This card seemed to fit the bill in price to performance. I play a lot of Warcraft and it looks beautiful. Running at level 7 getting 100+ fps, and even at level 10 getting 60-75 fps almost as good as the RTX 2060 I have in the living room system. So if you don't care about ray tracing, this is the better bang for the buck for sure and over time with drive updates will be the new tech over a pascal card like the GTX 1060.

Now if Amazon and EVGA could get the promotional free game code correct, i'd be even more happy.

Reviews.title: for budget gaming, this is the card you want
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2019
Reviews.text: i've been a Big Red loyalist for years, but when Wolfenstein II and Nioh came out and i needed to upgrade my video ram to play them, this was the card that was most highly recommended to me, and it was absolutely worth the price of purchase. if you're in a situation like i was (needing an upgrade for a budget gaming pc, but unwilling to go above $300, because why not buy a Switch at that point?), then this is absolutely the card for you. just do yourself a favor and figure out if it'll fit in your case without completely rearranging the contents, unlike what i did.

This was only Fortnite though I haven’t tried other games. I also have a ASUS ROG Swift PG258Q 24.5” Full HD 1080p 1ms 240Hz DP HDMI Eye Care G-SYNC eSports Gaming Monitor and with this card hooked up, I was blown away! It feels good smothering people on Fortnite lol. I would buy again! I’m new on pc gaming world, I switched from console to pc and noticed a big difference. So far I feel like a Fortnite God playing against my console friends in creative mode lol

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2019
Reviews.text: Ordered this card to replace an 8 yr old EVGA GTX 550 TI. Physical installation was straightforward with an extension 6 pin to 8pin PCI-E power cord. I had downloaded new drivers from EVGA. Driver installation was also good with the exception of GeForce Experience which no longer worked. Had to download the latest version from NVidia but ran fine after the reinstall. Also downloaded the new EVGA X1 program that's still in Beta. Haven't game tested yet but did a couple Benchmarks which showed significant improvements compared to the old card. So far so good. Probably should have deleted the old drivers and done a clean new install but wasn't a big issue.

Reviews.title: Great price to performance ratio.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2019
Reviews.text: Great price to performance ratio. Fits in a small itx build, runs with a 450w power supply. I can triple screen gta with mods and mid settings at 1080p around 55fps with a i5 7600k and no over clock. Same for sim racing with settings maxed out. Single monitor runs most games on high setting around 70fps.

Reviews.title: Flawless card for its price.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2019
Reviews.text: Upgrading from a GTX 960, the GTX 1660 is a great upgrade with more than twice the performance of it's predecessor from two generations ago. Improved speeds, great thermals, and an excellent cooler that keeps the GPU at a great temperture when idling and when in game. There are limit output ports on the back, three being a DVI, DisplayPort, and HDMI 2.0. The GTX 1660 also supports adaptive sync, so FreeSync monitors can take advantage of G-SYNC technology depending on how compatible it is certain monitors. Thankfully, I own a Acer XFA240 which is one of the G-SYNC compatible monitors that works flawlessly with G-SYNC.

Reviews.title: Amazing Budget Card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2019
Reviews.text: Upgraded to this card from an EVGA GeForce GTX 1050ti FTW recently and it has been one of the most unregrettable purchases I've made in a long time. Back when I purchased my 1050ti I bought it for around $200 and this card outperforms my old 1050ti by two fold on higher game settings. If I were to run my games on the 1660 like I would on my 1050, the games would perform better than two fold. Definitely worth the buy as this card is by far the best budget card I've seen in years.

Reviews.title: Speed and Performance

You simply can’t go wrong with these graphics cards for playing Battlefield or any other highly intensive graphics, these cards do perform well.

Reviews.title: Ultimate performance and improvement in my computer speed
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2005
Reviews.text:
I ordered this product because I did nto want to upgrade my desktop with all new mobo and stuff. Bought a 200GB HD during Thanksgiving for only 40 bucks and was not able to be detected by my Win ME/Trigent Cognac mobo (HP XG838 machine. ) Added this card and now motherboard recognizes the HD with proper size.

When I got this card its firmware was already latest. Installed WinXP Pro and now my 800MHz celeron/256MB Machine boots in less than 1 minute. It was a good buy for just 30 dolllars and also got my points with Amzon visa card. I certainly recommend this product who are still using old machines and want to put high capacity drives.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2005
Reviews.text: The description for this item (as of 7/21/05) is incorrect, according to Promise Technology's web site (which I really should have checked before I ordered this card and tried to install it), this card only functions as a PCI to ATA 2 channel controller, it has no RAID functionality whatsoever. The descrptions of RAID functions seem to be describing the Promise Technology Fasttrack 100TX2 card. I've notified Amazon about this error, and if they change the description thus saving others from the aggrivation I had, then kindly ignore this review.

Reviews.title: Excellent Product
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2010
Reviews.text: While not a RAID controller and not designed for SATA or Optical drives, this controller is ideal for adding hard drives of any size to any system. (especially adding drives larger than 120gb to pre-XP systems) I own four for different systems and they've always been the highest quality. For what it's designed for, it's ideal.

Reviews.title: One Star
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2015
Reviews.text: This product is only compatible with outdated operating systems.

Reviews.title: Doesn't deliver
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2004
Reviews.text: Word of warning: If you're using any SATA HDs or trying to hook up a DVD-RW, don't get this card. I was trying to simultaneously install a new IDE 80GB HD and a DVD-RW, and had to get this card because I already had 2 CD drives and a Zip drive taking up all the IDE channels on my motherboard, plus my primary drive was a SATA Raid. The card will install flawlessly on an XP machine, but XP will hang on bootup when attaching a DVD-RW. I tried multiple configurations with this card and ultimately could not get my setup to work. I was also trying to install the 80 GB HD on the card, and if you have SATA HD (like I do), then you have to do some serious motherboard BIOS tweaking before the PC will even boot up. It keeps trying to boot straight to the empty drive. Nothing that I tried attaching to this card would work. I'm planning to return it and go with an ATA 133 card with XP specific drivers.

Reviews.title: Outstanding when used for intended purpose
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2006
Reviews.text: This product is outstanding when used properly. It's not a "Raid" card, so don't fault it for that. And it's not a SATA controller, so don't slam it for not being what it isn't. The card is a "PCI IDE Controller" card. It is intended to boost the IDE PATA controller transfer rates of older systems from 33mbs to 100mbs, thus allowing the full use of newer ATA-100mbs hard drives in older slower computers. For that intended use, it works superbly. (It also increases the performance of ATA-66 hard drives in ATA-33 computers.) I did not buy the one product listed here for sale "used" because the shipping costs made the price non-competitive, but the product itself is great. It made a new hard drive in my old P-II 233 computer blazing fast compared to the original ATA-33 hard drive.

JUNK! Stay away!!

Reviews.title: Item not as advertised
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 15, 2015
Reviews.text: I bought this item used, for only $37, so I don't have much room to complain. My issues are that this came with a dual-VGA cable instead of the dual-DVI-I cable, which is shown in the picture; and the driver CD included was home-made, not the "official" disk that would have come with the graphics board when new. It also did not come with the DVI/VGA adapters or the long bracket shown in the item's picture n Amazon. Because I need DVI-I, I now have to go to the Web and try to find the right kind of dual-monitor cable to do my work, which will reduce the amount of savings I had from buying the used item. As far as the home-made driver CD, it worked fine, but due to my own security standards, before using it, I had to do a virus/malware scan on it, and then I downloaded the software from the VisionTek web site to make sure that what was on the CD matched. All in all, about three hours of extra work. But the item worked just fine with the single VGA monitor that I have, and will hopefully work once I manage to find a dual-DVI-I cable somewhere. Not the easiest item to find. So, item shipped wasn't the identical item shown on Amazon. But I made it work, for now. Will be returning it if I can't find the dual-DVI cable.

data.description: The EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 graphics card is loaded with innovative new gaming technologies, making it the perfect choice for the latest high definition games. Powered by NVIDIA Pascal - the most advanced GPU architecture ever created - the GeForce GTX 1060 delivers brilliant performance that opens the door to virtual reality and beyond. These cards also feature EVGA ACX 3.0 cooling technology. EVGA ACX 3.0 once again brings new and exciting features to the award winning EVGA ACX cooling technology.
