Reviews.title: This card exceeded my expectations
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2019
Reviews.text: This quiet little monster performs much better than I expected. It plays all of my AAA games on Ultra and it doesn't sound like a leaf blower. I do not overclock anything. Not the processor, not the graphics, in order to preserve the lifespan of the technology. Out of box, this card performs like a rock star. You can't really go wrong. It uses one 8 pin power connector. I have a 850 PSU which is way above the requirements, but then, I always go above PSU requirements by no less than 300w extra on purpose. Why? Because if I want to upgrade or add things like pumps for water cooling, I have that option. I'm all about options. Buying the 1060 was one of the best things I've done for my system.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2020

But wow this thing really held me off. I thought I would have to settle for less, but this card was surprisingly powerful. Considering its price, it's a steal.

It is now 3 years later, and I've been trying to upgrade for the past 2 years to no avail. Especially right now; it's impossible to get an RTX.

Reviews.title: Team green FTW
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2017
Reviews.text:
Excellent gaming and VR card. I've always been a big fan of Nvidia, but I did switch to "team red" years ago. I needed an inexpensive card and went with an AMD Radeon HD 7550, which was ok many years ago. Then I switched up to a GTX 750ti I bought on sale, but it really couldn't keep up with modern games.

I defected back to red with an ASUS ROG RX 570 recently and it just won't work at all, even with an ASUS ROG B350-F motherboard. Drivers wouldn't load and it just acted strange. Maybe I got a faulty card, but it seems ever since AMD switched to the Catalyst and newer Radeon driver platform, things have gone downhill.

I'm back with the green team for good. Nvidia just works. No hassles with drivers or compatibility. So far this card rocks; consistent 58 FPS with Superposition Benchmark at 1080p and that's all I could ask for. I'm not a 4K gamer (yet) so I know this card will handle my needs until the next Nvidia chipset comes out.

data.description: NVIDIA's flagship GeForce GTX 1080 is the most advanced gaming GPU ever created, powered by the new NVIDIA Pascal architecture. The GeForce GTX 1080 comes with ultra-fast FinFET and high-bandwidth GDDR5X technologies, plus support for DirectX 12 features to deliver the fastest, smoothest, most power-efficient gaming experiences. Reviews.title: Fast in DX11, very disappointing in DX12...where it really counts
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2016
Reviews.text:
I was lucky enough to get my hands on a reviewers sample of this card through a friend of mine that has "connections." I was fortunate enough to be able to install it and benchmark the card on both a Z170 i7-6700K system and my personal X99 i7-5930K system, and was able to benchmark/or test every DX12 game currently on the market such as Hitman, Ashes of the Singularity, Quantum Break, and Rise of the Tomb Raider. For me, DX12 performance is the MOST important area of focus, especially for Nvidia since AMD has and continues to dominate its Nvidia counterparts at every price tier in DX12...in fact, Nvidia cards have actually displayed performance loss in switching from DX11 to DX12, and with the controversy surrounding Nvidia's Maxwell architecture (900 Series cards) and their complete inability to perform asyncronous switching at the hardware level, DX12, in my opinion, is where the GTX 1080 had to prove itself. The majority of new AAA PC game releases will quickly become DX12, especially since Xbox One has already fully implemented it, and because DX12 is such a superior API and places in the hands of the game developers the responsibility of ensuring games perform up to par on a piece of hardware, the performance of a given game on a given GPU isn't dependent on the GPU manufacture's ability to create perfect drivers anymore. What this means is that Nvidia's advantage in DX11 performance, largely because of their ability and budget for creating drivers, is no more, and AMD's former disadvantage will disappear as well. Now, the onus is on the GPU hardware to perform and not the programming. DX12 performance becomes even more important when you consider the rather expensive price on this card and that it factors into the desire to get as much use out of it as one can for as long as one can, preferably at least two years, so while DX12 might not be the sole API currently, sooner than later it will, and the GTX 1080's performance in DX12 will determine its life expectancy.

Unfortunately, I have to report that the GTX 1080's performance in DX12 is, for lack of a better word, embarrassing, especially at 4K where one would expect this card to be able to perform and maintain at the least 60fps @ 3840x2160 resolution. Not only does it not achieve the necesssary 60fps, but the performance gains that the GTX 1080 obtains in the switch from DX11 to DX12 hovers around an average of a few percentage points, literally (the biggest improvement being about 3% now that I recall). What's even more disappointing is that the GTX 1080 only manages a few FPS more than the AMD Fury X in DX12 @ 4K. In fact, in Ashes of the Singularity, the GTX 1080 only manages 53.3FPS while the Fury X achieves an extremely close 49.0FPS. Again, in Hitman, the GTX 1080 achieves 47.0FPS and the Fury X 44.2FPS! To me at least, this is unacceptable on nvidia's part, especially considering that the GTX has an inherent advantage over the Fury X in that the former is produced on the 16nm node, while the latter is on the now relatively old 28nm process. Additionally, Nvidia had plenty of forwarning about DX12 and AMD's considerable advantage as a result of the hardware's ability to do asynchronous compute, so it's not as if Nvidia was caught off guard or blindsided; they've known for plenty of time that it is a big deal. I've attached a chart with a few examples of the GTX 1080's DX12 performance, and while some of you may look at the results from Rise of the Tomb Raider and say, "Hey, the GTX 1080 did a lot better than the Fury X in that game"...well, while it may be true on the surface that the GTX 1080 did considerably better in RotTR, an important consideration has to be pointed out in that at the last minute, prior to that game's release, Nvidia had the developers remove the use of Asynchronous compute, which while making the GTX 1080 appear better, is a serious disservice to the players of the game who happen to own hardware capable of producing major performance boosts from Async compute. In order to not appeaer like such a failure in DX12, Nvidia was willing to ruin the experiences of a large swath of players to achieve such misleading results. So even though it may appear like a redeeming result for nvida, in reality the RotTR numbers only further highlight Pascal's lack of async compute, for if the geme developers left the feature in like the originally intended, the GTX 1080's results would be much in the vein of the other DX12 games.

To conclude, I do not see the GTX 1080 to be the "savior from heaven" that so many reviewers and fanboys hyped it up to be. Sure, the DX11 performance can result in advantages of up to 20FPS fpr the GTX 1080 over the Titan X, but considering DX11 is on it's way out and more and more titles in the past few months as well as in the months to come will be DX12, I feel as though the DX11 performance is not enough on it's own to warrant upgrading for current owners of a Maxwell/900 series GPU and especially owners of a 980Ti or Titan X. I think I can speak for many of us when I say that the community expected this card, especially considering the node shrink and new architecture, should be capable of a minimum of 60fps @ 4K and especially in DX12, but it just doesn't deliver. The problem is only excacerbated by the fact that since DX12 is "closer to the metal" than previous APIs and doesnt depend on driver support nearly as much, if the GTX 1080 isn't performing in DX12 now, it's not going to magically achieve a market leap in performance later though software wizardry as was capable with DX11. My advice is to avoid upgrading right now, unless youre coming from the 700 series or less, as the GTX 1080 just does not deliver what its price and technology would suggest. Personally, I'm waiting for AMD's Vega Architecture (the successor to Fiji/Fury X) as it will have HBM2 and will most certainly impress with its DX12 performance as all AMD cards have done so far.

**I'd just like to iterate the fact that I am NOT an AMD fanboy, I have no alliegence to any brand, and only judge a given product on it's own merits, aka its price:performance ratio. My critical review of the GTX 1080 is solely motivated by my belief in the fact that DX12 performance is a factor of tantamount importance to any other, and the GTX 1080 just does not deliver in this respect.

Reviews.title: From a 745 to a 1080 its an amazing GPU. 5 stars!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2016
Reviews.text:
From a 745 to a 1080 its amazing GPU. 5 stars!

I have the HP ENVY Phoenix 810-430qe with 32 GB ram and a i7-4790 Intel core processor. No custom rig but I got it
for a decent price. Long story short it came factory installed with a Nividia Geforce GTX 745.

I'm a hardcore gamer, do video editing and render a lot of images and with a GTX 745 it just was not durable anymore so I decided to
do a major upgrade. Now let me say for those who do not have a custom rig it is very possible to install
an EVGA Geforce GTX 1080 into an HP ENVY Desktop if your tower has the right measurements. The GTX 1080 is about 10.5 inches in
length and fit perfectly with room to spare.

The reason I chose to get the Founders Edition instead of the
custom GTX 1080s coming out is because of the cooler design for airflow. The GTX 1080 Founders Edition ejects heat from the rear
of the tower instead of storing it within the tower which is a very big deal especially if you have a smaller tower like I do.

If you can afford the extra $100 bucks do not hesitate. Its very fast as in it renders images and plays any game easily without any struggle
depending on your game settings.

I've tested some benchmarks myself with everything turned up on ultra settings and it handles 4K very well with overclocking of course.
Only games tested so far is Doom( 55 fps), Grand Theft Auto V( 59 fps), and The Witcher 3 (44 fps) very impressive on a single gpu.
To add, it handles anything below 4k with no overclocking no problem at all every game 60fps and up.

Overall a great card I love it does exactly what I want and more.
Managed to preorder from Amazon at the $699 price (of course) and shipping was surprisingly fast.

Pros:
-Great for rendering, video editing and 3D software
-Amazing cooler design
-Very easy to install
-Sleek design

Cons:
-None coming from a GTX 745

Reviews.title: GTX 1080 vs GTX 770 SC
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2016
Reviews.text:
I was able to order this card from Amazon Prime when it was available, and so paid MSRP. It replaces a GTX 770 SC, and I use it to play games like Skyrim and Fallout 4.
PROS:
-It's smaller and uses less power only one 8 pin cable from my power supply
Because of this I was able to remove one cable - nice!
- It is a little smaller than my GTX 770 - nice because it was a real trick getting the old card out/in
- It has a backplate, so you don't have to be paranoid about touching the component board when installing
- The memory speed is much greater, which for me results in less memory usage while playing a heavily modded Skyrim
Because of this, I see fewer instances of frame drops while running through texture rich areas
- This GPU is not working as hard while playing, GPU frequency is lower during similar events as compared to the GTX 770
Because of this my average operating temp decreased by 9-10c
- Newer games will probably utilize the 8GB VRAM more, my modded Skyrim doesn't use more than about 1.4GB
- Nice looking card

CONS (For me):
- Pricey although probably future proof
- After comparing to my 770, I doubt that a person upgrading from a 980 Ti would be that impressed - especially compared to a 980 Ti SC with a backplate

Overall - Glad I bought it, it works well and the installation was a breeze. It was also a great excuse to vacuum out the interior of my computer

Reviews.title: Pascalardo
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2016
Reviews.text:
The ultimate "Pascalardo" until the Titan is released. Please ignore the negative reviews about the price. I have no idea why people are leaving bad reviews on the item and not the price gouging sellers like they are supposed to. Yes you should wait till you can buy it at the $649~699 MSRP range from the normal retail stores. Take it from someone who owns one. It's fast and an amazing card.

This card run's fairly hot at stock fan speeds under load (80c range) that can be remedied by increasing the fan to 50~75% fan's in the 70's range bring it to a more healthy 60-75c under load even when OC'd to 2 Ghz.

Performance wise it handles very well usually about 65-74 FPS in Witcher 3 (maxed,) 100's range in Overwatch (maxed,) all within 2560 x 1440.

DSR Performance so far I have only tested on a few games. Witcher 3 5120 x 2880 20~30 FPS (maxed)

Also, If you plan on using EVGA Precision do not use the normal EVGA Precision there is a newer program out for the Pascal series called EVGA PrecisionOC

Asking for the fan issue I have had no issue with the fan speed spikes with my EVGA GTX 1080 FE.

The first photo isn't mine Kudos to whoever made it =D

Reviews.title: Great GPU, Great Investment!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2017
Reviews.text:
I don't know much about GPU specs besides knowing the performance of it, and the basics of a GPU in general, but I must say, this GPU is a beast... Runs every game that I have played at max settings with ease, always-typically over 100 FPS, if not, it's always near. I like the FE for its blower style, takes the hot air, and pushes it out the back, instead of staying on the inside of the case and relying on the fans to push the hot air out.

I have bought this a few months ago, and still in great shape, nothing wrong came with mine. At the time, I bought this for 700$, I don't know if it's worth that price, but at the same time, it's a amazing GPU, so it really depends on the buyer. I'm so happy that I have the ability to say I have a 1080 XD! Only if I had the TI! XD!

I wish though that the LED was changeable, since my case fans are blue/white...but green works okay... Happy Gaming! Ima be using this GPU for atleast 2-3 years!?!?

Reviews.title: Got it at MSRP
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2016
Reviews.text:
This EVGA founders 1080 popped up at the MSRP price so I grabbed it , then it went back to scalpers prices about 20 minutes later.
Anyway , i know zip about games/gaming. I was comparing it to the TITAN I have running cuda code.
Good News : About 70% faster on the code I used.. It also drives my dual 4K displays , no issues.
Other News: My OS is Ubuntu 16.04 and getting this thing working was a bear. Good thing they have a nvidia developers site to get some tips or I would still be struggling with it. BTW, I ran it with Windows10 and it ran right off the bat with no issues , but also did no testing with it either.

Reviews.title: coil whine and running hot
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2017
Reviews.text:
this my second video card i remplace it and the second one is the same problem , i order a new PSU evga supernova G3 850 watts , amazing PSU , but still the problem continue coil whine , to the PSU is not the problem , i dont play game in 4k , i have monitor asus 60 ghz 1440p 27 inches ,
i play with the vertical sync enable always my fps dont go up than 60 , i only play WoW , and not ALL in ultra , well when i play wow my video card reach the 80c ine some areas other 70-75c and while the video card is more hot , the coil whine increase more too , i never conact evga support yesterday i open a ticket explaining my problem and i tell if they can change my founders edition for the ftw edition , diferents model but same serie 1080 , the only diference is ftw cost extra 10 dollars than founders edition that all , and probably are better than the poorly founders edition with a single fan and get high temps playing videos games that no even nast video games in graphics and in monitor 60 ghz and 1440p , i have a full power and good air flow

the agent told me they cant change for diferents models , only for same model , well i did i remplace in amazon for same model and problem persist , and the box of the video card say PLEASE NOTE: if your product is not working properly DO NOT RETURN TO STORE EVGA OFFERS DIRECT CUSTOMER SERVICE , that why i contact to evga and then he told me return it and buy the ftw edition

Reviews.title: Well Worth It!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2016
Reviews.text: This card is an absolute monster! Super easy install (as any card should be) - picked right up by the comp. Easy download for the EVGA drivers and boom! Now running everything in the highest settings possible with everything turned on and still getting 60FPS. I know some people were giving lower ratings to this card due to the prices by sellers due to the current scarcity of the card and that's a shame because it has nothing to do with the card. This is well worth it. It's true the price will probably come down over time, but it's already comparably close to what last gen cards are still going for and the boost is well worth it.

Reviews.title: Great card, but pricing is high (Even at MSRP)
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2016
Reviews.text:
I bought this card to get me by while i wait for the FTW edition to pop up, and so far i absolutely love it! The price is a little bit steep ($750~ because of tax) even for MSRP but that's better than the prices that we've been getting normally out of most cards. DO NOT BUY THIS CARD IF IT IS OVER $699.99, those sellers are juicing the money out of the low stock that we're having to deal with.

The reason i'm giving it 3 stars is that fact that this card is so much more pricey in comparison to cards like the SC and FTW edition from EVGA themselves. FTW will cost about $679.99 and has a boost clock much higher than the reference design we see here and has that ACX cooler that we all know and love.

That premium for the "Founders Edition" just can't be justified in my eyes.

Reviews.title: Best GPU performance per watt ever!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2016
Reviews.text:
Blows away any current gaming GPU at the time of its release, I am amazed at the performance per watt of this piece of hardware. I am able to run the most current games (Doom, The Division, Hitman) at 2560x1440 at max settings at a smooth 60+ frames per second.
If you are looking for different cooling options or more overclocking features then make sure you wait until mid June when the partner's cards will be releasing with aftermarket coolers, extra bios, and better power delivery. But if you just want the best performance right now and aren't going to be overclocking as I plan to do with my setup then don't hesitate to pick up this card right now!

Time by time, the config comes back by itself, not sure why. So I've saved a profile and I load it every time, so my games don't crash. If you have similar issues, try it out. Peace.

Reviews.title: If you dont really care about Raytracing or image quality reduction like DLSS, This card is for you!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2021
Reviews.text:
I've almost always bought Nvidia GPU's, MY first GPU was a 3dfx voodoo 2 banshee. first 3d accelerator to have 2d graphics built in, but after that it was always Geforce cards, GeForce 4 ti 4200, GeForce fx 5700xt (have on my living room shelf on display) 6800gts, 8800gtx, GeForce 295 (the dual gpu card, soo over powered at the time) GeForce 480, GeForce 680, DUAL GeForce 970 gtx's, then a 1080ti, then a 2080 super. I've loved Nvidia cards Until recently. DLSS is an upsampling technology that NVIDIA is trying to brainwash people into believing is a good thing. In short, it takes a low quality image and then uses its imagination to fill in what's missing. since it isn't actually rendering those things, the "imagination's" version is bland and is not at all legit looking. Since most games dont USE raytracing to any notable amount, and DLSS is Garbage, I wanted a card that could excel at 1440p High refresh gaming.

To accomplish my noble goal of Ultimate gaming Perfection, and to once again laugh at Console gamers who ALMOST got as fast as my pc, BUT NOT THIS TIME YOU CASUALS!! Even the most potent console (the xbox series x) only has a 12 TF GPU.. a 56 compute unit chip that runs at around 2ghz. I knew that I needed to call in the BIG guns. After a Research Grant from the Federal Taskforce for Noob Trolling, It was discovered E = M C Squared, SO that meant only one thing. We needed to Get a ALL AMD system built, to take advantage of Smart Access Memory for a free 0-10% performance boost, we needed to get a Merc 319 from xfx as well, since Hardware Unboxed and JaysTwoCents both on youtube, determined that the merc 319 6800 xt was the best air-cooled version of the 6800xt and could overclock almost as good as a water cooled card, without the mechanical failure point of the water cooler. We lost a number of Scientists along the way.. 5 alone to the Fortnite plague.. After the funerals, and after we burned the bodies to ensure there wouldnt be any contimination to the facility from anything ELSE that had been infected by Epic Game Store, we completed the parts list.

Ryzen 5800x -8 cores is the GO TO standard for gaming this gen. 6 are required, 8 is ideal.
Radeon 6800xt - Xfx Merc 319, best air cooled 6800xt as of time of writing
Asus gaming pro x570 - a motherboard. with slots. and ports.
Noctua D15 cpu cooler - for amazing Cpu Thermals
Case: Cooler Master h500 - for amazing full system thermals
SSDs: - 1tb samsung 970 boot drive, 2tb XPG S40G RGB SSD for games
Hard drives internal - 2x8tb iron wolf 7200 rpm hard drives
External hard drives - 2x6tb segate archive drives
Monitor - MSI 32" 1440p 144hz curved monitor, Asus 23" secondary both on monitor arm
Perhiphrials - Valve Index/w knuckles, Logitech x52 flightstick, Logitech G920 Steering wheel

This computer now DOMINATES any game I throw at it. It might not get the highest fps Specifically in GeForce sponsored titles, but the 6800xt still raytraces better than a 2080ti. Since most all games DONT take advantage of nvidia's "features" I opted for a graphics card that can turn all of its capabilities lose on Every game, not just the ones written for it.

No man's sky and most other games, 144fps+ at 1440p resolution, all settings as high as they can be set, and even 90 fps in Cyberpunk 2077. Any Multiplat game that is going to release both on console and PC, will be automatically optimized for Ryzen AND the 6800xt as the Rdna2 Gpu architecture is what powers the "next gen" consoles.

>10TF for the ps5
12<TF for the xbox series x
20 TF for the Pc running a 6800xt.

Nothing beats Pc gaming for pure fidelity, performance, options and no corporate overlord deciding what you can and cant play on it. I'm looking at YOU Sony.

Reviews.title: Thoroughly Impressed by the Aesthetics and Performance
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2020
Reviews.text:
I purchased this to build my Second computer. I was using a laptop for a long while but finally decided it was time to build. When I received this package I was so excited to open it up. It comes very simply packaged but plenty of foam to protect the GPU in transit. Unfortunately I don't have any pics of the GPU in the box or the side view as I am writing this review after I already built it. Too lazy to take it out. So far I've been playing Apex Legends at a rock solid 165 FPS on high settings. Let me tell you going from a laptop to this made it feel like I wasn't playing a game but watching a movie.

As I've been playing the GPU temps have been at a a stable 70C during game play.

All in all I do recommend this GPU however at the price point it is quite steep. Considering that it is 100 dollars higher than AMD's original version the cooling and construction is definitely worth the extra price. As for comparisons to the 3080 FE I feel that it is more worthwhile to get it but what sold me on this was one I was lucky enough to get it this early after release and two I wanted to take advantage of the resizable bar AKA SAM.

My specs:
- AMD Ryzen 5 5600x
- MSI MPG B550 Gaming Edge Wifi
- 32 GB G.Skill Ripjaws DDR4-3600 CL16 Memory
- 2x ADATA XPG SX8200 Pro 2 TB M.2-2280 NVME SSD
- XFX Speedster MERC319 Radeon RX 6800XT Black 16GB GDDR6

- NZXT Kraken X73
- NZXT H710
- 2x Lenovo Legion Y27q-20 27-inch WLED Gaming Monitor

Reviews.title: After an RMA, card is outstanding
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2020
Reviews.text:
Edit: Below is the initial review, which was for a card which failed on me in about 4 days.

XFX support was able to, after a couple chats on the phone with them, pull stock for their support to do an RMA. The RMA process was very quick after they received the card (2 days), and the new unit appears to be working fantastic. Card plays Cyberpunk 2077 at Digital Foundry’s “optimized settings” at like 60-90 FPS which fantastic. Even in my 11L SFF case it never breaks ~70C while running 100% utilization.

Initial review
——————
Worked for about 4 days, then started exhibiting cascading black flickering leading to system crashes. Was never stable on Windows for more than 5 minutes after that began.

Drivers reset, BIOS set back to default, new power supply and cables tried, multiple reseats, nothing. Backup card works fine with the system.

Now it won’t even POST past the VGA fault check on my ASUS motherboard. Fans spin, but will never boot to BIOS.

Reviews.title: Looks and works great, stays quiet and cool.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2019
Reviews.text:
I purchased this as an upgrade from my older GTX 970 that was finally kicking the bucket from the constant sagging it was doing. I'll not be going in-depth on the actual performance of this card, as you can find YouTube videos that would cover that much better than I could.
What I will talk about is the noise, temperatures, build quality and aesthetics of the card.
When gaming on this card for around 3 hours, the card never exceeded temperatures over 68C for me personally, though I'm not surprised because the cooler is pretty beefy and the card has 3 fans. I was mostly playing Shadow of the Tomb Raider at 1440P, though my older i7-4930k OCed to 4.2GHZ appeared to be a bit of a bottleneck for the card.
Noise levels were pretty much inaudible. Having the computer beneath my desk and roughly a meter away from my ears I could not hear the computer running, even after the extended gaming period. This is a night and day difference from my older GTX 970 that sounded like it was going to explode, even after a thorough cleaning and new thermal paste was applied.
Aesthetics
I'll be honest, as vain as it is, this was one of the main selling points for the card for me. There are so few high-end graphics cards that are white. Everything seems to be dark colors. This one fit the color scheme of my case great. The lighting of the Gigabyte text is a little dim, but overall still noticeable.
Build Quality
Nothing on the card felt cheap when I was unboxing it and installing it into my case. The back plate felt rigid and the shroud didn't feel flimsy. Nothing arrived damaged and the overall packing of the card was good. Everything pretty much worked out of the box. (Though you will need to download software to change the lighting on the card)

The card also used Samsung GDDR6 as opposed to Micron GDDR6 which is theorized to be a cause of most faulty RTX graphics cards which was one of the other main reasons I picked this card instead.

Reviews.title: Expensive but you get what you pay for!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2019
Reviews.text:
After about 1 week of gaming I can say that this GPU is just a beast! I was given two free games, Control and Wolfenstein, with my GPU. After playing Control to try out the graphics, the ray tracing was absolutely stunning! I was blown away! Considering I have never really had a top notch graphics card before, I definitely noticed the performance boost this card offers. I was gaming on a 1440p, IPS monitor with 165Hz refresh rate and this card was producing stunning, crisp images and scenes.

This card may be the most expensive component of my build but it was very worth it and I am happy to have it in my build. It is also one of, if not the only, all white GPU available which was also a huge selling point for me since I was putting together an all white build.

Reviews.title: Performs really well
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2019
Reviews.text: I don’t think some of the negative reviews are accurately reflect the performance of this card. I read something about fan noise but I’m willing to bet his custom settings were Misconfigured. I’ve clocked my card to 2.05 GHz with a 7850 ghz memory frequency without issue. I only see performance degrade clocking it +155 so I’ve set it to +140. Even though boost clock is marked at 1830 for the card. Not sure where the extra 60 or so mhz came from but I’m not one to look a gift horse in the mouth. Got this for 700 back at the beginning of June and even with the super release I don’t regret that decision as these cards currently go for 789.

Reviews.title: Good card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2019
Reviews.text: No issues with card. In my pc case at stock settings never went above 65c while under synthetic load. Usually 60c while gaming. Mine was a decent overclocker. Got it to 2100mhz on core and 7850mhz on memory. Only adjusted power limit. Did not add any voltage. Temp is now 65-68c while gaming, no adjustment of the fan curve was necessary. The gigabyte rgb software is junk. If you download it to change the color of the gigabyte logo, leave it running and uninstall program in the windows settings. The color you set will stay that color unless you re download the software. Of course they just released the 2080 super now so go get that one

Reviews.title: Great gpu with 4 year warranty!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2019

Temps is around 35c no fans, and light load like web browsing. During not domanding game temp is around 550 to 60 with fan running at 1000rpm. During intense gaming (demanding games at ultra 1440p) the temp is max 79. Im getting 60 to 110 fps in division 2 ultra 1440p.

I wish the logo was GeForce RTX 2080 instead of gigabyte and more lights. Even not rgb at least white lights on the fans.

Reviews.text: Had trouble getting this work on an MSI B550-A Pro motherboard. Toggled around some of the settings until I noticed that you can set the CPU PCIe Gen to 2,3 or 4. Reviews.title: Perfect for Linux gamers
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2021
Reviews.text:
After fighting to get the nvidia binary blob to work with my low latency kernel, I decided to give AMD video a try, since the drivers for these cards are already in the kernel, no driver download needed.

It worked flawlessly, easy peasy, no problemo. Good performance too.

Reviews.title: It works well but is glitchy
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2021
Reviews.text:
It works well but is glitchy. I think the drivers are conflicting with my installation of Window's 10. I have had periodic screen blackouts, especially with Google Chrome. To fix Chrome issues I had to turn off it's hardware acceleration feature.

Games work great and is a marked improvement over my older card.

Just wish the glitches would go away...

Reviews.title: Excellent Replacement!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2019
Reviews.text: A few months back my old graphics card just up and died. I was looking for something that was affordable and did well with most modern games. I was surprised to discover that this graphics card can play BRAND NEW games including Star Wars JEDI Fallen Order as well as Borderlands 3. Of course I have to lower the settings to medium but still, if it can play these new games with little to no problems at all, I really can suggest that anyone get this if your looking for a gaming graphics card for anyone who has a tighter budget.

Reviews.title: it works as it should
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2021
Reviews.text: whats not to like it serves its purpose

Reviews.title: Perfect for the casual gamer
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2020
Reviews.text: I got this card for my 7 year old nephew that wanted to play CSGO and Fortnite. Put this into a prebuilt Acer Aspire (only 300w psu despite the recommended wattage) and it’s perfect for his needs. 100+ FPS in CSGO and 70-120 FPS in Fortnite with an i3 9100. Temps haven’t gone above 65 degrees Celsius on the CPU or GPU. Needless to say, he couldn’t be happier.

Reviews.title: Allows for Mojave upgrade
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2019
Reviews.text:
Bought for my Hackintosh so I could upgrade from High Sierra to Mojave. Benchmarks say it is slightly slower than the Nvidia 1050 it is replacing, but I can’t tell. It is used primarily for audio production, so graphics aren’t terribly important.

Unlike the Nvidia card, there was no struggle with drivers/kexts. I just inserted the 560 and it booted right into High Sierra flawlessly. And the Mojave upgrade was similarly painless.

Reviews.title: Save your money!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2021
Reviews.text: This card is very mediocre I was running it with an intel i3 and I highly suggest is save up alittle more money and get something else if your just looking for like 720p on medium settings for most games this card would work but if you want something 1080p get a different card.

Reviews.title: It is compatible with older Mac Pro Machines.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2019
Reviews.text: I have a 2012 Mac Pro 5.1 computer. The Mac Pro stock video card will only work on OS X High Sierra or older. If you want to upgrade the OS to Mojave you need to upgrade to a newer "metal" card. The Mac version upgrade costs up to $800. However, since OS X runs basically anything you can purchase this "Windows" card for about $120 that works great on Mojave and you save a lot of money. Theoretically, it should work for the next OS after Mojave.

Reviews.title: Shuts my computer down, not happy
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2021
Reviews.text: I bought this to upgrade my computer. My computer worked fine as a regular desktop but not good enough for gaming since it did not have a graphics card. I got this graphics card since I thought it was going to take my gaming experience to a whole new level compared to where I was at. It worked fine for a few days but out of nowhere when i started playing games (in particular i only tried it on the sims 4 and overwatch both on low res) it started to make my screen turn black and exit me out of my game. If i pressed space it would load my computer up just with the games exited out of but if i didn’t click anything it would just shut down my computer. I have a 500watt power supply which is the minimum. I don’t know why it’s doing this but it was when i put this into my computer. I’m very unhappy and was expecting better from something that is this expensive.

Reviews.title: Excellent card for the money. Excellent card for Linux. Highly Recommend.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2019
Reviews.text: I am a Linux user and have always used Nvidia cards. I have to say I will no longer be using Nvidia cards. AMD based cards as this one is are fare superior on Linux. You don't even need to install the driver from AMD because the Open Source driver has the same or better performance. I am hugely impressed and would recommend getting this card or any AMD based card if you are a Linux person.

Reviews.title: Great card!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2019
Reviews.text: Had this card for almost a year now and it has been so good I'm considering adding a second. It is so maddening to try to overclock that I just gave up and hit the reset button, but the games I play are CPU bottlenecked anyway....however, not all of them are. From what I've seen, having 2 of these in many cases beats a single 1080Ti, and considering my cpu has nothing at the moment that can really beat it by any significant margin, for cooling purpose alone adding a second of these would be a great idea. It's a great product--as I thought before and still do now, even after the age of the RTX 2080 that I don't want to pay for.

Update: Still no problems, still smiling from ear to ear.

Reviews.title: Outstanding gaming, as good a price as you can find
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2018
Reviews.text: Will update if I have any issues after extended use but so far the performance is phenomenal and cooling solution is sound. Never broke 60c while mildly OC’d & under heavy load with fans set to 70% max, and they stay nice & quiet. Much higher than 70, the noise was definitely an annoyance but I maxed the fan curve at 70% and the temps didn’t even increase compared to 80% plus. Great card for about as cheap as you can get a decent 1070 ti for (MSI’s bottom barrel Ti’s don’t compare)

That product is inspected and tested to work and look like new by Amazon-qualified suppliers. Then, the product is sold as an Amazon Renewed product on Amazon. data.description: Sapphire Radeon Pulse RX 570 ITX 4GB GDDR5 HDMI/DVI-D/DP (UEFI) PCI-E Graphics Card 1 x HDMI 1 x DVI-D 1 x DP Whether you're new to PC gaming or you're looking to push your existing rig forward the sapphire Pulse range has everything that a modern Gamer needs featuring a range of high performance cards to match your budget and so that you can game the way that you want to without breaking the bank Pulse products have great performance and are engineered to last they feature top technologies such as Black Diamond chokes high-polymer aluminum capacitors that offer outstanding reliability and even twin HDMI ports for VR All sapphire pulse cards come with the performance parts you need for an excellent gaming experience at a price you can afford.

Reviews.title: Best Budget GPU
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2019
Reviews.text: First off, if you are looking for a top of the line card to run modern games on ultra settings, this is not it. This is, however, the best budget card you can buy. I went with this version of the rx570 because it only needed a 6 pin connector, and I didn’t need to update my power supply for an 8 pin. Brought my 8 year old build back to life for moderate gaming on a budget. Can’t run on ultra, but can get by on high at 60 FPS no problem on 1080p. I’m sure my quad core CPU bottlenecks this card, so maybe paired with a new Ryzen it would perform better. Still, great card for under $150 bucks.

Reviews.title: 1st version
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2018
Reviews.text: It’s an ok graphics card. HOWEVER, this card is the the slower version of the 2 versions. Sapphire has 2 cards of the exact same name BUT the clocks are different. This version is the slower clocked version in memory and GPU MHz. Just copy this cards name and put it into google. Go to sapphires website and pick the 2nd version. Copy that name and put it into google and you will see the faster clocked version of the 2 versions for this sapphire card(if you want the faster version). Other than what was described above make sure you have a CPU better than an intel core i3-6100 to pair with this card.

Reviews.title: They have one of the best ROIs for mining of any video card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2018
Reviews.text: We use these cards for mining and we have dozens running full out 24/7. They do put out a fair bit of heat with the single fan, but they stay around between 60C and 75C when mining which is not abnormal for RX570s. We can get 29MH on Eth with these and they only need a single 6 pin PEG connector for power. They have one of the best ROIs for mining of any video card.

data.description: PowerColor AMD Radeon RED DEVIL GOLDEN SAMPLE RX 580 8GB GDDR5 DL-DVI-D/HDMI/DPx3 PCI-Express 3.0 Graphics Card.

Reviews.title: Pretty good card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 18, 2018
Reviews.text:
This card is amazing if you're looking to play games above 60fps on high/ultra settings. The "Red Devil" red logo that you can turn on/off was a nice detail from PowerColor, the card also has a good looking backplate and nice design overall.

On the other hand, some "problems" that I found with this one is a bit of coil whine (not really that much) and some high temperatures (75-80°C) but that can be fixed by building a custom fan curve. Remember as well to have a good air flow in your case, I had to build the fan curve because my case only has two fans and it seems it's not enough to get good temperatures with the default fan curve. Also, I think this is one of the few RX 580 that requires a 6 + 8 pin cables, so make sure your power supply have them included.

Pros: - Nice and solid design. Has a cool backplate as well.
- Amazing performance in demanding games
- Runs cool, around 60-65°C (with a decent air flow and a well-built fan curve).
- It's perfect for those who want to OC and have a better performance (I think it can reach +/-1500MHz).

Cons: - The card is FAT so it's not the best choice for a crossfire.
- A bit of coil whine which can be annoying if you're not used to it.

Reviews.title: RX 580 Power Color Golden Sample
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2018
Reviews.text:
Had a little problem with the wrong card being sent but got in touch with the seller and they were very nice.
I was emailed a pre paid shipping label for my return and they sent my video card out the very next day expedited shipping FedEx. Over all a very pleasant experience. The Video card Rocks the Power Color RX 580 runs all my current games at max and Ultra settings, runs very cool compared to my old ASUS r 9 290. Wouldn't hesitate buying from Stalliontek again, great experience. Update 9/3/19 upgraded my monitor from a BenQ 24 inch 1080p 144 hrz to MSI 32 inch 1440p 144 hrz monitor was a little worried about the RX 580 keeping up at 1440p it does very well at the higher resolution in gaming. Still running games at high to ultra settings. 45 to 80 fps on most games buttery smooth playing.

Reviews.text: THIS IS A BIG CARD. Measure length, width and height BEFORE YOU BUY. I bought this for one of my computer and I did not get the height right (My fault). I had a mother board component that just barely got in the way. I could not install this on my main computer. However I stole my sons =) 580 that was not so thick and put it in mine. He as a VR system and needed the boost anyway and I didn't. Fortunatly it worked out in the end... Not a fan of the big Pentagram on the card; however I don't let things like that hold me back. I would buy again. I will update if this card fails within 2 years.

Reviews.title: Great card for GPU shortage.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2021
Reviews.text:
I got this card for USD 729. Amazon claims it looks like new and I can confirm that it does: only a few surface scratches are visible. The PCI-Express interface was clean, with no bent pins. The GPU fan works correctly and is very quiet.

Being an item that was manufactured around 4 years ago, thermals are surprisingly OK: on full load, the fan would kick in and keep the GPU below 75 degrees Celsius at all times. I don't think there is a real need to replace the thermal paste nor the cooling mechanism.

According to NVIDIA, this card supports the latest CUDNN release, which suits my purposes of using the GPU to run software pipelines using CUDA accelerated routines. I have not tested this card for gaming neither for CAD software.

I very much recommend this GPU for anyone interested in having a more than decent piece of hardware to run CUDA accelerated applications. If you can live with less memory (8 GB instead of 12 GB), I would also recommend taking a look at the Quadro RTX 4000. In my case, I got the M6000 at a significantly lower price than the one listed today (10/06/2021) so the RTX 4000 was a no-go.

EDIT (2021-10-16): I have been using this card on a daily basis for GPGPU computing, including deep learning applications, as well running some modest games.

I would not recommend running GPGPU applications without renewing thermal compound, as my card reached over 90 degrees Celcius for a couple minutes. After renewal, I got little more than 85 on the same application.

Modest gaming is also possible: Dirt 4, Project Wingman and World in Conflict are handled with ease (even if "maxxed out").

Blender, FreeCAD and SolidWorks 2016 (the one I could get for testing) also work flawlessly: having 12 GB of VRAM really pays off when using these programs.

The card is currently coupled to a 12 core Ryzen 3950X, 32 GB of RAM and NVMe storage. I regret nothing about this purchase given the absurd prices of GPUs.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Canada on September 26, 2021
Reviews.text:
I ended up returning the card I was shipped because it was not of the listed specification.

I think these cards are refurbished. Which is most likely they are pulled from scrapped servers from a datacenter as they are being end of life and a company verifies they still boot up. But in practice these refurbished cards run super hot, and consume a lot of power for what relatively slow performance, that a card made after 2015 with the smaller pricess (like anything smaller than 10nm today) would be able to achieve for you, and with less money.

The other advantage of buying a new card, is you get the full manufacturer warranty with the card, which is the order of years. I worry that this card might be "good luck" after the usual amazon return window.

Reviews.title: Great Card but has it's flaws
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2019
Reviews.text: I bought this card after trying the reference design first and finding that it was unbearably loud and ran very very hot 110c. The Thicc with it's two very large cooling fans does a much better job at cooling the card. However, the plastic shroud that XFX places around the PCB (Which is not any larger than the reference design cards) is what makes this card "Thicc" it also restricts airflow So in my Second picture I took a page from Gamers Nexus and took off all the plastic shrouds and the card cools much better now. This card has plenty of power it is supposed to be clocked at 1905Mhz but in games, it states that it is clocked at 2090Mhz which is what the Ultra is clocked at. My card is not an ultra model but maybe it was mispackaged? No idea there. This is a nice card for the money I actually had an RTX 2070 prior to going team Red and getting the RX 5700 XT. I like the performance of the RX 5700 XT over the RTX 2070. Before I took off the plastic shroud I was getting 55-71c after taking off the plastic shroud 38-68c.

Reviews.title: The card is one of the best looking cards out there in the 5700xt line up
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2019
Reviews.text: I like the card very much over all, although I have a few gripes. The card looks great in my Ryzen 3700 X build, although the cooling fins were bent a little on my card which was noticeable when installed in my clear sided case, it bugged me, so I tried to straighten them out as much as possible, still noticeable a little but much better. Probably done in shipping as the box was damaged. The two blue LEDs are overpowering, doesn't match up with my RGB's at all. Same gripe as others, the fans are loud during gaming. The good, the card performs great while gaming, seems a lot better than my RTX 2060 Super I have also, games seem to run smoother than the Super, due to my gripes I only gave the card 4 stars. I do highly recommend the card for the over all looks, and especially the great performance.

Reviews.title: Great Buy!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2019
Reviews.text: This graphics card has been a great purchase, I was upgrading from an old XFX r9 390x and the difference is night and day, I have 3 monitors hooked up, 2 1440p 144hz curved Samsung screen and a 3rd 1080p HP monitor on top. for productivity this thing can drive all 3 monitors no problem, for gaming at 1440p this card delivers an excellent experience, I like all major games like COD:MW, Borderlands 3 and The Outer Worlds this card delivers an incredible experience. If you don't have high-end 4k monitors I see no need to get anything beyond this card. I have read other reviews complaining about noise??? this card has been very quiet, fans only spin when the card is under load, and even then they aren't "loud" I have had a really good experience with XFX products and I am happy to recommend it.

Reviews.title: Beauty and performance
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2019
Reviews.text:
The first thing I want to note is that the card is beautiful. I’m a bit sad it’s inside my case.

The performance is outstanding. This is one of the most expensive cards I’ve purchased but the performance justified the price. I give it 10/10 in performance.

I think the only downside of this card is the fan. Don’t get me wrong. It’s loud but not obnoxiously loud. Like what you’d expect from a beefy graphics card. I just expected it to be more silent given the price range. Overall I would give it a 9.5/10 for the fan.

I also need to give a shout out to the helpful staff at XFX. I has some issues at setup and customer support was a godsend.

Reviews.title: Driver issues and too much plastic. AVOID this card.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2019
Reviews.text:
I'm dropping this bad boy to a 1-star review after noticing the VRAM temps were 88c while the VRAM temps on my Radeon VII and reference RX 5700 were 66c. Shame on you XFX! XFX, Did you not happen to notice the EVGA debacle with the GTX 1080 and 1070 FTW cards? Really.... do you have a bunch of rookies making these cards. Now I have to go watch that Gamer's Nexus video in order to try to fix the VRAM and probably the VRM's too. What a waste of time and money. Last XFX card I'm buying.

Taking off the backplate and the plastic attachment dropped the GPU core temps by 5c but only dropped the VRAM temps by 2c. With the fans at 80% the VRAM temps are now at 76c while the reference RX 5700 VRAM temps are at 66c at 50% fan speeds.

These RDNA cards still have a lot of driver bugs. I also have an RX 5700 (non-XT) reference card. Maybe Lisa Su needs to take some of that money she’s making off Zen 2 and hire some software engineers for the GPU side of things.

I’m having a lot of trouble connecting multiple monitors with these RDNA cards. If I can connect 2 or 3 monitors then I get screen flickering.
All is fine if I only have only 1 card connected.

The reviews for the Thicc cards aren’t that good. The reason why is the Cadillac shroud is too big but the Heatsink is wimpy. More fluff than stuff. Get it right XFX.

Reviews.title: Weird Design choices resulted in a very good deal for those willing to tolerate small inconvenience
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2020

I did, though. And I haven't had any trouble yet with overheating. I bought this particular card because these issues suppressed the price. I think I got a decent deal. In general I can recommend this GPU. It is considerably faster and sharper than the prior-gen AMD GPU we had for gaming previously.

It runs at idle for me at 31 degrees and 68 degrees under full load playing 1440p 144hz in titles like battlefield 5, apex, borderlands 3, ghost recon, Assasins creed odyssey and more.

Reviews.title: HD5770s and 6770s never came with 4GB of VRAM! AVOID!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2022
Reviews.text:
The vast majority of HD6770s did not come with a VGA port. The real ones also require a 6-pin power connector. Most cards that have an output layout like this are fake and, seeing reviews from people saying it won't run DX11, I'm inclined to believe this isn't even a 6770 as those did run DX11. The listed clock speed is about 200mhz lower than the original cards which, at best, points to these being faulty cards flashed with a different BIOS to operate at a lower clock speed. HD 5770s and 6770s (same card with 2 names) also NEVER came with 4GB of VRAM.

Again, this points to this being a card with a fake BIOS. I've tested another faked GPU claiming to be a GTX 960 4GB and the card even reported itself as such to the computer. In actuality it was a GT640 with 1GB of VRAM. When a game would try to utilize the reported 4GB of VRAM that didn't exist, it would cause the computer to crash.

Best case scenario here, you get a GPU that was originally released in 2009 (as the 5770, again, identical to the 6770...AMD just renamed the same card 2 years later) which has not received driver support since 2015, running at 76% of it's original speed (which may be how it gets away without a 6 pin power connector...but I doubt it) and have to spend some time dialing in settings to avoid games using more than 1GB of VRAM so the computer won't crash. In other words KEEP SHOPPING!

Reviews.title: I NEEDED A CARD TO CRUISE AROUND THE INTERNET WITHOUT ISSUE AND THIS IS IT!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2022
Reviews.text:
I just needed a basic video card to cruise around the internet without being stifled by lame performance of a cheap video card. While this card is a tad expensive it is not priced at the ridiculously insane prices of the middle to high end gaming video cards in 2022. This GPU has done the job of letting me go anywhere on the internet without video lag.

I had a more expensive NVIDIA GPU in my system with otherwise state of the art hardware. The newest most power Ryzen 9 \ 5900 CPU, fast memory and a 750 watt power supply. The NVIDIA GPU ran like hot garbage on my Ubuntu system. Ubuntu has a nasty sepia color scheme that saturates the entire OS and everything in it. It is not only ugly but painful to look at due to my vision issues.

I did not know for sure at the time but, I hoped a new video card from someone other than NVIDIA might perform better. Turns out this AMD designed GPU got rid of the nasty sepia tint. This video card creates a simple un-tinted OS that is a pleasure to use. The card is not BIG and uses only the power supplied by the GPU slot.

The card has some energy saver garbage installed that turns the card off if you power down your monitor. I took a star off for the energy saver mess. There really are no other issues. This is a great card to use on a Linux\Ubuntu system that is not used for hard core gaming.

Reviews.title: It does what I needed it to do
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2022
Reviews.text:
At my workplace I needed this half-height graphics card for a PC running a graphics intensive application that was practically unusable using the on-board graphics on the PC. Installing this card resolved the performance issues. I was pleased enough with that purchase that I bought one for my home computer to resolve some lag issues when playing 4K video on my old PC. This card resolved that issue, too. I don't know how this product benchmarks against the completion. I didn't do any testing like that. I simply had performance issues with applications that needed a graphics card performance boost. The price was right on this graphics card and I found that it worked fine to resolve those issues.

The only issue that I had was that the package came with no English instructions, no drivers and no software. I am an IT technician by trade, so I had little trouble finding the right drivers and software online. On one PC, Windows Update found the drivers, but I still had to download and install the correct version of the Radeon software. On the other PC I had to download both the drivers and software. So, this wasn't much of a problem for me, but it may be more than a novice PC users can deal with.

This product did what I needed and I've had no problems with it either at home or at work. It gets a 5 star rating from me even though I would have expected better instructions for installing the product and obtaining the correct drivers & software.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on August 29, 2022
Reviews.text:
Diese Grafikkarte ist absolout NICHT VR fähig ! Wer VR möchte MUSS mehr investieren !

Dennoch möchte ich diese Grafikkarte einmal für ihre erstaunliche und herausragende Leistung loben.
Hier hat MAXSUN alles richtig gemacht!

Ich habe einen Rechner mit ordentlich Leistung und natürlich auch mit einer entsprechenden Grafikkarte um damit die Valve Index VR-Brille zu betreiben. Ich bekam ein ausrangiertes Fujitsu Esprimo C710 mit USB3.0 und einem betagten aber ausreichenden Prozessor und suchte nun nach einer Low Profile Grafikkarte, die dabei auch noch schlank und bestmögliche Leistung bringen sollte.

Mein verrückter Plan:
Wenn an meinem Rechner was abraucht, sollte der kleine Esprimo das Ganze überbrücken.
Mit 32GB RAM und der MAXSUN Radeon RX 550 ist mir das sehr gut gelungen.
Wir reden hier natürlich von minimalistischen Grafikeinstellungen ABER BeatSaber, Phasmophobia (SinglePlayer), Pistol Whip und Blade & Sorcery sind durchaus spielbar und die Karte wird dabei nicht übermäßig heiß. Half Life - Alyx hingegen lagt sehr deutlich (wie es auch zu erwarten ist)

Dies ist keine Kaufempfehlung für VR, es soll aber verdeutlichen, was die kleine Karte auf dem Kasten hat.
Denn hier schlägt sie die vergleichbare GT 1030 um längen. Für Titel wie Diablo III und Co ifinde ich die RX 550 völlig in Ordnung und sie macht dort auch eine echt gute Figur.

Fazit: Es gibt natürlich deutlich stärkere Grafikkarten, egal ob AMD oder NVIDIA aber wer bei dem aktuellen Auf und Ab der Grafikkartenpreise eine günstige und verhältnismäßig starke Grafikkarte sucht, weil er sich gerade keine große leisten kann oder wie bei mir für einen kleineren Zweitrechner, sollte hier gut bedient sein.

Wir zocken wenig wenn dann Strategiespiele, Autorennen usw eine unserer Anforderungen war die Grafik entscheidend zu verbessern ohne Unmengen Geld zu investieren. Also neuer Monitor, Grafikkarte und ein zusätzlicher Speicherblock. Das Ergebnis kann sich mehr als sehen lassen!!!
Kein geruckel mehr und eine schön saubere Grafik, das beste die Grafikkarte wird bei uns nicht mal warm, läuft also alles sauber. Für 160€ kann man bei der Karte nichts verkehrt machen!

Reviews.title: Works great
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2022
Reviews.text: I use this graphics card for X-Plane on an older Intel 4790 that only supports DDR-3 memory. The program demands a lot of video resources, which the GD-1030 supplies. I cannot run at the highest frame rates, but it runs quite well. I am very satisfied with this graphics card.

Reviews.title: A solution to a problem.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2022
Reviews.text:
A family member had their monitor burn out and a 4K monitor was bought. Sadly, the built-in video card in the older computer was not strong enough to support the max resolution.

This video card did exactly that. And it is fine for a computer that is used for surfing, basic desktop work, etc. But once you want to watch a full-screen 4K video it struggles. Badly.
To be fair here, the 10-series were not built for 4K. But it needs to be said: it is one thing to do static work on 4K resolutions; once you go to a high-quality media display this is not the card you are looking for.

So this card does what it needs to do - and it will perform fine for most things in resolutions under 4k. It is affordable and available. But don't buy this one for high-quality gaming or intensive video or animation work.

Reviews.title: Probably was a return
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2022
Reviews.text: Some of the previous reviewers had opined that there cards might have been returns. I received an open box (no factory tape on the folds) and no documentation on the inside. No disk, manual, or anything for that matter other than the card. Obviously a return. Forewarned is forearmed and I had already gone to the Maxsun website and downloaded the latest drivers. I installed the card and, in fairness, works as advertised. The vendor just needs to ensure that the documentation is in every box. I also haven't registered it (no disk asking me to) but will do that on the website. Arrived on time.

Reviews.text: It's a decent substitute to be able to run games, but it isn't a great card. Not even an average card now. Thankfully I've got a RTX Ti 3080 on the way.

I upgraded my dell with 16 gig (from 8), SSD (from HDD), and now this video card which blows the doors out for the graphics performance I was getting before, for video rendering. No addtional power supply needed, either. It seems happy with my 224w. Very happy. Thanks again!

Reviews.title: Calling all base model alien ware x51 users
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2021
Reviews.text: Okay so to start , can you run gears 5 on 4k absolutely not. Can you run in a stock Alienware x51 without upgrading your power brick and running extra power ? Absolutely yes! Fits right in slim designed case , total install time was 10 min if that. I have looked high and I've looked low for a form fitting card for the x51 without a massive power overhaul. This card is not what I call "gaming" ready but the price point should sell you that. Overall it's slim will definitely fit in a modular case and does the trick of you are looking to do anything that's graphic hungry. Minus of course Fortnite at 60fps consistent. The value is peek. The extra 2gb of room helps to. Hope this is your final review to read before pulling the trigger. I did , great product in an oversaturated market currently

Reviews.title: Perfect for the price in today's market!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2022
Reviews.text: This GPU isn't the top of the line, but paired with my 60hz 2560x1600 HP monitor, it's given me crystal clear images with good FPS in Halo Infinite (@1366x768 for H.I. only), Kerbal Space Program, and Automation, the Car Company Tycoon Game. Though in Beam.NG, visual settings have to be set to Low for decent-good FPS. It keeps at a decent temperature (35-45°C) while being run at 100% consistently. If you're looking for a good GPU for 3D dense programs such as Second Life, this one is more then capable with the sacrifice of FPS (25-30 at High, 10-15 at Ultra graphics settings).

Reviews.title: Radeon HD5450 PCIe 512MB DMS59 Small Form Factor Video Card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2012
Reviews.text: I recently purchased a refurbished HP DC7700 Small Form Factor computer for $200 (actually I spent $250 to include the 5 day replacement policy for 2 years) and was looking for a SFF video card which would allow me to play both old and newer games. I needed to stay with XP because much of my work software would not operate under either Windows VISTA or Windows 7 due to the shortsighted way they implemented those upgrades. The HD5450 plays all the games I have including: Skyrim, Civilization V, Two Worlds, X3 Terran Conflict, Witcher Enhanced, etc. Plus the old games such as Hearts of Iron, Star Wars Knights of the Republic, Silent Hunter III, CMBB Special Edition, Combat Mission, and even Vampire - the Masquerade. I had to change the DC7700 so that all USB ports use port 11 (5 and 10) are required by the video card and turning back on the embedded sound after installing the video card. I am very satisfied with this card and it did not require me to upgrade my power supply (req. 240W) from what came with the computer.

Reviews.title: Best way to go for dual monitors
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2012
Reviews.text: Best way to go for dual monitors - in my opinion - have yet had any issues with the units I've purchased. Drivers are well behaved and in some cases you don't even need the install disk it just happens - overall user productivity increase. The USB2VGA devices are OK but tend to act up and just don't work consistently and have problems with matching quality. So in short the Radeon HD5450 good idea & worth the money.

Reviews.title: Excellent Graphics Card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2018
Reviews.text:
I loved the GeForce 1080 Mini from Gigabyte. I purchased mine on Amazon while they had a discount to $469, but wound up returning it as I found a better deal elsewhere. On both cards, I ended up with the same results.

Gigabyte's website advertises their core clock speed topping out at 1733 Mhz under OC mode, but GPU Boost 3.0 from nVidia saw it different. When the card is operating at its stock temperature cap (70 deg. C), AIDA64 is reporting GPU core clocks exceeding 1800 Mhz. That's 100 Mhz over the advertised speed! However, it is incredibly work-load dependent. Sometimes the GPU doesn't actually need to spin up that fast.

Even under full load, while the fan is spinning, I cannot really hear the GPU from outside my case. This is a FANTASTIC card for its size.

Reviews.title: Great size, great power.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2018
Reviews.text:
I'm coming from a GTX970, which by all means handles 95% of current PC games flawlessly. I upgraded because I wanted better performance in Fallout 4 (which is poorly optimized), and on emulators. Now with the GTX 1080, I'm getting almost constant 60fps in the center of Boston in Fallout 4 (and that's with texture overhauls and 200 mods). And as for emulators, I'm running Breath of The Wild with absolute minor stuttering on CEMU.
I also edit videos frequently but have not yet seen how much improvement there is with rendering in Adobe Premiere, but I'm sure it will be great. Lastly, this card is totally silent! Even emulating BoTW which takes a whomping 8.5gb of RAM to run, the card is incognito.

Reviews.title: Excellent card but be careful if your case is mini ITX
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2018
Reviews.text:
My case is Cougar QBX. It was a headache to install this card in my case due to its height.
The top of the card, where the SLI connection, is interfered by case's edge during installation. I had to separate the metal cover of the GPU's ports (taking almost all screws out) from the card in order to achieve the flexibility that is needed in order
to fit it in the PCIx16 slot.

Again pay attention to the height since it unusual (The older GTX970 and GTX750ti fit without any problem).

As a graphics card it is excellent. Played COD4 smoothly (~120 fps, 1900x1200) on the highest mode.
The temperature was ~80deg during gameplay and ~32deg in idle.

Reviews.title: Great space saver
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2018
Reviews.text: It's a great little gfx card. When I got bought it here from Amazon I got it for just $539.99(about $580/w tax) & I got what was advertised. When you do your research you'll find it is tiny bit slower than a full size 1080 at factory settings but the price was SO right. As for the price now ($749.95 when writing this review) I'd say if you don't need it to put it in a micro/mini case and have the space I'd get a full size card (or just keep searching and hope to find a MAD DEAL like I did). I use mine on a standard ATX m/b.

I recommend this to anyone who wants to game at high levels in a small form factor case

Reviews.title: Works with Xbox Series X
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2022
Reviews.text:
The SSD used was a WDC 530 with the 4096 sector size 512GB and 1TB. There are some that are floating around that uses the 512 sector, don't know if it will work.

The kit came with a thin (probably 0.5mm) thermal pad and a slightly thicker (probably 1mm) thermal pad. The thin pad was for the bottom layer of the SSD, without any component. The thicker one was used on the top lay where the NAND flash and controller are mounted.

The SSD was first confirm in a working condition by connecting it to a Win10 system. The SSD is then initialized to the GPT layout. The MBR layout was not attempted as it is consider an older format under windows.

To get it working, the SDD is plugged into the USB 3 port of the Xbox with a USB-to-NVME adapter. Once the Xbox detected it, a format was initialized. After the format, the SDD is mounted onto the kit and then plugged into the expansion port. It was detected without any issue.

To confirm the SSD was working, a Series X game is installed onto it and was play for over 1 hour. The kit was warmed to the touch, which implies the thermal pads are transferring the heat metal plates.

The steps to make it work:
1) Format the SSD under Win10 to the GPT format
2) Mount the SSD to the adapter
3) Plugged into the Xbox expansion slot
4) Xbox will say the expansion storage is not valid, this is OK
5) Unmount the SSD from the adapter and mount to a NVME-to-USB adapter
6) Plugged it into the Xbox USB plug
7) Xbox should say a new USB storage is detected
8) Format it
9) Unmount the SSD from NVME-to-USB adapter and mount to adapter
10) Plugged it into the expansion slot
11) Xbox should now detect it successfully
