data.description: The EVGA GeForce GTX 980 K|NGP|N graphics card is meticulously designed for the extreme over clocker. With a 14+3 power phase design, this new digitally controlled VRM can deliver up to 600A of current, all delivered through 3 power inputs, 8pin + 8pin + 6pin. ACX 2.0+ keeps the card running cool, and the ability to go single slot, with the included single slot bracket, makes this one of the sleekest graphic cards designed to date.

Reviews.title: It is a very good card. (Real world experience review)
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2015
Reviews.text:
I mostly got this version because I love Nvidia's Reference Design for their cards and it was out of the box OC, and can still be pushed even more. It is a $500 dollar GPU. When it comes to PCs money literally buys performance. Especially in terms of CPU and GPU. So it performs amazingly in everything I have played.

My PC Hardware:
CPU: i7-4790k.
GPU: This one?.
RAM: Kingston HyperX 2x4GB.
SSD: Samsung 850 EVO 120GB for Operating System (Win 10 64bit) and Apps.
HDD: 1TB Western Digital Green for games (and videos I record).

Call Of Duty: Advanced Warfare; This game runs amazingly at max settings excluding super sampling. There does not seem to be a noticeable difference with super sampling on. I see about 90FPS all the time during gameplay no matter what is going on in Campaign. In multiplayer the framerate is well over 100FPS with now stutter or slowdown.

Skyrim; The game destroys skyrim. Okay that is expected. BUT it also runs rock solid 60FPS with ENB mod and Many many other graphical and physics mods active. The only Mods that hurt the framerate are those ridiculous grass mods. That drops the FPS around 40 sometimes which is a bit disorienting when in combat. Other than that it will handle any mod you throw at it with ease as far as I have seen.

Tomb Raider (2013); Runs 60 FPS MAX with 2xSSAA (4xSSAA is just weirdly demanding. There is still plenty of VRAM left, system RAM, and I have a i7-4790k so i seriously do not understand what the problem is with 4xSSAA). The only time the game drops frames is during cutscenes when the camera gets close to Lara's Hair when TressFX is on. Other than that I have played through the entire game and noticed no other performance problems. You can check out a video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NP5C6aYIkik You will notice the only time it drops frames is when the camera gets close to her hair.

Firestrike Demo: Scored 14,214 for Graphics Score. 11,895 for Overall Score. (Better than 87% of results it says)

Now I do not know the power draw and all of those super specific kind of things but it only has 2 6pin power connectors which should tell you it is very power efficient for how powerful it is.

The default fan profile is really quite and keeps the card from killing itself (along with throttling back).

My card boost up to 1380MHz after GPU Boost 2.0 does its thing. I have tried lightly overclocking the card's GPU which worked fine but caused coil whine. I fixed the coil whine by setting the card back to default values then simply stressing it out with games and benchmarks for a little while. That method has worked for me but I would caution against OC the card further. I have since left my card at stock. (I will probably overclock it again anyway, I am weird like that lol).

I tried bumping the RAM speed up a little. All i can see for this is do not do it lol. I do not know why but my card threw a fit and the graphics driver crashed. A LOT of reviewers of the base model 980 and all the 3rd party derivatives bumped the RAM speed up to a woping 7010MHz (10 from the base 7000MHz) and left it there. This card as you probably saw in the specs list Some said it was because of the way that power is allocated on this series (900) cards that OC the ram would take power away from the core so they just put all the OC effort into the Core. I think it is for a different reason but again I cannot be for sure.

The moral of the story is this card can handle pretty much anything @1080p you can throw at it. And it looks nice....really nice. It is pretty. It is quite at base fan profile like all the other cards with this cooler. If you have the money for this and not the 980ti/Fury X i would recommend it.

Reviews.title: 980s Overall Experience.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2015
Reviews.text:
Do you hate options menus? Do you like graphical fidelity? Do you value performance ratings over price/performance ratios without going to extremes? Then the GTX 980 is the perfect choice for you.
It's no question that the GTX 970 has a better price/performance ratio and you'll be able to pick one up for just at 200$ less, and if your budget can't handle the increased price of the GTX 980; you're not missing all too much. Realistically from what I've seen, the GTX 980 performs about 10-20% better, which isn't enough for many to justify 200$.
Likewise, the GTX 980 is to the Titan X what the 970 is to the 980. For another 500$, twice the price of the 980, you can have a Titan X and 20-30% better performance. I, myself, opted for a dual SLI 980 build rather than a single Titan X build. SLI 980s performs a good bit better than a single Titan X and cost about 100$ more. With DirectX12 coming out soon, SLI is a smarter idea than ever due to SLI scaling. Currently, dual-GPU configs realistically only run at 160-170% the performance of a single card. DirectX12 aims to make that 200% in addition to the massive performance tweaks. With dual 980s already outperforming a single Titan X, it was a no brainer to me to go for the 980s.
For those worried about the 980 only having 4GB of VRAM (and planning to SLI), don't. DirectX12 is said to also add together VRAM instead of limit it to the maximum of one card. This means that a dual 980 build will have 8GB of usable VRAM - plenty for 1440p or 4k. At 4k, Shadows of Mordor on maximum settings with the ultra texture pack only uses 6.5GB. Shadows of Mordor is an extreme example, however, as most games don't even come close to touching 4GB, even at 4k.

All of that said, you really don't need to opt for SLI with the 980. Unless you're trying to future proof for a while or plan to play in 4k in everything that has it as an option, it's unnecessary. One single 980 very, very easily gets 60FPS at 1080p max settings. The same can be said for 1440p, you'll rarely if ever see less than 60FPS at max settings. Even at 4k, you'll generally have over 30FPS.

I'm not a fan of overclocking generally because I don't trust my own ability not to destroy it; thankfully, EVGA has one of the highest stock clocks of the 980. I can safely have an overclock done by professionals without having to worry about my warranty. Additionally, EVGA's cooler design is very well done. The ACX 2.0 design acts as an intake rather than an exhaust and seems to work very well. Only with kboost on for extended periods of time have I come close to breaking 70 Celsius (with fans set to maximum). That said, unless you're benchmarking or doing something extreme like that; you'll never, ever hear your fans. In fact, on the stock fan config, the fans won't turn on until they reach 50 degrees Celsius. On maximum, however, they are quite loud. Playing Shadows of Mordor at 4k on maximum settings, the fans are barely at half speed and still rather quiet; though I'm not the type to care about how loud fans are.

I'm very happy with my 980s and I'd recommend them to anyone with a similar budget; but for those who prefer to save 200$ or 400$ in an SLI build, the 970 is a worthy choice as well.

Reviews.title: Awesome Video Card + Awesome Manufacturer
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2015
Reviews.text:
I'm not going to write a very long review because you can find the specifications and benchmarks of this card on nearly every major tech website. Instead I'll focus on what separates EVGA and this card from other manufacturers succinctly. EVGA is one of those rare manufacturers that hasn't outsourced it's support so if you're in the USA and have an issue with your video card at 2 am, you can call their 24/7 tech support and be assured someone will pick up on the other end.

My experience with their warranty service has been stellar and beyond what most companies do. For example, I previously purchased a pair of GTX Titans and after a year, one of them died on me. I used EVGA's online RMA system and since I purchased their advanced RMA warranty, they cross shipped me another one and I had a replacement in two days. Prior to that, I had an EVGA GTX 680 that had a broken component on it (purchased it like that used from someone else). I sent pictures of this to EVGA and asked if it could be repaired, even if I had to pay. To my astonishment, they simply said, "send it in to us and we'll either fix it or send you another one". Sure enough, a few days later after they got it, I checked the online system and a replacement had been issued. How can you beat that kind of service?

Now as far as the EVGA GTX 980 ACX 2.0, I bought 2 of these in SLI and run them in an NZXT H440 case which is famous for poor airflow. However, despite that, these bad boys overclock to 1520 MHz core on stock voltage (1.206v) with +400 on the memory and they don't even flinch. Temperatures are also really good, GPU 1 is 78C max after hours of gameplay and GPU2 is 68-70C max. Fans never rev to 100% either, GPU 1 maxes at 75% and GPU2 at 65% using EVGA Precision to control them. ASIC quality for mine were both 75-76% so I lucked out there.

So the price is good, the performance is fantastic (they destroy my Titans when comparing both OC'd) and the operating temperature is really good. I can't really think of any cons associated with this video card and especially EVGA. If you're in the market for a new video card, go for the EVGA GTX 980, you won't regret it.

UPDATE: 2/23/15

I took one star off because I recently learned EVGA requires people who purchase these cards to register them within 14 days of the card's *purchase date* (not shipped or received) in order to qualify for their Step-Up program. If you miss it even by 1 day, well then too bad because they won't budge. Instead, if you want Step-Up, they penalize you by forcing you to buy their 5 year extended warranty for $30/card. In my case, that would be $60 and all for simply missing the registration date by a few days. It's obviously a way for the company to earn extra money but after already giving them $550+, you'd think they'd just make exceptions and let it slide or better yet allow customers to register for Step-Up for the entire 90 day period. Normally I recommend EVGA products and services to others without hesitation but based on principle, I will strongly consider competing brands the next time I buy $1100+ worth of video cards.

Reviews.title: 4K Dreams? GTX 700 Series Jumpers Beware, GTX 500 Series Jumpers: This Card's For You
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2015
Reviews.text:
I currently use this card on a i7 5820K on an X99 MSI Krait Motherboard, Windows 8.1 on SSD, and 32GB of RAM. When I upgraded this card, I was running two 760s SLI, and had bought a beautiful 4K monitor in hopes that I would pioneer into the 4K Realm. I'd watched all the professional youtube videos about 4K Gaming and seen people running games at 4K on 1 980. And many games 4-5 year old games do just fine at settings that might not be Ultra, but decent enough to give you that high end gaming experience you're looking for on a PC. The multiplayer populars such as League of Legends, Dota 2, Counter Strike, and even Battlefield 4, can push at 4K on the 980 at High settings, at 60 fps and higher. But the trouble comes when we talk about AAA Game Titles such as Witcher 3 (Yeah, even with the Hair FX turned off), Far Cry, or even high end graphics games like Evolve.

I'd go into details, but I'm not a professional reviewer or a spec nerd, I consider myself knowledgeable enough to tell you the honest truth about what to expect. For a modest gamer, this card will definitely be decent for you at 1080 or 1440p, without question. If you don't feel like going to 4K, don't worry, one of these cards will be future proof for at least 5 years. But if you're that kind of person who just has a dire need to be ahead of the game.. this card is dwarfed by the 980 Ti, which stands to be the card which will be able to keep up the fight for some time.

For those in the GTX 500 Series, this card will seem like a huge leap, you'll notice the difference and by all means be satisfied. But if you're a 700 Series guy, the real improvements found in this card are its power usage which you'll notice is significantly less. EVGA's styling of this card is very good from a profile angle, and I haven't had many complaints except for the occasional screen glitch here or there, which I personally think has more to do with my monitor than it does actual issues with the card itself.

Remember, if you have a monitor that is outdated, the card won't make it more awesome, and most cases with vsync off, will make you realize how painful your refresh rate on your monitor really is (especially if coming from the 500 Series). This card is almost ideal with a high end 1440p gaming monitor like the Asus RoG Swift PG278Q or another 120-144Hz monitor that can really give you the experience of those extra frames so you can do something with it.

Overall I like it, but since I'm kind of obsessed with pushing the limits, this card isn't for me. But if you're not going to be trying to break the "4K Pixel Barrier" anytime soon, this card is definitely for you.

Reviews.title: My journey to the GTX980
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2015
Reviews.text:
I'm a conservative gamer. I even prefer to play with a controller. Hey, I grew up a console kid, no judgments from the PC Master Race. That being said, I was slow to join the darkside, but I have a lot of tech knowledge, so to not build my own gaming rig didn't make sense.

So I finally decided instead of getting a PS4 (I actually did end up getting a PS4 for xmas, but I never use it), I would build a gaming rig. I started with an R9-280, but it couldn't quite keep up with me, so I tried the R9-290. It was a good card, but it liked to run hot, and I felt like the performance was not as strong as it should be. I considered the R9-290x, but it wasn't enough of a boost to justify the change. I also considered the R9-295x.

The problem with the R9-295x is it's basically a crossfired card. The problem with crossfire (I tried it with 2 r9-290s), is it gives terrible micro stuttering (and BSOD too!). I can't abide micro stuttering or tearing at all. It's like nails on a chalkboard to me.

After looking far and wide for the strongest single GPU card, all the benchmarks led me here, to the GTX980. The only problem is the price is a little high. Okay, it's a lot high, so I was expecting a lot of performance per buck. I did some initial benchmarking with the card against the R9290, and I was surprised at how well... the r9-290 kept up. I actually wanted the GTX980 to destroy the R9-290. After all, the R9-290 is at a price point of around $250 to $300 bucks. So the GTX980 being twice as much at $550, I expected twice as much power. Not so.

That is not to say the GTX980 is not an amazing card. It is. And it is certainly better than the R9-290, but it is not incredibly, unbelievably better. It's about... 20% better. But where this card really shines is in a few different places.

First, power usage and heat output. This card is probably 33% cooler than an AMD card, and that's a big plus. It means I don't have to worry about it overheating and can just get my game on.

Second, I have also found it handles memory better, especially with games with high textures, like modding some games to death with 4k textures. It doesn't complain about it like a little girl. (i.e. crashing or black textures)

Third, and most importantly, it runs much smoother than the R9290. This is a measurement that you don't see on benchmarks, but this card just gives consistent performance. And what I'm referring to here is dropping frames. You can run through a crowded street, and maybe your FPS will drop, but it does so consistently. 60...55...50...45...50...55...60. With the R9290, it's like 60...10...40...50...30...10...60. It jumps all over the map! It's annoying. But the GTX980 is just smooth.

All and all, this is a 5 Star card, and I would buy it again. But to be fair, check your expectations at the door, and if you want something with similar performance but for a whole lot less, wander over the AMD camp. They have cookies. Nvidia has the cake :P

PS Thumbs up for EVGA quality too!

Reviews.title: Absolutely phenomenal card - A Skyrim Modders Dream
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2015
Reviews.text:
Absolutely phenomenal card. I upgraded to this from an EVGA GTX 680 2GB and the difference is immediately noticeable. I run a very very heavily modded version of Skyrim that I used to get around 35-50 FPS with the performance RealVision ENB. With this card, I get 60fps everywhere (with the full RealVision ENB) with only the occasional dips in extremely populated or vegetated areas. I was also able to add 5 new graphical mods to Skyrim such as the famous FPS hungry "grass fields" mod, 4k texture replacers, and a few others, and I barely notice it at all in my frame rate. You know those absolutely insane screenshots you see of modded Skyrim? A lot of the time those shots have graphical settings so high that the game is actually unplayable, and that fidelity is only used for screenshots before the player turns down the graphics a little to actually play. Well this card can actually PLAY the game at the fidelity you see those screen caps at. This week I am going to test out Far Cry 4, Bio-shock Infinite, and both of the Metro games on Ultra with this beast. I have no doubt in my mind this thing will run smooth as butter on those titles.

When should you upgrade?:
If you currently have a 600 series card or below, then I recommend picking this (or the 970) card up as it is definitely a worthy upgrade for the price. If you have a Titan, or 780/780ti then I recommend just holding off a little bit until the next generation of card is released. Simply because it might not be that big of a leap from the 780ti to this in terms of cost justification (unless you can sell your 780 to make up a portion of the cost of this of course, which is what I did with my 680).

Noise:
This card is quiet as can be. with the ACX 2.0 design the fans don't even spin up until you need them (by design) and when they do you don't hear them at all.
UPDATE on coil while. I DID end up experiencing slight coil whine while playing high intensity games. I found out this was coming from my PSU and not my new 980. Once I upgraded fron a 700w to a gold rated 800w PSU, the whine went away.

Size:
This card is just as long as my GTX 680. But the 980 is actually thinner due to my 680 having a blower fan shroud and this having standard fin fans.

In the end, this card is great, I highly recommend it, and I wish I wasn't at work right now or I'd be home slaying dragons while counting the bugs on the rocks in Skyrim.

Reviews.title: Running this card since 2015
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2022
Reviews.text:
I have been running this card daily between a few people since 2015, 7 years later it is still working like i first bought it despite showing its age in newer games over the past few years.

the use i have got out of this card has probably made it my best tech purchase ever - it's been through multiple motherboards, cpus (originally started w/ sandy bridge 2500k,) and setups and now has a final home in a HTPC/server paired with a 3900X until its end of days.

Nowadays i can't recommend this card for obvious reasons - the main being its age and power draw//performance as there are better options. Especially at its current price of $400.

Reviews.title: Amazing
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2015
Reviews.text: First I'll start with telling you the performance this thing has. This card allows me to not only view in simply amazing quality but aswell as being able to handle it! with the purchase of this card came a free game download from uplay, so i chose far cry 4. the other two options were "the crew" & "assassins creed: the unity(I think)" I was able to play far cry 4 on ultra settings with no problem. Some wouldnt consider minecraft an actual intense game, but I played a yogscast complete pack which is heavily modded & it makes you lag extremely bad. with this card (& of course alot of ram & a nice pcu) I was able to get 300fps according to the game, without overclocking anything of course. So this card is amazing, but the only issue I have is the heat this thing creates. This thing can get pretty hot. especially when i loaded up far cry 4 the card shot from ~40c (average temperature) to 70c within a few minutes. Now, you do have the option to set up your own fan profile for the card, which I did. I had to turn the fan to I think around 60-70% speed for the temperature to sit around 60c. Now, you may think, "well thats not so bad" but the issue I have is that the fans are like jet engines. they are really loud, but they do cool off the card VERY NICELY! Im sure you could let the fan sit at 100% speed and probably have the temps down to 45-50c but I just dont know if i can trust the fans spinning that fast for multiple hours without something wrong happening. aswell, theyre really loud at high speeds. I plan to water cool this sucker as soon as the water block is released for it & im sure once this thing is water cooled it will be a force to be reckoned with!

Reviews.title: EVGA has done it again. Top performance and cooling with decent clock speeds out of the box for a decent price tag!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2014
Reviews.text:
The ACX 2.0 cooling solution is top-notch and quiet, I honestly hear my case fans over top of the ACX 2.0. I setup a custom fan profile in the EVGA Precision X software along with a low impact 10% OC on top of EVGA default "superclocked" speeds. The card has never gotten over ~61 deg. cel. during marathon gaming sessions. (Metro Last Light, Planetside 2, Skyrim, Farcry 4, Crysis 3, Titanfall) Even on the highest settings the FPS may bog down a bit but it still PLAYS SMOOTH.

Pulled a 3DMark score of 12,229 in First Strike w/modest clock speeds. This could easily get over 13K if I pushed the clock speeds up.

I'm running a Core i7-3770K @ 4.6ghz w/16gb 1866 RAM. Everything plays smooth as silk, I am extremely pleased with the card. I have a lower power/thermal footprint for a huge gain in performance (Upgraded from water-cooled GTX 480). Now, I just run the CPU in the cooling loop alone as the video card doesn't even need it.

My system:
ASUS Maximus V Gene
Intel Core i7 3770K @ 4.6ghz
16gb DDR3 1866 (PC15000)
EVGA GTX 980 SC @ 1350mhz base
ASUS VG248QE 24" 144Hz 1ms (GTG) LED Backlight LCD 3D Monitor
2x Samsung 840 Pro SSDs and 2x SATA HDs

IMPORTANT NOTE: You will need male to male Displayport cables if you want multi-monitor setups. The only way to get over 60hz refresh is via DVI / Displayport, HDMI does not support > 60hz refresh. Also, you will need to tweak the settings in nVidia control panel if you do use HDMI or you won't be getting the full range of color out of your display. See: http://www.pcgamer.com/nvidia-cards-dont-full-rgb-color-through-hdmiheres-a-fix/ for more information. Also, the latest BETA drivers have a setting under "Adjust desktop color settings" and then "Dynamic Range" where you can specify 0-255 for the full range. This will get you the deeper blacks and brightest white/colors when using HDMI.

data.label: Phanteks 8 to 8 (4+4) Pin M/B Premium Sleeved Extension Cable 19.68" 500mm Length, Green (PH-CB8P_GR)

The cables are longer than standard cables in the market, at 500mm, this help make installation easier. Made from high quality braided sleeves, the cables will also be compatible with the Phanteks' power supply splitter.

Reviews.title: THE PICTURE OF THE ITEM MAKES IT LOOK DECEPTIVELY SHORT.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2020
Reviews.text:
I had no problem with the Phanteks 24 Pin M/B Premium Sleeved Extension Cable 19.68" Length, Red(PH-CB24P_RD). At 19.69 inches in length it is a bit longer than most 24 pin extension cables for the PC. I'm not a real worried about perfect cable management unless it impedes air cooling. The cables work fine. I had a big fat 1000 watt power supply that blocked lots of cable access points. I had to take the long way round to access the 24 pin connector on the motherboard. The stock 24 pin cable from my 1000 watt corsair power supply just did not reach no matter what I tried.

The Phanteks 24 Pin M/B Premium Sleeved Extension Cable 19.68" Length, Red(PH-CB24P_RD) connected to the power supply cable extended the reach so it easy connected to the 24 pin motherboard connector. The shock of orange cable in that sea of black cable made the case look nice. Using the cable was child's play as there were no special connection issues. Just a few gentle clicks and everything that needed connection was.

This Phanteks 24 Pin M/B Premium Sleeved Extension Cable 19.68" Length, Red(PH-CB24P_RD) worked for me without issue. I highly recommend using this cable in a PC build where the 24 pin cable needs some help lengthwise.

data.label: ASUS Dual NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2070 Mini OC Edition Gaming Graphics Card (PCIe 3.0, 8GB GDDR6 Memory, HDMI, DisplayPort, DVI-D, for Intel NUC 9 Extreme Kit and Small Chassis.
data.description: Powered by NVIDIA Turing, the ASUS Dual-fan RTX 2070 MINI features Overclocked 8GB GDDR6 and a cooling solution that is compact enough to fit into a 2-slot design, and resigned cooling solution that allows two axial-tech fans to take advantage of the mesh side panel of small chassis like Intel NUC 9 Extreme Kit, Intel NUC 9 Pro Kit.

Reviews.title: Super A1 Chip with Extreme Overclocking Capability. Easy 2085+ Core /7500+ Memory
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2020
Reviews.text:
The very latest A1 revision seems to have been improved more and now allows even higher and more stable overclocking out of the box. All you need to do is to dial +150MHz Core Clock, +500Mhz Memory Clock, set Power Limit to 100% and increase fan speed a bit, the card will run stable at above 2000MHz core and 7500MHz memory consistently.

I tested few other settings to increase Core Voltage by +5 to +10, but that didn't seem to affect overclocking at all. Now I just keep it default and also dial Power Limit to 100% and customize the fan to run at higher % to keep it very cool. The screenshot of the clock rates has a drop off due to screen protection. Before that, it ran at 2055MHz stable with medium GPU load. I didn't bother to test the highest memory clock rate as it's already extremely fast and not bottlenecking the performance. At higher GPU load, the clock rate will fluctuate more but still run at high clock rates.

Reviews.title: A relatively cool and quiet card that performs as expected.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2020
Reviews.text:
My initial impressions of this card are very positive. It runs decently cool under full load: mine peaked around 69 (nice) degrees celsius in Red Dead Redemption 2 after I undervolted. It can handle RDR2 at 1440p Hardware Unboxed settings with 60fps+, so it can likely handle anything at that resolution. I expect it will perform well for years to come.

However, I have some minor gripes. My card did have SOME coil whine, but this was greatly lessened with my undervolt. At this point, I think some coil whine is pretty unavoidable. The only card I've ever had that didn't have any coil whine was the excellent Asus GTX 1070 Strix. I certainly wouldn't describe this card as "silent", but it isn't loud either. Under light loads, it's completely silent, which is something that is VERY important to me. Impressive considering its form factor.

All in all, I'm very happy with this card and I'm looking forward to putting it in a Skyreach 4 Mini.

Reviews.title: Neat little card that works as advertised. Happy so far!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2020
Reviews.text: So far this has been a great product and works as expected. I purchased this for an itx build that I was working on and have so far been pleasantly surprised at both it's performance and temperatures in my phantek evolv shift case. It has taken every game I have thrown at it like a champ with only a few games that I have tested spiking the temps... Looking at you assassin's Creed odyssey. Avg temp for the games I play has been around 60 celcius. Everything has run at ultra with over 60 fps at 1080p. I think that my only disappointment so far is that it isn't a 2070 super card instead!

You’re mileage may vary, depending on your case cooling, but at full power I see 70c temps after full on gaming for a couple of hours. Be sure to use GPUTweak and set a good fan curve.

data.label: ASUS Radeon RX Vega 64 8GB Overclocked 2048-Bit HBM2 PCI Express 3.0 HDCP Ready Video Card (STRIX-RXVEGA64-O8G-GAMING)
data.description: Powered by AMD's Vega architecture, the ASUS ROG Strix RX Vega64 OC Edition delivers jaw-dropping 5K HD gaming experiences featuring 8GB of HBM2 memory. Outshine the competition with Aura Sync RGB lighting while MaxContact and FanConnect II maximize cooling performance. GPU Tweak II allows for simple and intuitive monitoring and control.

Reviews.title: A flawed but really good aftermarket card, however DO NOT buy this card in 2020.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2020
Reviews.text:
I cannot recommend purchasing the Vega 64 Strix card in 2020 at any price point other than $200-240 used. If for some reason you want this exact card know that it can be purchased for $350-400 new as of February 2020 on eBay. However, at that price you can purchase a 5700 XT which has 15% more power. The current listing price of $800 is absurd and shouldn't even be considered unless you like flushing your hard earned money down the toilet.

For 1080p 100-144+ FPS or 1440p 60-90 FPS gaming, with a mix of high and ultra settings, and the occasional medium setting (curse you Volumetric Clouds in AC Odyssey) this card performed outstanding. However getting it there took a few tweaks. The biggest problem I had with this graphics card was with the way the card was manufactured. The factory thermal pad in it didn't make full contact with all of the VRM so some of the heat produced wasn't properly pulled into the heat sink as a result the card would throttle and never reach the clocks that ASUS listed. I fixed this by replacing the thermal pad with one that properly covered the VRM. After that undervolting the card and overclocking the HBM2 memory I was able to get close to a 15% boost in performance. I don't know how wide spread of a problem the thermal pads are with Strix Vega 64 cards, but at the time googling a fix I found several people on forums also having the same issue.

I bought this card early 2018 and while Vega wasn't a GTX 1080 killer as rumored, I have been pleased with it even with the problems I've encountered. That said, I have bought just Strix cards for last few GPU cycles and have to say for the 1-3% boost in performance with ASUS cards they are not worth the price premium, if price to performance is your main drive for purchasing a graphics card.

If this was late 2017 early 2018 I would say go ahead and buy the card, but with so many much better options in 2020 you really should look at something else.

Reviews.title: Save you money...
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2018
Reviews.text:
Factory overclocked my @ss! I have done EXTENSIVE testing on this card and I can say without a shadow of a doubt that this card is NOT worth the money! The whole issue stems from the fact that the Vega 64 chips dynamically adjust their clocks on the fly. I can't seem to hit the advertised clocks on this card as the chip automatically throttles itself down. 1350-1520MHz clocks is ALL I EVER get out of this card no matter the use. My Vive VR games will stutter and glitch as this card is running WELL below it's advertised speeds. And it's not a heat/fan issue. The card never gets above 76. Fan never goes above 55%. The fan will max out at 75% though. So if your case fans aren't doing their job, expect the card to NEVER use 100% fans.

I'm not saying it's a bad card. Runs circles around my Fury X. But I've NEVER had a card flat out refuse to hit it's advertised speeds. Sure, with Chrome it will hit max clocks. But not in a single 3D application...you know, the whole reason you bought the d@mn thing in the first place. I've tried Wattman, MSI Afterburner, ASUS AI Suite, you name it. I've scoured the internet and REDDIT forums for answers. I can NOT get this card to do what it's advertised to do in a video game! If this is the direction AMD is headed, I might have to start buying nVidia again...and I f'ing HATE nVidia!

UPDATE: Finally got the card to hit 1600MHz or so. Had to install ASUS GPUTweak and manually set the fans to max speeds at lower temps. Then,. I hooked one of my PWM case fans to the pins on the back of the card and set the speeds for it to max out at about 45 Celsius. I also set my Corsair H115i AiO cooler to max speeds forcing as much hot air out of my case, and bringing in as much cool air as possible. Sounds like a wind turbine in my room now, but the card's temps stay around 55 Celsius which keeps my clock speeds a lot higher than before, thus making my games run faster. A lot of work to get it functioning correctly. And with my speakers (or a good set of headphones) I can overpower the fan noise.

Reviews.title: This thing games
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2018
Reviews.text:
I used this in an all-AMD build. 2700X with this Vega 64. You'll probably watch youtube reviews on this thing, by people that are paid by Nvidia to tell you how garbage this card is, but those are false. My specs are 2700X (air cooled by Wraith Prism), 16GB 3000MHz RAM, STRIX Vega64. Running Rust, on Fantastic settings (I use this because the game is not AAA optimized) I get 90FPS on procedural maps, and 110-118fps on Hapis. BF1, I get 120-140 fps on Ultra. Overwatch gets just under 140 in heavy fights on the highest preset, and Rocket League never drops below 144 on the highest.

I think it's a great GPU, and I'm happy that I am able to finally go back to a full AMD build (which may not be a consideration for most, but I have historically built AMD/ATi rigs). You can control the GPU color (if you're not using an ASUS mobo, which integrates all Aura devices) by downloading the Asus Aura software. It's a little more work to put the color values in from other software if you're doing matching, but it's a one-time thing.

I have heard, and seen data that shows, that the card draws a lot of power. I don't measure that. My utility bill is no higher than it was with my i5/GTX970 build, but that's the nature of house electricity. I only needed a 650W PSU for this build.

Reviews.title: Excellent Graphics Card For Gaming, Don't Focus On The Negative Crypto Mining Reviews
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 22, 2018
Reviews.text: I bought this Asus ROG Strix OC Gaming RX Vega 64 to replace my aging and failing CrossFired pair of Sapphire Tri-X OC R9 290x's to power a new 32" FreeSync 1440p monitor for gaming, and I am not disappointed. I am getting similar framerates (to ideal CrossFire framerates with my old graphics cards and a 27" 1440p non FreeSync monitor), without the hassle and side effects of CrossFire. A lot of newer and/or upcoming games do not support CrossFire or SLI. The smoothness of a single powerful card paired with adaptive sync is hard to beat, and now I can play the games that didn't support CrossFire with very high to maxed out settings with very smooth game play. This card is very large, larger than the Sapphire Tri-X's being replaced, but quiet and runs fairly cool (around 75 degrees C max after hours of gaming in a well ventilated case) for what it is (a power hungry Vega 64). If you are coming from a setup like mine, it will be a side grade as far as framerates on most well optimized CrossFire supported games, but without the CrossFire stutter, and an upgrade of framerates, pretty much doubled, on the games that don't support CrossFire, and you will only need two 8 pin power connectors instead of four. With or without FreeSync, you will enjoy very smooth gameplay on very high or maximum graphics settings at 1440p with this card. Whether you need to replace an aging graphics card setup, or want to build a new gaming rig with an AMD powered video card (or both), I highly recommend this graphics card, at a reasonable price ($599 was reasonable to me after waiting so long to buy an RX Vega 64 because of the pricing during the first half of 2018). I highly recommend pairing it with a FreeSync monitor as well. You won't regret either decision if you have been waiting to game on a RX Vega 64 and/or a FreeSync monitor.

Reviews.title: ASUS AMD VEGA 64 is amazing and...my first AMD card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2018
Reviews.text:
This GPU is amazing. Very very fast and the build quality is just amazing. I have always used Nvidia GPUs but...i decided this time that i want to try AMD. Man I'm not disappointed. With my freesync monitor i can now enjoy very fluid game play and for a lot less than the Nvidia counterpart. This Asus AMD GPU is just quality! Everything about it is awesome. The only negative i can give is that when the fans are spinning is a bit noisy but you can setup everything with the Asus software so it won't run too loud. To me the noise level is acceptable and...man there's nothing bad to say just wow. I'm really impressed and happy with this GPU. Just 10/10.

Update:
After having the card for more than a month, i can honestly say this card is very very good. I don't know about those reviews that claim VEGA64 is a power hungry card but this VEGA64 from Asus never goes above 195 watts of power usage. I mean doesn't matter what game i through at it it never consumes more than that. And that's even without playing with undervolting the card. So I'll try that another time or simply just keep the card as is. But I'm still in love with this card and my perception of AMD has changed drastically. AMD is a great company and i will happily recommend AMD products to my relatives.

Reviews.title: Vega’s are annoying and way to finiky
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2018
Reviews.text:
I’m having trouble justifying anything higher than 2 stars, and even that is pushing it. I am not going to lie, my card was for mining. I purchased it to fill the 6th slot in my AMD rig. Anyone who’s mined crypto with AMD cards knows how much of a PITA they can be to get running reliably.

At first the new card seemed to work flawlessly with my other 5 (4 Vega 56’s and another ASUS Vega 64). However, each time I would reboot my rig Win 10 Pro would crash each time I would manually restart my Vega’s in device manager. The only thing that would fix it was to boot into safe mode and use DDU to uninstall the drivers and then re-install them after rebooting (I have only had luck with the block chain drivers, the newer ones with compute mode resulted in a large drop in hash rate).

After reinstalling the drivers for the 10th+ time I had my rig running but I noticed what sounded like a fan cycling it’s speed up to 100% and then back down. At first I thought it may be a voltage issue, but I dismissed it because I am running 2 1200w PSU’s (3 cards on each). After investigating I noticed that my new Vega 64s fans would stop and then cycle up to 100%, and then stop. My other Vega 64 wasn’t doing this. This is when I realized that my issues with resetting my Vegas in device manager was probably due to this card being faulty. I have all of my cards set to run a minimum of 3000rpm via OverdriveNTool, so this cards fan should not have been turning off and then on again.

I am in the process of RMA’ing the card. I am probably going to go with a Saphire next, or I may just switch and use Nvidia on both of my rigs.

Major con: Vega’s produce an incredible about of heat.

Reviews.title: Best Price-to-Performance Graphics Card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2018
Reviews.text:
I love AMD, been wanting to upgrade from my RX580. Got it when it was on sale.
I can run Rainbow Six Siege at Ultra settings at1440p (2k) at 120fps and get little to no frame drop. Other games got a huge quality boost.

Pros:
-It can run most games at Ultra at 2K(1440p) over 100fps.
-Looks Great
-Customizable RGB (you can change the colors to match your setup)
-The 3 fans help it run at cooler temps

No Cons for me yet. It is what I expected.
-Bulky (make sure it fits in your case before you buy, I sacrificed 1 HDD slot but I don't really need it)
-You need a minimum of 750psu (power supply unit) if you are going to run at 4K ultra settings
-it is an 8 pin psu connector, RX580 is 6 pin. Make sure you have the right cable for best performance.

My setup
-Asus RX Vega 64
-EVGA 650 80+ gold PSU
-B350 PC mate
-AMD Ryzen 7 1700
-Samsung Evo 860 SSD 500gb
-WD black 2TB HDD

Reviews.title: Great card but not recommended for Sonnet eGFX Breakaway Box 650W or MacOs
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2018
Reviews.text:
On the positive side: The card works as well as any high-end Vega64 - with well managed fan noise and great OC tools (under Windows). It worked flawlessly with both Windows and MacOs but there is no OC support for MacOS - so some of the benefits of this card over the less expensive alternatives are not realized.

My use case: I purchased this to use it with my Sonnet eGFX Breakaway Box 650W - both with MacbookPro and Dell Precision 5520.

The Bad: Fitting this card into the Sonnet box requires removal of the PSU fan form the Sonnet box and very careful installation as the size of the card is significantly larger then the reference AMD design. The side exhaust of the Sonnet enclosure is not designed for 3 fans therefore it limits the effectiveness of cooling - and the less expensive MSI Radeon RX Vega 64 Air Boost 8G OC outperfomed the ASUS card in all benchmark both on PC and Mac due to better thermal management in the Sonnet enclosure.

Bottom line: Great card for WIndows PC, but for Mac in eGPU setting MSI Air Boost is a better choice.

Reviews.title: Cheaper than 1080TI, but just as good for me
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2018
Reviews.text:
The good: Great card at a cheaper price than paying the $400 additional NVIDIA tax ($200 monitor g-sync tax, + $200 more for 1080Ti video card). The difference in performance is not noticeable to me.

Now for the bad: came with an electronic voucher for Farcry 5, but you are forced to install Ubisoft U-play to use it. You cannot redeem the code in Steam, for Ubisoft wants all your personal data. I prefer to give my data to one company, not every single gaming company that wants it or tries to have a Steam competitor...

AMD needs to just give us a CD code in the future, so that we can decide what platform we want to use to install and play the games.

Reviews.title: Bought for Freesync 144hz gaming
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2018
Reviews.text:
Buy this version of the card for the upgraded cooling solution. IMHO the overclocking it not noticeable from a standard Vega 64 card. I don't really care about the LED features of this card.

I bought this card to do 144hz gaming on my freesync display. Does a much better job at 144hz gaming than my prior Radeon card. This is a major upgrade for anyone with a R9 290 or older.

I recommend this card for anyone who wants to stay with 'red team' or already has a freesync display. The 'green team' NV 1080 and later will outperform this -- compare on price and which display tech you pair with. Don't pay more than six hundred for this card.

Watch out for titles like Skyrim that do not operate properly at 144hz. (Problem with game software, not hardware)

Reviews.title: Great buy! Very happy so far.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2019
Reviews.text:
Originally bought an XFX RX 580 8gb card, but after a ton of problems with audio and video cutting out under load (no overclock) I decided to return it and buy this. So happy I did! Had it for about 3 weeks now. It was pretty much plug and play. I put this card in, uninstalled the AMD drivers, installed NVIDIA drivers, and it worked perfect after that. Haven't overclocked at all yet and I'm not sure I will because I'm already getting great performance. In Furmark I'm getting about 106fps at full 1080p. It's also VERY quiet. I play Cities: Skylines a lot and I have large, complex cities with tons of mods and assets and water features that are hard on the entire system, yet I barely hear the fans on this card. Sometimes I will stop playing and check to make sure they're on and they definitely are, just super quiet. Another reason I'm glad I bought this triple fan version. If you have the room in your case, I'd definitely recommend getting this one over any of the two fan versions. Runs much cooler and quieter overall. I will update this review if anything changes, but as of right now I couldn't be happier.

My system:
Thermaltake Core V21 mATX Case
ASRock B365M Phantom Gaming 4 mobo
Intel i5-9400f w/ Cooler Master Hyper 212 Evo CPU cooler
2 x 8gb Corsair Vengeance 2666MHz RAM
This GIGABYTE GTX 1660ti
2 x 250gb Crucial SSDs
1 x 4tb Seagate Barracuda HD
Seasonic 550w FOCUS 80+ Gold PSU

FYI - if you're looking to build a PC or upgrade your existing one, I'd highly recommend all of the components listed above. Very impressed with the price to performance ratio.

Reviews.title: Priced budget, but performs tiers above
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2019
Reviews.text:
I'll admit: I'm not playing the newest of the new games. I don't have a 4K monitor. I'm not trying to push 1727372 fps.

What I am trying to do, however, is play my favorites on the highest settings possible with a steady 60 fps. And this delivers.

I upgraded from an old Radeon R9 280, which was starting to fail. Obviously, it's not going to take much to impress me after that, but considering the 1660 is priced similarly to how that Radeon card was, I'd say it's definitely exceeded expectations.

The 3 fans are super quiet, and keep the card cool while I spend hours logged into FFXIV with max settings. Temps are still nice and low when I play Overwatch on epic settings. Like I said, I'm not playing anything particularly recent, but man do these games look better than ever.

The 1660 is, obviously, considered to be in between the 1000 and 2000 lines. It's a step up from the 1000 architecture, and has many of the same features found in the 2000 line. Not all of course, but this card will affordably bring you into the next age of graphics processing.

So if you aren't obsessed with running the newest games on the highest settings, and don't want to spend a month's worth of rent on a graphics card (I'm looking at you, RTX line), then this card will last you for years.

Reviews.title: Amazing gpu if cant afford/don't need RXT 2060
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2019
Reviews.text:
I decided to upgrade my AMD RX 470 (after a CPU upgrade to Ryzen) and it was a tough decision which Video Card to get. The sapphire RX 590 was on sale for $220 on another site!

The RTX 2060 was also very tempting, but only around 15% more performance for almost $100 more so I picked the GTX 1660 ti. Literally every single 1660 ti was sold out on Amazon except a handful of RGB MSIs ($309) and this Gigabyte 3x fan model ($299).

I am glad looking back, that the $279 models were sold out, because the Gigabyte 3x fan 1660 ti was only $20 more and gives me tons of Overclocking room with it's cooling superiority. Plus cheaper Zotac models usually have fans die years sooner than slightly more expensive models like this.

Extremely happy with my purchase. RTX 2060 would have been nice but the GTX 1660 ti was still around a 65% performance upgrade without even Overclocking yet! Pairs wonderfully with Ryzen 5 2600 and 16gb ram, playing Division 2 with flawless performance, 100fps @ 1080p mostly ultra settings.

Reviews.title: Help! My kids have taken over my PC! I want a turn!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2019
Reviews.text:
Bottom line: All kidding aside, I'm very happy with this purchase.

I'm giving it 4-stars, because the first one I received was defective. The second worked very well. And yes, the PC I installed this card into has become the gaming machine of choice within my house. I'm lucky if I can elbow in an hour or two for myself each week, usually after everyone else goes to bed.

Just to report on the first card that I received. It worked, but there was some issue with the fan control. If the card turned on the fans, it would turn them on at 100% and was very loud. There was no mid-range, only ON or OFF at 100%, no matter the settings. Also, once the fans were turned on, it would not turn them back off without a reboot. I played around with settings for about a week, and finally gave up and requested a replacement. Glad I did, because the second works great.

Reviews.title: This is my second replacement, but EVGA made things right
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2018
Reviews.text: I've bought this card during the mining craze. During this time the tolerance was higher than normal leading to many cards to fail, mine was one of them. I was getting crazy artifacts in games that often ended up with my whole PC crashing. I called up EVGA, the tech support was very friendly and he didn't underestimate my knowledge which was great. Usually these tech support people will treat you like an idiot even if you demonstrate that you know your tech. They sent me a new card quickly and everything was well for a while. A few weeks later the card started showing similar problems, I was starting to think it was something else on my PC. After hours of diagnosing, I came to the conclusion that it must have been the new card EVGA sent me. A bit discourage, I called up EVGA again, they sent me a new card again, and I crossed my fingers hoping it would work. It's been about a year now and so far everything is working as expected. Customer service was top notch even though they didn't get things right the first time.

data.label: ASUS Dual-Fan Radeon Rx 480 4GB OC Edition AMD Gaming Graphics Card with DP 1.4 HDMI 2.0 (DUAL-RX480-O4G)
data.description: Deploy into the VR rebellion with the dual-fan Radeon rx 480 with 1-click overclocking. Auto-extreme manufacturing technology with Super alloy power II components ensures premium quality and reliability while dual fans provide a quieter and cooler gaming environment. Gpu tweak II with XSplit Gamecaster delivers ultimate monitoring and streaming control.

Reviews.title: Great Budget Friendly 1080p Powerhouse
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2017
Reviews.text:
Where to begin with this $200, budget friendly, 1080p powerhouse. At first I was a little apprehensive about going to Radeon. I have owned a GTX 660 and GTX 680 and was very happy with the Nvidia cards. I wanted to upgrade as the GTX 680 was starting to show its age and performance in games was dipping (still playable at lower settings at 60 fps, but I like my games to be pretty). I did my research on the RX 480s and saw mixed reviews on the temperatures and performance from some of the launch models. I chose Asus Dual-Fan edition to hopefully combat the threat of rising temperatures. I am impressed with the way this card handles.

I play a lot of RB6 Siege, Witcher 3, and Fallout 4. I'm able to max the settings at 1080p for these titles and play within 45-60 FPS (most of the times higher than that). The card itself never gets above 60 degrees celcius even when OC'd, which is not very necessary in most scenarios.

I docked one star due to the fact that the Radeon software suite and GPU Tweak tool are just plain aweful compared to the GeForce Experience suite. Wattman is tough to navigate and the various settings are confusing and conflict with in-game graphical settings. I prefer to use MSI Afterburner for any OC needs. Also, another reason for the 4/5 is the noise this card makes when the fans operate at 70% and higher. Sounds like a hair dryer in my machine. There have also been times when the card is showing 30-40 degrees and the fans kick in to 100% for a few seconds...scaring the crap out of me.

I highly recommend this card to anyone who has a budget of ~$200. I don't have any buyer's remorse but I do wonder what would have happened if I went with the GTX 1060, which was my second choice.

Reviews.title: Are you up for a bit of a challenge?
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2016
Reviews.text:
I'm gonna be honest this graphics card has been kind of a pain in the butt. It has some serious throttling issues (well my card anyway) that make it a bit difficult to work with.
It has plenty of power once tuned in right, it's just a pain to get tuned right. On default settings this card runs too hot and throttles too quickly. Asus set the max temperature for throttling to 75C unlike most cards which throttle around 85C so it will throttle at least once every minute creating terrible stuttering. This card also does not reach it's intended clock speed without power target and voltage adjustments. In my experience a carefully tuned overclock and custom fan curve are absolutely necessary to get all of this card's potential.
Once tuned correctly this is a very good card for gaming at 1080p, this can max out any game I throw at it and fly through with 60+ frame rates in pretty much every game I own.
To sum things up, this card has a lot of potential but it takes a little bit of patience and time to get everything you can out of it.
If you have experience overclocking graphics cards and have the time to tweak this to make it work then this is a great card.
If you are more hands off and just want things to work I would not recommend this card, there are other RX470s that do not share the problems that this one carries and would be much more enjoyable for alot of people.
I have gotten to know this card pretty well and honestly enjoy it a lot, it could be that my card is unique and most people will have none of the problems that I've had, but based on my experience I would urge you to be cautious about this card. If you are up for a bit of a challenge in the beginning, then this is an awesome card.

Reviews.title: I think this card would have been perfect had I kept it
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2017
Reviews.text:
I would have given this card 5 stars were it not for the fact that you have to run AMD drivers from ASUS instead of from AMD direct. I had problems with my custom built PC with recovery from sleep mode in Windows 7 64 bit. I spent weeks trying to work it out with ASUS. I have to admit that the ASUS support person I was working with, worked very hard to try and help me resolve the problem. I never was able to really fix it until I replaced my Samsung SSD with a WD SATE HD. So, all this took me over a month to finally resolve. I had sent the card back to ASUS to check out. They found no problem with it. It was ASUS support that informed me not to update this card with AMD drivers direct. I was supposed to use ASUS drivers from their web site instead. While the card was gone, I purchase a slightly better (Sapphire RX480) card to try out.

I decided to keep the Sapphire card and replace the Samsung 840 EVO SSD (my second try with a Samsung SSD - the first one a 960 EVO wouldn't accept Windows 7) with a standard 3GB WD HD. All problems are now resolved.

Finally, and very much to their credit, Amazon gave me a full refund for this card after the normal 30 day return policy was up because of all the hassle I had been having. So, good for Amazon and good for ASUS for working with me to try and resolve the problems I was having. Had I continued using this card without the Samsung SSD, I believe I would have been very happy, not being able to use AMD drivers direct notwithstanding.

Reviews.title: Great graphics card for 1080p gaming
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2016
Reviews.text:
This Asus Dual Rx480 4gb graphics card goes well with my Asus Sabertooth 990fx R2.0 motherboard and FX 8350.
I tested the games and benchmarks below with my CPU at stock 4.0mhz, 16gb DDR3 1333mhz ram and my Asus Dual RX 480 4gb set to OC mode with NO manual adjustment to voltage and power target.
-Dues Ex Mankind Divided: The game ran at 62fps avg 83, max, 40 min on High preset 1080p with no tessellation.
- BF4 with Ultra settings: 1080p my fps was 135 fps.
-Cinebench R15: 90.37 FPS test result in Open GL.
-3D Mark Fire Strike Benchmark for High-performance gaming PC's: graphics score 12418,graphic test 1- 58.33 fps, graphic test 2- 50.26 fps
-3D Mark Skydiver Benchmark for Mid-ranged PC's: graphics score 38934, graphic test 1- 186.00 FPS, graphic test 2- 170.26 FPS
-Heaven Benchmark: 2x Anti-aliasing, 1920x1080 no tessellation, full screen
High quality- 86.7 avg 24.6 min, 159.4 max FPS
Ultra quality- 79.2 avg 25.5 min, 147.5 max FPS
-Valley Benchmark: 2x Anti-aliasing, 1920x1080 full screen
High quality- 68.9 avg, 24.0 min, 112.7 max FPS
Ultra quality- 63.8 avg, 24.4 min, 109.5 max FPS

I am sure with a better and more expensive intel cpu the frame rates would go up. I have not tested any game with my cpu or gpu overclocked from factory presets yet because my monitor can only go as high as 60fps so there is no need when i am getting good results at stock speeds with the games I currently have, but is good to know I can overclock my fx 8350 to 4.8mhz and overclock the GPU if need for a more demanding game.
I also need to say that the 8gb Asus rog strix rx 480 version would be better because games like Dues ex MD and Rise of the tomb raider need more than 4gb vram to run at ultra high settings.
I would recommend this card for anyone that wishes to game in 1080p for sure!!!!!

Reviews.title: If 1080p ultra settings @ 60FPS is your goal, this is your card.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2017
Reviews.text:
This is a good card for 1080p @ 60fps. It can go higher in other games, but some AAA titles known for stressing out cards might go to low 50s fps. GTA V on MAX settings (No MSSA) for example.

Other games like Tomb Raider (2013) can be played at max settings with TressFx @1440p downscaled to 1080p via VSR (AMDs equivalent to Nvidia's DSR.) This can make huge upgrades to last gen games. It feels like a whole new experience. The resolution is so nice, you can barely see jaggies anywhere. So you get to see the benefits of 8GB VRAM right out of the box and it really renews your 1080p monitor experience.

All MAX Settings fps results (no MSSA)
Doom Ultra 60 fps @1440p (vulkan)
Batman: Arkham Knight 55-60 FPS @ 1080p
Batman: Arkham Origins 60 FPS @ 1440p
Dead or Alive 5 LR 60FPS @ 1440p
Metro 2033 Redux 60FPS @ 1080p
Metal Gear Solid V 55-60 FPS @1080p
Mortal Kombat X 60FPS @1440p

4 stars because the global vsync setting does not apply to games and I must manually change it for each game. Nvidia didn't have this issue. Also because anything more than 50% speed is loud as heck. 100% sounds like a jet engine. The card usually doesn't get to 50, but some games that tax the card with bad optimization will make the fans blow high.

Reviews.title: Severe Throttling Issues
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2016
Reviews.text:
This card performs well as long as you don't ask too much of it and you have decent ventilation in you computer.

Here's a few things I wish I had known before I purchased it:
1. The card will throttle when it goes over 75°C. This is far too low of a temperature. It drops the card's speed down to 300mhz and your games will drop down to 10fps.
2. The card will overheat with any sort of overclocking. Don't listen to the other reviews here about needing to overclock it to get it to run well. It WILL overheat and it WILL throttle, unless you're liquid cooling maybe.
3. When you get the card, just run it on the "gaming" setting to test it. If you have problems with throttling then either increase the fan speed or underclock it a little bit. It sucks but that's the best way to get it to run stably.
4. If you are trying to get max performance and overclock it, choose a different card. The MSI rx470 seems to be much better for overclocking.

I'm surprised Asus made the decisions they did when producing this card. 75° is way too low of a temp cut off.

All that being said, the card works very well when it's running properly. It's silent, has a miniscule power draw, and I'm getting 40-50 fps on games like the Witcher 3 on ultra settings. Just be warned, don't try to push it too far!

EDIT: I dropped a star Since writing this review. I have been in contact with ASUS, and much has changed with the card.

ASUS refused to recognize there was a throttling issue with the card. Despite their assurances below, they are not here to help. They are here to keep you from besmirching their "good" name.

They released an update that "addressed" their throttling issue. It sure did. The throttling issue is now gone. In it's place is a complete system shut-down. Once under heavy load the computer will just auto shut-off. I initially suspected it was a problem with my PSU. After replacing that, and the problem still persisting, I swapped out the GPU and voila, problem solved. The GPU I switched it out to has HIGHER power requirements.

ASUS is flailing about trying to fix their poor engineering, and we are paying the price. This card is going back. Look at those 5 Star reviews. They all read like they were written right after installation, no? Trust my advice and stay away. This is not the card to support.

Reviews.title: Another Coil-Whine Free Asus Card 5-stars
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2016
Reviews.text:
Great Upgrade from a Asus AMD RX 270, basically 100% upgrade for me.
Went from being able to barely run games at half quality settings at 2560x1440 and getting fps below 60 dips.
To being able to max them and still get 60fps+ and ontop of it all freesync now actually works with my monitor where it did not with the RX270, so even more gain there when it does dip below 60. WIN WIN WIN.
Could not be happier with this card.

But why did I choose this over the cheaper RX470's from Sapphire or MSI when they are for the same price and also come with 8gb of vram??...
Well Asus wasn't selling them, and I did not want to deal with the DREADED COILWHINE BUZZ, you see ASUS actually re-engineers the power delivery structure that cause this on other brands and they don't use the worst caps\vrm's for it either which most other brands use low tier ones.

You don't have to worry about coil whine much with Asus cards basically, but unfortunately ASUS was not selling a RX 470 8gb that was cheaper then the RX480 4gb they were selling. So I got this, and I am not disappointed as it is faster then a 470 by a bit.

Be-live me it doesn't matter how fast a Card is, if you have to put up with a LOUD high pitch buzzing sound that never goes away.
Don't want to sound like a fanboy but really, Just get an Asus card, stay away from the other brands that use the reference designs for power delivery none of the others give a dang about it use low tier caps\vrms! And give them dumb names to make them sound quality and its a crapshoot if you get a card that whines or not with the other brands.

Reviews.title: Great buy!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2017
Reviews.text:
Great Card, Asus Dual RX480 08G, great deal, got it overnight Free on Prime on *Saturday*! Big step up from my former MSI R9 380 4GB...which was a great card for the last 18 months or so...it now goes to the wife...who is ecstatic (she doesn't game quite like me, etc.) I liked this model because it wasn't cartoony or gaudy looking, and the light-gray-silver cover is simple, clean, and elegant looking. (I get tired of all the garish red/black GPU enclosures that look rather monotonous after awhile--just my personal taste.)

I would advise, however, to simply skip using the Asus Tweak II control software for the card. MSI Afterburner 4.3 is much better and supplies features the Asus software doesn't--with much better fan profiles and so on. (Make sure you use 4.3, however, as it's the version of AB designed for the RX 480. Earlier version may work but some features may not--so go with 4.3.) Other than that, great card! Also, after first uninstalling your previous GPU drivers, then installing the RX 480 card physically, and upon first boot to Windows, install the Crimson 17.2.1 software from the AMD site--ie, don't use the driver set included on the DVD as it's way out of date! With those few, simple caveats--enjoy, it's a great product!
Running Win10x64 Insider's build 15048.

Reviews.title: Quiet and powerful for 2560x1080
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2016
Reviews.text:
This card looks great, runs extremely quiet, and performs well in any game you want to play. In order to reach it's advertised 1206 MHz core clock, you'll have to do some quick and easy tuning to the card, although it doesn't help in every situation.

Due to ASUS limiting the GPU's default voltage, you'll have to go into WattMan settings and adjust the Power Limit (%) slider to at least 15%; allowing the GPU to reach its 1206 MHz clock under load. For some reason, doing so brought instability and crashing while playing Overwatch. This seems to be a problem on Overwatch's side, although I can't be certain that this won't persist in other titles as well.

So, at the end of the day this GPU will probably play your games well, and will do so quietly. Unfortunately, tweaking the settings in order to get the advertised performance that you paid for may not work in your favor. I'd highly recommend going for another another Rx 470, such as the MSI Gaming version for $10 more.

Reviews.title: Amazing 1080p Card!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2016
Reviews.text:
I am loving this card! Every single game I play can easily run at 1080p Ultra @ 60FPS. Some of the older titles at even higher frame rates than that. That being said in order to pull that off you do need to go into the Wattman software or the included ASUS Gpu tweak II software and raise the power limit by 50%, Its very easy to do and it keeps the card at a stable 1270Mhz, If you leave the power target as it is the card will throttle down to around 1150mhz so its very important to change that setting. The card is very quiet under load and silent at idle so I have no complaints there. The temps are also very good, My card stays at a steady 50 Celsius at idle (26c Ambient Temp) and at 65c under load.

Pros:
- It's Quiet
- Runs at great temperatures
- Excellent performance for the price

Cons
- Will not keep advertised 1270mhz clock speed out of the box (thought it can be easily fixed with included software)

As a side note I am currently pairing this with a FX-6300 Clocked in at 4.3Ghz any CPU worse than this will affect your Framerate as my processor already bottlenecks the card in some games I tested.

Reviews.title: Dead on arrival
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2020
Reviews.text:
Stay away from this one! Mine showed up with tons of cracks in the water block. There are 2 layers of plexi-glass and the cracks were on the bottom of the inside layer, so I thought it was some aesthetic choice from EVGA. I hooked it up in my water loop and the card wouldn't display anything. I spent hours trying different cables, different monitors, and different settings, but nothing worked. I finally disconnected it and contacted EVGA, who told me those cracks are not by design. I have no clue how they came to be, perhaps EVGA's production line is to blame for over tightening the screws?
I called EVGA and apparently now I'm waiting for them to approve a return. I have to ship the card to them, wait for them to get it, wait for them to process it, wait for them to ship it back, and then pray the replacement works. I spent so much time on this and that answer is so disappointing....plus with the cracks in the water block I could have fried my entire system easily.
Bad design, bad assembly or bad shipping practices created this problem. Adding a layer of bad service after is just the icing on the cake. I'd advise looking at the other brands if you value your time and/or computer.

Reviews.title: Leaked upon arrival
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2020
Reviews.text: Luckily amazon's customer service is top notch. Got it all hooked up and after running just my water pump for 10 mins I started seeing water "on the right side" of the water block - no where near the fittings. Continually dried it and discovered it was leaking around where the block contacts the card - but the fittings were definitely bone dry. Amazed is sending a replacement super fast - but certainly disappointed with EVGA's quality control. Not many have bought these and to have this level of failure is pretty disappointing. Maybe pay the guy sealing the blocks to the card more than 5 bucks an hour?

Reviews.title: Absolutely LOVE it. But ONE small issue!

Sometimes a few colors fail to register and will show up white. Red, blue and orange mostly. I have to pop off the side panel and wiggle the wire right where it connects to the LED's to get it working again. It's a pain. Reviews.title: HD5770s and 6770s never came with 4GB of VRAM! AVOID!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2022
Reviews.text:
The vast majority of HD6770s did not come with a VGA port. The real ones also require a 6-pin power connector. Most cards that have an output layout like this are fake and, seeing reviews from people saying it won't run DX11, I'm inclined to believe this isn't even a 6770 as those did run DX11. The listed clock speed is about 200mhz lower than the original cards which, at best, points to these being faulty cards flashed with a different BIOS to operate at a lower clock speed. HD 5770s and 6770s (same card with 2 names) also NEVER came with 4GB of VRAM.

Again, this points to this being a card with a fake BIOS. I've tested another faked GPU claiming to be a GTX 960 4GB and the card even reported itself as such to the computer. In actuality it was a GT640 with 1GB of VRAM. When a game would try to utilize the reported 4GB of VRAM that didn't exist, it would cause the computer to crash.

Best case scenario here, you get a GPU that was originally released in 2009 (as the 5770, again, identical to the 6770...AMD just renamed the same card 2 years later) which has not received driver support since 2015, running at 76% of it's original speed (which may be how it gets away without a 6 pin power connector...but I doubt it) and have to spend some time dialing in settings to avoid games using more than 1GB of VRAM so the computer won't crash. In other words KEEP SHOPPING!

Reviews.title: I NEEDED A CARD TO CRUISE AROUND THE INTERNET WITHOUT ISSUE AND THIS IS IT!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2022
Reviews.text:
I just needed a basic video card to cruise around the internet without being stifled by lame performance of a cheap video card. While this card is a tad expensive it is not priced at the ridiculously insane prices of the middle to high end gaming video cards in 2022. This GPU has done the job of letting me go anywhere on the internet without video lag.

I had a more expensive NVIDIA GPU in my system with otherwise state of the art hardware. The newest most power Ryzen 9 \ 5900 CPU, fast memory and a 750 watt power supply. The NVIDIA GPU ran like hot garbage on my Ubuntu system. Ubuntu has a nasty sepia color scheme that saturates the entire OS and everything in it. It is not only ugly but painful to look at due to my vision issues.

I did not know for sure at the time but, I hoped a new video card from someone other than NVIDIA might perform better. Turns out this AMD designed GPU got rid of the nasty sepia tint. This video card creates a simple un-tinted OS that is a pleasure to use. The card is not BIG and uses only the power supplied by the GPU slot.

The card has some energy saver garbage installed that turns the card off if you power down your monitor. I took a star off for the energy saver mess. There really are no other issues. This is a great card to use on a Linux\Ubuntu system that is not used for hard core gaming.

Reviews.title: It does what I needed it to do
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2022
Reviews.text:
At my workplace I needed this half-height graphics card for a PC running a graphics intensive application that was practically unusable using the on-board graphics on the PC. Installing this card resolved the performance issues. I was pleased enough with that purchase that I bought one for my home computer to resolve some lag issues when playing 4K video on my old PC. This card resolved that issue, too. I don't know how this product benchmarks against the completion. I didn't do any testing like that. I simply had performance issues with applications that needed a graphics card performance boost. The price was right on this graphics card and I found that it worked fine to resolve those issues.

The only issue that I had was that the package came with no English instructions, no drivers and no software. I am an IT technician by trade, so I had little trouble finding the right drivers and software online. On one PC, Windows Update found the drivers, but I still had to download and install the correct version of the Radeon software. On the other PC I had to download both the drivers and software. So, this wasn't much of a problem for me, but it may be more than a novice PC users can deal with.

This product did what I needed and I've had no problems with it either at home or at work. It gets a 5 star rating from me even though I would have expected better instructions for installing the product and obtaining the correct drivers & software.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on August 29, 2022
Reviews.text:
Diese Grafikkarte ist absolout NICHT VR fähig ! Wer VR möchte MUSS mehr investieren !

Dennoch möchte ich diese Grafikkarte einmal für ihre erstaunliche und herausragende Leistung loben.
Hier hat MAXSUN alles richtig gemacht!

Ich habe einen Rechner mit ordentlich Leistung und natürlich auch mit einer entsprechenden Grafikkarte um damit die Valve Index VR-Brille zu betreiben. Ich bekam ein ausrangiertes Fujitsu Esprimo C710 mit USB3.0 und einem betagten aber ausreichenden Prozessor und suchte nun nach einer Low Profile Grafikkarte, die dabei auch noch schlank und bestmögliche Leistung bringen sollte.

Mein verrückter Plan:
Wenn an meinem Rechner was abraucht, sollte der kleine Esprimo das Ganze überbrücken.
Mit 32GB RAM und der MAXSUN Radeon RX 550 ist mir das sehr gut gelungen.
Wir reden hier natürlich von minimalistischen Grafikeinstellungen ABER BeatSaber, Phasmophobia (SinglePlayer), Pistol Whip und Blade & Sorcery sind durchaus spielbar und die Karte wird dabei nicht übermäßig heiß. Half Life - Alyx hingegen lagt sehr deutlich (wie es auch zu erwarten ist)

Dies ist keine Kaufempfehlung für VR, es soll aber verdeutlichen, was die kleine Karte auf dem Kasten hat.
Denn hier schlägt sie die vergleichbare GT 1030 um längen. Für Titel wie Diablo III und Co ifinde ich die RX 550 völlig in Ordnung und sie macht dort auch eine echt gute Figur.

Fazit: Es gibt natürlich deutlich stärkere Grafikkarten, egal ob AMD oder NVIDIA aber wer bei dem aktuellen Auf und Ab der Grafikkartenpreise eine günstige und verhältnismäßig starke Grafikkarte sucht, weil er sich gerade keine große leisten kann oder wie bei mir für einen kleineren Zweitrechner, sollte hier gut bedient sein.

Wir zocken wenig wenn dann Strategiespiele, Autorennen usw eine unserer Anforderungen war die Grafik entscheidend zu verbessern ohne Unmengen Geld zu investieren. Also neuer Monitor, Grafikkarte und ein zusätzlicher Speicherblock. Das Ergebnis kann sich mehr als sehen lassen!!!
Kein geruckel mehr und eine schön saubere Grafik, das beste die Grafikkarte wird bei uns nicht mal warm, läuft also alles sauber. Für 160€ kann man bei der Karte nichts verkehrt machen!

Reviews.title: A solution to a problem.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2022
Reviews.text:
A family member had their monitor burn out and a 4K monitor was bought. Sadly, the built-in video card in the older computer was not strong enough to support the max resolution.

This video card did exactly that. And it is fine for a computer that is used for surfing, basic desktop work, etc. But once you want to watch a full-screen 4K video it struggles. Badly.
To be fair here, the 10-series were not built for 4K. But it needs to be said: it is one thing to do static work on 4K resolutions; once you go to a high-quality media display this is not the card you are looking for.

So this card does what it needs to do - and it will perform fine for most things in resolutions under 4k. It is affordable and available. But don't buy this one for high-quality gaming or intensive video or animation work.
