Reviews.title: If you can get it for MSRP...it will amaze!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2016
Reviews.text:
First off, I would like to say DO NOT buy the Founders Edition GTX 1080 for anything other than the MSRP ($700) There is no reason to, and just wait it out until you are able to get it for the MSRP or look to a different edition. However, having owned it for about a week now and having paid the MSRP I will not just give it a 1 star just for the jacked up prices as others have already done so to ward people away from overspending.

This card is an absolute beast in almost all aspects. I upgraded from an SLI GTX 970 and its outperforming those by far. I play on a 1440p monitor and its absolutely OVERKILL at that resolution. 60+ FPS on all games highest settings, (currently playing Overwatch, Warhammer, Witcher 3, GTA V) The reason I upgraded is because with the two 970 SLI I couldn't take full advantage of my 1440p monitor and I plan on doing future upgrades to 4k as well as a second build.

The Pascal Architecture seems to be a wonderful change. I don't know how it works but while I'm playing games at 1440p max settings, the card flickers between 70-71C after hours of gaming(WHICH IS AWESOME!), and despite playing in a hot room when I want to save money on the electric bill and keep the AC off. I planned to put a water block on it and keep it that much cooler before receiving the card but right now there's no need for it. Playing at the resolutions and settings I'm at. As for 4k I have no personal experience but check out reviewers on youtube. It seems that this card at 4k resolution is playing games such as Doom at the high settings at about 40-55 fp. However the temps with the Founders Edition seem to be into the low-mid 80'sC , at least from what I've read and seen. Still a good look for future video cards.

The temps are also while the GPU is overclocked to 2025Mhz Core clock and 5500 Memory Clock, I may be able to achieve 2.1k Mhz but haven't been able to thus far. The boost clock says into the 1700's Mhz but mine definitely boost into the 1800Mhz on it's own, for those who don't overclock. Which brings me to my next point. 2k+ Mhz, which is pretty awesome and easy to achieve with this card. From what I've read the community is trying to achieve over 2.1Mhz Core clock but even with the custom cooled cards they haven't been able to. (At least from what I've read! I could be wrong as I haven't possibly seen or read everything!) But 2k Mhz is still something to be happy with in my opinion. Again these temps are with these clocks at 1440 p resolution.

The Founders Edition looks beautiful. I like the look but some may be more inclined with a custom cooled card that matches their rig better. This was asked before but being sold from Zotac, the card does not have Zotac logos or colors on it from what I've seen. If it does then it really hidden. The 8pin power connector that came with this Zotac edition was yellow hoever. Not sure if that's the standard or just Zotac. The FE GTX 1080 is only an 8 pin power connector however I haven't seen too much evidence of it being an issue. Also there is a backplate included on the card. At first I was disappointed that it was plastic. However the card is pretty heavy at least compared to my 970s and a metal backplate may have made it heavier.

Now onto the bad. The temps are wonderful on this card (not a high 4k settings) however the fan is LOUD at the higher fan speeds. And I mean L-O-U-D. This doesn't bother me as I usually have my headset on, speakers playing music, and I personally am able to drown the sound out so it doesn't bother me. But for people who this matters to I assure you that it will bother you because again it is LOUD. If this is a big deal to you I'd recommend looking at a custom cooled version of the card.

The biggest issue I had and I've seen on some forums is its compatibility with Windows 10. When I first put the card to use, the PC recognized it, however I kept getting an issue saying that the GPU drivers were not compatible with my version of Windows 10. After a few hours of frustration and research I found that my Windows didn't update to the version 1151 when the update was put out a few months ago. So if you're on Windows 10 you will have to update to that version if you haven't already or the drivers won't work!

At 1080p and 1440p this card is overkill. At 4k this is still a beast from what I've read and seen just worry about the temps. It was worth the price of $700 for me at least. Look to the customed cooled cards if they're available if you want for sure but as far as performance it seems that they perform similarly despite the added cooling. You may even wait for a possible gtx 1080 ti if that comes out this year. Just know you won't go wrong with this card!. Hope this helps someone!

Reviews.title: ZOTAC GeForce GTX 1080 AMP! Extreme: Amplified Excellence!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2016
Reviews.text:
I ordered this product before the release date for $875 and asked for an earlier ship date from a third-party seller, Brandon addinton, and received the product of this electrifying video card days after the release. A huge more than double the upgrade from the EVGA GeForce GTX 970 FTW ACX 2.0! Literally, you may need some extra space in your case if you can't detach your hard drive case to move it to another slot.

This monster, this beast will destroy anything from the old titles to new titles you throw at this card!

Don't forget for most users and Windows 10 PRO: Set the TDR Delay registry (Google if you must) to 10 seconds for this card for optimization. A signal is sent to the GPU checking if the drivers are working properly, normally, if the GPU does not respond within 2 seconds, the PC will shut down. Don't listen to crappy reviews over the AMP! Extreme not being able to overclock, as I've got quite the high stable clock with my specifications I listed a ways below in this review. At least on par or a better clock than the Founder's series and MUCH, cooler with this custom model.

With my full air cooling setup as listed in reference below, with a Summer ambient temp of 42C at most, the heavily overclocked GPU can run a maximum of 30C-61C, maximum being the most intensive computing. Averages of 30C-50C. I ran Asus RealBench with temps between 30C-45C. The card has silence as described, the card has an easy program to use called Firestorm to use as described and meets beyond what the boost clock says, I can reach 2088MHz stable load. I play in 1080p for extra GPU rendering, but easily this card will have excellence in 4K and definitely worth making SLI. The card will not disappoint you for years, this is my 100% honest review with pictures from my Samsung Tab S.

Reviews.title: Best 1080 on the market
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2016
Reviews.text:
This is a fantastic card, but like most cards, it is not without issues...

Firstly it does get hot under high stress and you will need to adjust the fan speed manually to keep it running optimally, but even under full utilization of the card, it does not exceed 65*C in my rig, which is a very high airflow rig.

UPDATE: I have now had this card for 7 months still going strong, I have upgraded my PSU and Case fans since and my whole rig is pretty silent, under 20dBA by my guess. (Seasonic Prime 850W PSU, dead silent, Corsair ML140 fans set to 800RPM, dead silent) So when I changed out these fans I noticed that this card does have an extremely annoying problem which may or may not bother some users, but at idle (under 30% load or so) the fans will spin up hard (much more than necessary) and stop in a cycle which is extremely annoying. This is easily fixed with a custom fan profile, I like MSI: Afterburner so I use that. You MUST keep the fans at least at 30% to keep the spin up cycle from happening. Mine is set to be at 30% until 39C and then it spins up at the same percentile as the degree number. With the profile set like that my card very rarely goes over 55C and is barely audible with headphones on, without phones it gets a little annoying. The fans ARE NOT audible until about 50% or so, if you can manage to keep the fans speeds under that level without the temp going over 65C you will be very happy.

The second, and only real issue is that this card is MASSIVE, it WILL require you to buy or rig a brace, there is a risk of damaging the PCI-e slot on your motherboard without it.

All that being said this card is fantastic and I have not had a single major problem with it so far, it runs almost everything at maxed out settings at 3440x1440 @100Hz resolution, save extremely GPU heavy games, but that speaks more of the chip and the overclock than anything.

The RGB lighting is limited but very nice and the monster card adds a little bit of awe to my rig.
The yellow stripe is a huge distraction from my otherwise Blue, Black, and Silver scheme.

As much as I love Zotac and the AMP! Extreme edition I am not 100% sure I will upgrading to the 1080 Ti version if these problems persist in the 1080 Ti AE, other manufacturers seemed to have step up their game significantly and I think I would sacrifice 1-3 fps for a card that will run cooler and quieter, even if it doesn't look as great in my rig. As far as looks goes Zotac still has the best looking card for the 1080 Ti.

Reviews.title: Super expensive, but a fantastic card.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2016
Reviews.text:
The GTX 1080 and specifically the Zotac Founders Edition are what you would expect from one of the fastest consumer graphics cards in existence.

Firstly, Founders Edition cards including this one are built like a battleship. They are heavy, have a stylized look with glowing lights and the construction is top notch. The card is somewhere in the middle when it comes to noise from the fan, and it is a single blower fan. This is totally fine for most players who aren't overclocking. I personally put this card in a small Mini ITX case and have no plans for overclocking with such limited space for cooling. You can expect this card to throttle as most modern graphics cards are tuned to throttling at certain temps, so overheating should be difficult on the 1080 unless your wiring and air ventilation is extremely poor.

Nvidia has generally very easy software to install to manage the card drivers, and they'll also give you their recommended settings for the games you have installed on your PC. I find this feature doesn't work all of the time. Nvidia's driver stability from the 970 to the 1080 has largely been a positive experience, compared to the AMD cards before it. You pay a premium but get a premium experience in return.

Performance of the card is so good that it's largely dependent on the quality of the PC developer if you're going to crush the settings. World of Warcraft on Ultra drops to 40FPS, but Witcher 3 runs at 144fps or higher if I uncapped it at 1080p. Basically the skies the limit and software optimization now needs to catch up with Pascal's new architecture. The 1080 is absolutely great with Oculus Rift games, including Elite Dangerous, which runs steady at 90FPS with VR settings on high (and some simple supersampling tricks). If you're taking VR seriously, the 1080 is probably right where you want to be for demanding games. Lastly it should be future proof, as in you should easily have this card for 2 years without feeling an urge to go out and upgrade. Graphics enhancements are slowing down, so I expect improvements to be pretty gradual going forward.

This is the card for VR/1440p monitors, but I'm still not convinced anything is really capable of running 4k at the performance I want. I don't think 4K gaming is really going to be up to my standards for another 2 years or so.

So yes, this is highly recommended. It's insanely expensive, but it's a large jump and you'll have it for a long time in computer gamer years.

Reviews.title: Excellent. PROs
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2016
Reviews.text:
Excellent.

PROs:
Super fast our of the box. If you do not need to "compete" for OC, you don t really need to touch this card at all. It delivers outstanding performance just after install. No need for special knowledge, is a real "Plug 'n Play"
In regard of OC I made a few tests and more about it later. Stock is 2075 on core. So far I was able to get it steady at 2122 but is not the cap yet, I could push it forward, just don t know if i really wanna do it :)

CONs:
It is only on the OC software. Firestorm is really behind Afterburner. Yoou need it mostly for the lights settings, but then fortunately, Afterburner can perfectly work on setting the card. I didn t try OC using AB but i use AB to set a custom dynamic range for the fans, which works way better than the same option on Firestorm.
Card is HUGE, not everyone can possibly set it in SLI, need to check your MB slots first to ensure they have the correct distance
It is expensive, but you get what you pay for.

OTHERS:
I guess I was lucky on the OC lottery. This card seems to be very OCable. However you have to monitor carefully what you are doing. Around 54 degrees it will throttle down and between 49 and 54 degrees it may throttle down because of voltage, therefore you need to add a bit of a juice there. So far I scored a 3029 on Heaven 4 and I am REALLY satisfied.
If you are crazy enough to get a Liquid cooler for this thing and then be able to keep it below 53 degrees, this thing can really hit the Sky. However, if you wanna do that, you don t need to get this card, a Founder Edition would already work for you, considering you have to apply a liquid cooler on it.

It is expensive, my previous card died prematurely, i was hoping to get to a 1080 Ti but didnt make it. I think this is the closest thing I could get to a future Ti. I do not know when the Ti will be available, i know it will be better than this but I don t think by too much (for this card comparison) so, if you have the budget, just get it.

Reviews.title: The ArcticStrorm is an absolute gorgeous BEAST!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2017
Reviews.text: First of all this is my first ZOTAC product but given their good track record, I wasn't at all hesitant. I usually like to add my own aftermarket watercooling blocks as about 90% of my system is EKWB. But I found this on sale over Christmas so I sold my R9 Fury X with a custom EK waterblock and ordered this to replace it. My standards for quality components and how I want them to look is pretty high. Having said that, Let me tell you that the pictures come nowhere near doing this thing justice. It is absolutely stunning in person and the craftsmanship more than meets my standards. And when I say in the title that its a Beast,. this thing can overclock like crazy and yes it also weighs a TON so be prepared to deal with it sagging. I am running a FurMark stress test in the background as I am typing this review. I have it at +200 Core clock and +1000 Memory clock and the temps are maxing out at 48c.. yeah.. 48c. Thats NUTS! I can push the Core clock +100 further but at minimal performance gain so why bother. This GPU is everything I had hoped for. I have always considered myself a bargain shopper with my PC but still wanting to get top end components. I usually wait 6 months plus till prices come down etc. I did what most AMD GPU fans did and waited, and waited, and waited for RX VEGA. Of course it turned out to be a flop and way overpriced. So I started to shop around for GTX 1070s and 1080s because they seemed like the best options. Sure not everyone has that $500+ GPU budget and I usually don't give in either. But I have to say that after swallowing hard and spending the big money it is so worth it. This GPU is beautiful and runs super cool and I finally have a Graphics Card that can do 60+ FPS at 4K.

Reviews.title: LED/Spectra issues
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2016
Reviews.text:
I've been using this graphics card to run my 50" Sony 4k tv to play world of warcraft. I run custom settings but for the most part everything on ultra or high, I do not use any AA settings and keep view distance and detail @ #7. The card get's a solid 52-60 FPS with v-sync on to prevent over 60fps as the screen only runs 4x4x4 Chroma and 60hz with A HDMI (this screen has no display port) using HDMI cable. I run resolution in 4k otherwise this card powerfully blazes through 1080P paired with Intels I7 4790k. I'm running a Alphacool custom loop with one 60mm thick 360mm rad, and dual Alphacool VP655 pumps. The Articstorm card runs stable, smooth and never even gets as hot as the CPU for the most part.

*Reason I knocked stars*
1. I do not like Zotac's software, the program you use to control the LED's and over clocking. It has the options and functions but forgive me for saying so it's not visually appealing to me what so ever.

2. When I originally got the card all of the LED colors work but not all of them it's a strange issue.
-Red Works
-Yellow Works
-Green Works
-Light Blue ( doesn't work, it just illuminates green.)
-Dark Blue (doesn't work, it sometimes will flicker on but for most part I get no color at all)
-Pink (doesn't actually turn pink just stays solid red, like the 1st red option on spectra)
-White (works, but doesn't because it's actually turning on something in between green/yellow)

The spectra really bugs me, I paid over $750 dollars and the one color I really liked that matches my system (blue) doesn't work. I've tried contacting Zotac and they said try reinstalling firestorm. But I know it's obviously an issue specific to certain colors and the card needs repair. Unfortunately it's my only system and they don't offer a quick service to repair the card in a timely manner. I'd be without a system for weeks or months and for me that's not an option.

So the card is working well it self, but having the spectra fail, and not having a system in place for cross shipping, or a faster warranty repair solution I may not invest in Zotac again.

Reviews.title: Reverted AMD fan - this new GTX 1080 is BEAST.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2016
Reviews.text:
After an exhaustive search online - I finally came across this Zotac GTX 1080 in stock. I was not real sure about the Zotac brand as I have
always been a loyal EVGA fan. Well since I needed this video card to complete my new PC build I went ahead and jumped on this opportunity. I have had this card installed now for 3 days and cannot be happier about the speed and performance of this Founders Edition card. Just last night I downloaded and installed MSI AfterBurner Beta software and was able to get a very stable overclock on this card at 2087mghz. I then played the new Doom on max settings and this thing never dropped below 60fps. The temperatures never got over 74c and this card is a beast. I also put on some GTA V all on max settings and again this card doesn't even flinch at anything I throw at it. After having this card for a few days and being in the IT industry for 20yrs I can without a doubt refer family and friends that this card is worthy of all the hype. Yes I paid the extra $100 over MSRP to get my hands on this card early and I don't regret it at all. This card was worth every penny and I highly recommend this to anyone looking for the best video card to date in my opinion. Also to add I ran a Benchmark on this card right out of the box and I was getting 1911mghz which is well over the advertised base clock on the Reference cards. I can add some screen shots on request if anyone is interested in my overclock on this stock reference card from Zotac.

Reviews.title: this card is great. Overclocked very easily
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2016
Reviews.text:
Going to keep this short and brief. First of all, the negative reviews are from people who didn't buy the card. They are from people who were upset by the pricing. Secondly, this card is great. Overclocked very easily. 2055 on the core and 5500 on memory @ 75% fan at all time. Can barely hear it and temps never go above 75 degrees. Playing Doom 4K maxed on Ultra settings, and also been playing Battlefield 4 on Ultra @ 4K as well as Crysis on Ultra settings @ 4K. This card handles everything you throw it at. Also handles VR with my HTC Vive beautifully. No issues at all. This card is insane and I am so glad I got it. The card also looks great in my case. You can definitely get board partner cards for cheaper than this, but the Founder's Editions have been in stock more than the partner cards as of now and in my opinion look better. If you want a card sooner than later buy this card, but if you can wait I would definitely wait for a partner cards especially if you don't plan on overclocking at all since they tend to come with higher base frequencies.

Reviews.title: I don't think this is the best 1080!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2017
Reviews.text:
I regret this card!
First of all, You should know this card has an issue: When this card has a load under 30% the fan will spin at full speed for 1 second and stop and will repeat the process a second later and you can hear the noise! (All Zotac Extreme Edition has this issue replacing the card won't change that)
You can work around that issue with Manual or Advance modem instead of the Auto but it's not a perfect solution as it has its own issues!
It seems like it's not stable, the reason I am saying that is with the same games same intense sometimes the card is working correctly with low noise and at other times it has high noise (I am playing the Witcher 2!!! not 3).
Also weirdly enough when I played Diablo 3 on Nvidia 1080 it gave me a steady 100FPS on my 34" Ultrawide monitor 1440x3440 when I played the same game with the same setting on the Zotac 1080 it was giving me between 70-90FPS!!! I don't understand since the Zotac extreme 1080 should be an overclocked version of the same Nvidia card (Now to be fair, I didn't spend enough time to compare between the two cards and find out if there is a reason for that or not!)
The first card I received had an issue with the LED light I had to replace it and the second one the LED was good!

It still a good card but since I just spend a ton of money to get a silent desktop I think there is other better option.
Don't do my mistake, don't base your judgment only on the base and boost speed as I did!

I hope my review help others toward their goals
Best of Luck guys

Reviews.title: Great card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2019
Reviews.text:
This is one of the best cards for folks that have a weak power supply or those who have to (God Forbid) run the 6-pin power connector off of a SATA power adapter...

The cards drinks the LEAST power from the SATA line of all the mid-high end cards and will not fry your power supply if you use a high quality SATA to 6-pin adapter.

So if you have a prebuilt system with an underpowered PSU (~300 watt) like an HP, Lenovo or Dell, this is your best option. If you don't have at least ~280 watt, then you should take a good look at the GTX 1050 TI which draws only 75 watts.

Reviews.title: Tom's Hardware forum sucks
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2020
Reviews.text:
I recently upgraded my rig to running 4 monitors, but found out I couldn't run my vr headset unless I unplugged a monitor. I had already been considering an upgrade, so I went to Google to check which GPU would meet my needs. According to Google, Tom's Hardware forums said that this would support 5 monitors, but after lots of struggle to install this gpu, I was disappointed to find that was wrong. I browsed the actual forum page I originally looked at, and it didnt mention 5 monitors anywhere.

This isnt the fault of Zotac, but either Google or Tom's Hardware forums. Overall, the gpu holds up great for gaming, and I'm not upset with the actual product's performance (I am a bit with installation but that's because of my case). I just wish I had gotten what I hoped for.

Reviews.title: 3GB Card Was Spotless, 6GB Card Less So.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2019
Reviews.text:
I ordered two of these Zotac 1060 Minis, one for my own PC and the other to help a friend complete his first build. I ordered the 6GB card, he had me order a 3GB card.

The 3GB came clean to a point I could hardly tell it was renewed. I saw no dust on the fan or heatsink, and was pleasantly surprised with QC...until I saw the 6GB card.

There was a night and day difference between the 3GB and 6GB cards. The 6GB had dust on the fan blades and heatsink, as well as the bracket where the video outputs are. Nothing that can't be cleaned, but makes me concerned about recommending someone order this if the condition is hit or miss.

Reviews.title: Great Card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2021
Reviews.text: Bought this for my first PC build, so far I haven’t found a game that it has trouble running. Solid card for a low/midrange build

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on July 19, 2022
Reviews.text:
I bought this card because I wanted to upgrade from a gtx 1080 ti. I've been using this card for a few years now, and even with Rtx's on the market, I still don't see an immediate need to upgrade yet. This card has been able to handle any game I throw at it and play them at ultra settings.

Having said that, the 4gb vram is beginning to feel a bit limiting and I wouldn't mind experiencing that Rtx lighting. Still, if you're looking for a mid range graphics card that will allow you to play most games released in the last several years at a reasonable price, you can't go wrong with this one.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on September 7, 2020
Reviews.text:
I bought this to upgrade the GPU in my Linux machine running Ubuntu 20.04. It's used for a bit of gaming (Kerbal Space Program runs wonderfully with all the highest detail settings on now) but mostly for GPU-based calculations on BOINC tasks.

The GPU computing part is the most important reason I went for this over the overclocked variety - some tasks are a but funny with overclocked GPU's. It runs 24/7 at as near to full capacity as I can make it. At that load, the fans on the card can't be heard over the PSU and CPU/RAM fans, so I'd say they're quiet enough for my purposes. In terms of real-world performance of the GPU for calculations, I have a PrimeGrid task for the Genfer19 project that's been running for over 6 days on the CPU (Xeon@3.5Ghz) but when run through the GPU they're taking 7,674-ish seconds on the GPU.

When gaming the card runs at about 40% capacity and the fans hardly run at all.

Installation was a breeze - plug it in and switch on. After a couple of seconds I was at the desktop and ready to download the drivers from Nvidia's website. Even without the drivers loaded, I had 1920x1080 displays on both of my monitors, not sure what the experience would have been on Windows as I don't use it so YMMV.

In terms of electrical power, this card needs a six-pin connection from your power supply, so a properly rated power supply is a must. I'm running a 700W unit which is probably a bit more than I need for this, but you should check the requirements of the machine you're running.

If you're considering buying this card, be aware that it needs some space around it for airflow, and will take up two slots in your case, and two expansion slots in the backplane. I didn't check the physical size of the PCB against the space I had available and I've had to modify my case as a result. I'd also suggest that you make sure you've got some space around the PC for ventilation, as it draws quite a bit of power and your PSU will generate a bit more heat as a result.

Overall, I'm very happy with this card.

Bei Tests bzw. Spielen gehen die Lüfter an und sind ebenfalls kaum hörbar. Sobald die Temperatur die eingestellten Werte wieder unterschreitet, werden die Lüfter sofort wieder abgestellt. Seine geliebten älteren Spiele sind alle wunderbar spielbar

Ich kann die GeForce GTX 1650 Gaming X 4G für einen Durchschnittsnutzer wie ihn nur empfehlen.

Reviews.title: HD5770s and 6770s never came with 4GB of VRAM! AVOID!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2022
Reviews.text:
The vast majority of HD6770s did not come with a VGA port. The real ones also require a 6-pin power connector. Most cards that have an output layout like this are fake and, seeing reviews from people saying it won't run DX11, I'm inclined to believe this isn't even a 6770 as those did run DX11. The listed clock speed is about 200mhz lower than the original cards which, at best, points to these being faulty cards flashed with a different BIOS to operate at a lower clock speed. HD 5770s and 6770s (same card with 2 names) also NEVER came with 4GB of VRAM.

Again, this points to this being a card with a fake BIOS. I've tested another faked GPU claiming to be a GTX 960 4GB and the card even reported itself as such to the computer. In actuality it was a GT640 with 1GB of VRAM. When a game would try to utilize the reported 4GB of VRAM that didn't exist, it would cause the computer to crash.

Best case scenario here, you get a GPU that was originally released in 2009 (as the 5770, again, identical to the 6770...AMD just renamed the same card 2 years later) which has not received driver support since 2015, running at 76% of it's original speed (which may be how it gets away without a 6 pin power connector...but I doubt it) and have to spend some time dialing in settings to avoid games using more than 1GB of VRAM so the computer won't crash. In other words KEEP SHOPPING!

Reviews.title: I NEEDED A CARD TO CRUISE AROUND THE INTERNET WITHOUT ISSUE AND THIS IS IT!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2022
Reviews.text:
I just needed a basic video card to cruise around the internet without being stifled by lame performance of a cheap video card. While this card is a tad expensive it is not priced at the ridiculously insane prices of the middle to high end gaming video cards in 2022. This GPU has done the job of letting me go anywhere on the internet without video lag.

I had a more expensive NVIDIA GPU in my system with otherwise state of the art hardware. The newest most power Ryzen 9 \ 5900 CPU, fast memory and a 750 watt power supply. The NVIDIA GPU ran like hot garbage on my Ubuntu system. Ubuntu has a nasty sepia color scheme that saturates the entire OS and everything in it. It is not only ugly but painful to look at due to my vision issues.

I did not know for sure at the time but, I hoped a new video card from someone other than NVIDIA might perform better. Turns out this AMD designed GPU got rid of the nasty sepia tint. This video card creates a simple un-tinted OS that is a pleasure to use. The card is not BIG and uses only the power supplied by the GPU slot.

The card has some energy saver garbage installed that turns the card off if you power down your monitor. I took a star off for the energy saver mess. There really are no other issues. This is a great card to use on a Linux\Ubuntu system that is not used for hard core gaming.

Reviews.title: It does what I needed it to do
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2022
Reviews.text:
At my workplace I needed this half-height graphics card for a PC running a graphics intensive application that was practically unusable using the on-board graphics on the PC. Installing this card resolved the performance issues. I was pleased enough with that purchase that I bought one for my home computer to resolve some lag issues when playing 4K video on my old PC. This card resolved that issue, too. I don't know how this product benchmarks against the completion. I didn't do any testing like that. I simply had performance issues with applications that needed a graphics card performance boost. The price was right on this graphics card and I found that it worked fine to resolve those issues.

The only issue that I had was that the package came with no English instructions, no drivers and no software. I am an IT technician by trade, so I had little trouble finding the right drivers and software online. On one PC, Windows Update found the drivers, but I still had to download and install the correct version of the Radeon software. On the other PC I had to download both the drivers and software. So, this wasn't much of a problem for me, but it may be more than a novice PC users can deal with.

This product did what I needed and I've had no problems with it either at home or at work. It gets a 5 star rating from me even though I would have expected better instructions for installing the product and obtaining the correct drivers & software.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on August 29, 2022
Reviews.text:
Diese Grafikkarte ist absolout NICHT VR fähig ! Wer VR möchte MUSS mehr investieren !

Dennoch möchte ich diese Grafikkarte einmal für ihre erstaunliche und herausragende Leistung loben.
Hier hat MAXSUN alles richtig gemacht!

Ich habe einen Rechner mit ordentlich Leistung und natürlich auch mit einer entsprechenden Grafikkarte um damit die Valve Index VR-Brille zu betreiben. Ich bekam ein ausrangiertes Fujitsu Esprimo C710 mit USB3.0 und einem betagten aber ausreichenden Prozessor und suchte nun nach einer Low Profile Grafikkarte, die dabei auch noch schlank und bestmögliche Leistung bringen sollte.

Mein verrückter Plan:
Wenn an meinem Rechner was abraucht, sollte der kleine Esprimo das Ganze überbrücken.
Mit 32GB RAM und der MAXSUN Radeon RX 550 ist mir das sehr gut gelungen.
Wir reden hier natürlich von minimalistischen Grafikeinstellungen ABER BeatSaber, Phasmophobia (SinglePlayer), Pistol Whip und Blade & Sorcery sind durchaus spielbar und die Karte wird dabei nicht übermäßig heiß. Half Life - Alyx hingegen lagt sehr deutlich (wie es auch zu erwarten ist)

Dies ist keine Kaufempfehlung für VR, es soll aber verdeutlichen, was die kleine Karte auf dem Kasten hat.
Denn hier schlägt sie die vergleichbare GT 1030 um längen. Für Titel wie Diablo III und Co ifinde ich die RX 550 völlig in Ordnung und sie macht dort auch eine echt gute Figur.

Fazit: Es gibt natürlich deutlich stärkere Grafikkarten, egal ob AMD oder NVIDIA aber wer bei dem aktuellen Auf und Ab der Grafikkartenpreise eine günstige und verhältnismäßig starke Grafikkarte sucht, weil er sich gerade keine große leisten kann oder wie bei mir für einen kleineren Zweitrechner, sollte hier gut bedient sein.

Also neuer Monitor, Grafikkarte und ein zusätzlicher Speicherblock. Das Ergebnis kann sich mehr als sehen lassen!!!
Kein geruckel mehr und eine schön saubere Grafik, das beste die Grafikkarte wird bei uns nicht mal warm, läuft also alles sauber. Für 160€ kann man bei der Karte nichts verkehrt machen!

Reviews.title: A solution to a problem.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2022
Reviews.text:
A family member had their monitor burn out and a 4K monitor was bought. Sadly, the built-in video card in the older computer was not strong enough to support the max resolution.

This video card did exactly that. And it is fine for a computer that is used for surfing, basic desktop work, etc. But once you want to watch a full-screen 4K video it struggles. Badly.
To be fair here, the 10-series were not built for 4K. But it needs to be said: it is one thing to do static work on 4K resolutions; once you go to a high-quality media display this is not the card you are looking for.

So this card does what it needs to do - and it will perform fine for most things in resolutions under 4k. It is affordable and available. But don't buy this one for high-quality gaming or intensive video or animation work.

Reviews.title: The Awkward Middle Child of the GTX 900 Series
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2015
Reviews.text:
So, there's a lot to like about this card, but it's in this awkward place in the GTX 9xx family.

The Good:
First of all, it's ASUS. If you haven't been keeping up with the nerdy-computer-guts market in the past five years or so, ASUS decided to stop crapping out sub-par laptops, and actually make some seriously good quality components. Nowadays, almost anything with ASUS on it has some serious love built into it, and though they're high-performance, the price tags tend to be fairly reasonable. ASUS GPUs also come with monitoring and on-the-fly profiling software that, while a little buggy on Win 8/10, is pretty nifty.

I'm also surprised how cool this particular card stays. Right now, this card's in a air-cooled mid-tower, and still, after about 90 minutes of stress-testing, I can't seem to push my card past 60C. And since the oversized fans are dynamic, at idle or low load, you can barely hear the card at all. Same goes for the wattage requirements. I was a little worried before I upgraded my PSU, but the old PSU seems just content with it. Even when I play something with some serious requirements for a few hours, I'm not getting any heat or power spikes.

The Bad:
Overclocking. Just... no. Keep it at recommended voltage, and less than %110 clock. Only one time I tried to benchmark the card at redline, and it was dropping frames like an art gallery in an earthquake. Eventually, the PC froze, and I had to hard reset. The small performance boost from OVing or OCing makes it pointless from all the HW errors. It wasn't from the heat, either. The entire time, I manually set the fans to full speed, and it never crept past 50C. It just doesn't like it.

The Ugly:
For %90 of the games in my library, the card runs like a champ. I was playing Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes, and for the lulz, I turned off VSync and removed the FPS cap. It ran for about 60 seconds and then crashed. After some investigating, I found out it was trying to run the game at >1000 fps. Awesome.

But then there's there's the other %10. I tried to play GTA V on max settings, and it's just struggling to keep >30 fps. Same deal with MSG V. Running the Unigine Valley benchmark at max with the card's default, and I'm lucky if I can average 30. I was getting spikes at 40, and min was something like 12. I have to really tone down the textures and the anitaliasing to get >60 frames.

I also got the 2GB version to save a little money. 2GB is just not enough. It's like putting a V12 supercharged engine on a go-kart transmission.

This is what I mean by "awkward". It's a little too overpowered if you're playing some casual games or an MMO. It's a little too underpowered to play something more demanding at max settings. That puts the 960 in this weird no man's land. If you want something to play LOL or TF2 with, save some money and go with an older 780. If you're trying to build a monster, shell out the extra $100 and get a 970 or 980 if you're not planning to SLI.

Bottom Line:
By no means can I call this a "bad" card. It's an ungraceful card. Most of the time, it'll outperform what I throw at it, but every once in a while, I have to go back and fiddle with the settings. I don't say I regret buying it, but I should have at least gotten the 4GB, and I think I can live with it until I decide to do an upgrade in the near future.

Reviews.title: Step Up to Better Graphics!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2015
Reviews.text:
I just purchased a 25" Acer 2560 x 1440 monitor.
After much research, I came up with this brand GTX 960. (ASUS STRIX)
It's dead silent, even when it runs. Small size, and uses a single 6 pin connector.
I already invested in 2 large silent case fans, and my older AMD GPU made very little noise. (Gigabyte HD 6850)
I also installed a large silent Artic Freezer CPU cooling system.
But now I know that's all that made nise in my mid tower build.
With this new GPU installed, I can't hear much of anything putting my ear 3" next to case which sits on my desk!!

I am a self employed photographer.
I use ADOBE Lightroom 6 and Vegas. Starting with this version of Lightroom, GPU processing is introduced.
AMD GPUs are faster, but are known to be sloppier in dropping or mashing frames.
Also, as for this moment Photoshop and Lightroom recognize "CUDA" cores which AMD doesn't use. Nvidia does.
The older, popular GTX570 has 480 cuda cores. This GTX 960 model has 1024.

But what amazes me, is that I can run my older HP 2311x monitor at 1920 x 1080, and the new monitor at 2560 x 1440!
At the same time. Extending the desktop. The 1080 Holds Lightroom controls, while the 1440 monitor displays a large real time, higher rez image,
of whatever I'm working on. Very slick, and natural feeling.

I didn't install any of the ASUS STRIX software. Just the latest Nvidia drivers and consol. It's easy to change to one (either) monitor to do web work,
check emails or amazon. This GPU runs my 1440 monitor with any steam game I have.

If you're thinking of going 1440, this is an amazing affordable card! I wouldn't hesitate to buy it again if needed.

Reviews.title: Not Necessarily for Enthusiasts... But for Value!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2015
Reviews.text:
I really wanted the GTX 970. I really did. But like most people I was stuck between getting a small card and living with it to upgrade to other bigger and better components and getting a higher-end card while being bottlenecked by other parts. With my ASrock X99M Fatal1ty board already purchased, I chose the former option.
Now that story time is over, let's see how the card performs. As far as overclocking is concerned, I was able to manage 1350 MHz (offset of +59) on the core and maxed out the slider at 8200 MHz (offset +1000) on the VRAM. I set my custom fan profile to be silent all the way to 60C and started gaming away at good ol' 1080p. I already knew that cranking up the MSAA wasn't really an option, so I stuck with high settings for most all games except Bioshock Infinite, which I could manage 60 FPS on ultra. Even with a relatively puny 2GB of video RAM, I was able to play almost all other titles on high with very decent frame rates. Coming from a 750 Ti, this is good news. For those who want all that MSAA, however, I would recommend stepping up to the 4GB version or ponying up and getting the GTX 970 instead.
As I said in the title, value was my game for this card until my 5960X comes to my front door. Sure, I can't max out GTA V, but I didn't necessarily feel it was necessary to shell out more money for a card that I am going to replace in probably a year anyway.
For those who are still running panels with resolution lower than 1080p, I can't recommend this card enough. Its overclocking potential, efficiency, and silence make it an enormous bang-for-the-buck, which is something the majority are actually into.

Reviews.title: Cool, Quiet and Fast! Props to ASUS and NVIDIA.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2015
Reviews.text: For the price, you cannot get a better 1080p gaming card from NVIDIA. This is their definite 1080p bang for your buck card. It's cool, quiet and performs much better than a reference design thanks to the higher clocks and custom cooling unit. I'd say the comparable card from team red would bet the R9 280x. This card beats the 280 in most games but the 280x is pretty neck and neck. So between the two it depends on whether you're looking for raw gaming performance, cuda support or OpenCL. I will say this card has played nearly any game I've thrown at it on Ultra minus multi-sampled anti-aliasing and kept above 60FPS. That is the key with this card though, unless you're playing a Source Engine game or Minecraft, you really need to turn the filters down. I don't play with MSAA unless it's a source game, and even then I turn AA off completely in most games. I run Skyrim at 1080p with over 120 mods, about 30 of which are graphics mods. That combined with RealVision ENB I'm still managing between 50 and 60FPS almost all the time. Games like Far Cry 4, Battlefield 4 and COD: AW all run well fast 60FPS as well. Far Cry 4 not being 100% optimized does need to be bumped down to Very High instead of Ultra to keep a steady 50 - 60FPS. Overclocking is also very good on this card, I was able to push mine 150MHz on the core, and 400MHz on the memory. So all in all I'm extremely happy with my purchase, and if you're looking for a solid 1080p card and you don't plan on maxing out every game you buy, then this will serve you extremely well.

Reviews.title: Runs Extremely COOL, QUIET, and POWERFUL. (Upgraded from ATI HD5850)
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2015
Reviews.text:
CONS:
Extremely cool
Powerful even with low voltage
Extremely quiet, basically silent, can hardly hear the fans at all
High potential overclocking.
Required only 1 6pin

PROS:
Sometimes the fans doesn't run at all, even when the GPU temp goes over 70'C, you will have to go to ASUS GPU tweak tool to click AUTO and click APPLY again in order to make it run normal again. Maybe is the GPU Tweaak tool comes from ASUS, I haven't try other program like MSI Afterburner.

Upgraded from ATI ASUS HD5850 to this card.
It is a big step up, running on 1080p monitor.
Using the Asus GPU tweak tool, this card easily oc'ed up to 1415 clock/7600mhz stable without having to tweak the voltage at all.
And it runs extremely cool, the fans are extremely quiet even when it runs.
The temp never runs above 62'C under full load with fan speed set on auto. (with 1415/7600 at default voltage)
Max fan speed i had seen is 57%, but I can hardly hear anything at all, it sounds the same as the fan is not running at all.
I used to only able to play the games at medium settings 35~60fps (ATI HD5850), now with this card, I can run all my games smooth at high to ultra or max settings at 1080p resolution.

Games I tested on:
COD AW
BF4
Dragon Age Inquisition
Shadow of Mordor
Borderlands Pre sequel

Basically, if you are running 1920x1080, this card will be the best $/performance for your system.
Extremely powerful card running at low voltage, runs cool, and quiet.
5 star!

Reviews.title: Good, not perfect
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2015
Reviews.text:
First, let me say that my installation experience was partially my fault, and partially the card's fault. I have a boss gigabyte motherboard that scores very good on passmark, however it is about 2 years old. I installed the graphics card after removing several wires and re-routing some power cords. The card's dimensions are perfect, and it also looks extremely sleek first glance. I plugged in my desktop, tested it out, and after several reboots while the computer ran through the general tasks,the computer finally turned on. However I was greeted with poor performance, the card was not recognized! After 24 hours worth of troubleshooting, I finally got the card working.
The performance is excellent, I'm able to run Battlefield 4 on ultra at about 50-60fps, which is great. The rest of my games smoothly on Ultra. In one game, I kept having an error. About 30 minutes in, the entire computer would freeze, which I later learned was the result of the graphics card shutting down. This is disheartening considering the seller advertised silent, cooled gaming, and the card would overheat and shut down!
It is for this reason that I am giving 4 stars, excellent performance but several errors.

Reviews.title: Bang for your buck!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2015
Reviews.text:
Great bang for your buck card. I was eyeing the AMD line for a while because of Mantle and their prices but after the bit coin boom placed them out of my price range I was stuck with my Asus 7750 for over a year. Then this line from Nvidia came out slap the Asus brand and pure gold. I mainly play Elder Scrolls Online and where I used to be getting 30-40 frames on high settings @ 1080p (sometimes less) I'm now getting 50-99 with most settings on ultra (55 in towns 60+ in outside world and 99 in dungeons).
If your on a budget and don't mind playing with everything not set to the highest settings then this is the card for you.

The only con I faced with this card that made me drop a star was because I had to reinstall Windows.
Yes I followed all steps for changing brands of video cards but when I loaded the drivers I kept getting a blank screen on windows start-up, I couldn't find the conflict but I was due for a re-install anyways.

Reviews.title: Great card for entry-level gaming
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2015
Reviews.text:
The purposes of buying this card were two: to be able to play semi-old games (2000&before - 2013) on the highest settings, and recent games (2014-2015) on medium to low settings, all on 1080p@60fps. It fulfilled the first requirement with minor hitches (some little-to-non noticeable 40-50 dips in fps while using PhysX/TressFX), and so far has bested the second one in letting me play modern games on a medium to high.

On the hardware side, the card is small so it should fit on most cases (even µ and mini form factors); the fans are not loud even on full load(my cooling solution relies on Noctua fans... and they're noisier); it doesn't require a meaty power supply (only uses one 6 pin connector); it has a combination of old and new outputs, which I think is the best of all the 960's (VGA / DisplayPort1.2 x 3 / HDMI). The backplate adds to the feeling of quality and it should help in both the cooling and any card sag.

A lot of benchmarks show the 4GB edition is unnecessary, since this card has a narrow bus-width that pairs well enough with the 2GB the standard model offers.

Reviews.title: so it's fine with three fans in the case
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2015
Reviews.text:
After about a week, our first one started having display issues, which would freeze the computer and not let me even make it past the login screen without freezing. I did a lot of troubleshooting to try to fix the problem, but ended up asking for a replacement in case it really was the graphics card. The replacement came two days later, and we haven't had any problems since. I am really grateful they gave me a replacement so quickly since I was really bummed about my newly built expensive computer not working.

There's no coil whine that I have heard yet, but it does get a little warm. I don't game for too long with too intense of graphics, so it's fine with three fans in the case, but hard core gamers will probably need a heat sink or more fans to keep it from overheating. Great graphics and great amazon service!

Reviews.title: Great Upgrade
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2015
Reviews.text:
Great card, looks awesome. Love that it has a backplate for the PCB, makes the card looks clean. The backplate is black metal, while the shroud is tough red and black plastic. Didn't measure, but it was shorter than the 660 FTW from EVGA that it replaced. Speaking of which, the ASUS fit great in my Dell XPS 8300 with a Corsair HW650 PSU, no problems whatsover. Benchmarks below are 960 vs 660FTW

Tomb Raider, Ultimate w/TressFX - 62.8FPS vs 40.7FPS
Furmark, 1080 Benchmark - 2536 vs 1778
Talos Principle, Ultra w/2XAA - 80.2FPS vs 68.0FPS

Heard some coil whine when running Furmark, but the case was open at the time. When everything was closed and in its normal position, I didn't hear anything. Max temp with Furmark was 68C, vs 76C with the old 660 FTW. Seems to be a great upgrade for the money, considering the rather large jump to the 970 and even larger to the 980. I mostly upgraded so I can play The Witcher 3 on decent settings when it comes out in May. I highly recommend this card.

Reviews.title: great performance for the price.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2010
Reviews.text:
Great product for the price at $200.00 on 11/2010. 460gtx. Only issue, my card showed up under clocked from the advertised spec. I had to use the software to clock the card to highest spec; which was also an under rated spec. The serial numbers matched up from advertised. But at high clocks, the card still idles at 30 CEL and under load with modern warfare 2 or crysis, it hits 50ish CEL. no problems. I'm lucky I know what I'm doing. If you are an average user and have no idea how to over clock or liquid cool a gpu, how would you know you are getting the performance you are buying? So, take my advice and learn about the clocks/software it comes with and tweak away. This card runs way better than my 8800GTX's OCE cards, that just burnt out. Honestly, it does a better job at a cooler rate equal to 2 8800GTX's and out performs 1 8800GTX. I ordered a second card and it's arriving today. I bet two of these in sli will blow the socks off of my old 3 8800GTX's sli setup. Amazon did great, fast shipping, great price, only issue was the factory under clocking which can be re-clocked with the provided software.

Also, Installation was a breeze and the cards is smaller than an 8800 gtx, which makes a BIG deal for anyone with a mid tower. This card is small than a 780i xfx and asus motherboard. the 8800gtx is an inch or two larger. With the 8800 gtx I had to relocate my hard disks/with this card they can go back to their original home!

Reviews.title: None Too Shabby
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2015
Reviews.text:
It plays games flawlessly. My only issues is the drivers keep failing. This is most likely due to the used, dusty condition in which I got the card and in no way should affect your decision to get this card. I have had no problems playing many games like Far Cry 4, BO2 @125 FPS, Sleeping Dogs with HD effects on, The Sabatuer, Payday 2 or any other games I have.

My specs for those interested:

Reviews.title: Good value and features
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2013
Reviews.text:
I have used both brands: nvidia and Ati (now AMD), even way back to 3Dfx. They are good brands with their respective features, but went for this card as it is a great value for the performance, nvidia drivers tend to be a bit more reliable and released more often to correct performance issues with new games.

All in all it is a well rounded product that runs current games without a problem with medium to max settings, depending on the resolution and how demanding is the game. But for general gaming it does its job.

You really can't go wrong with this card, unless you find a newer with more horsepower at special pricing. It is better to save money and use it on more RAM and/or a SSD (both will give you more of a performance boost for general use as well) than spend it all on the most expensive video card or CPU.

Reviews.title: First real graphics card...
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2011
Reviews.text:
I have always been a gamer, but 2 years ago I refused to upgrade my PC to play the latest games and bought a PS3 slim. My last card was a GeForce 8600GT and that couldn't run the latest games.

Earlier this year I went out and bought a LG 24" HD LED monitor and a GeForce GT240, then I realized that it was impossible to play games at HD resolution, so I made the plunge and bought this GTX 460.
After installing this card into a almost 6 year old Dell Dimension 9200 with a Core 2 Duo E6300 and 8GB DDR2 RAM,
I was amazed to see how games like Rage and Battlefield 3 was working at 1920x1080.

I think my next buy is gonna be a GeForce 560 Ti in the near future when I am building my spanking new system.
Although this is a very good card, and you will be amazed!!!

Reviews.title: One Issue
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2012
Reviews.text: I bought two of these to use in SLI mode for Battlefield 3. The cards installed ok and run fine, except when I try to play Battlefield 3 in SLI mode, which crashes my system after 30-60 seconds of gameplay. There is a lengthy thread running on the NVIDIA forum for this issue as a lot of people have the same problem with the GTX460 in SLI mode. I switched back to single card mode, which works perfectly. Hopefully we'll get updated drivers someday to fix the problem.

Reviews.title: Great card for price
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2011
Reviews.text: This card can handle pretty much everything I throw at it on ultra settings except for Battlefield 3. Skyrim is on ultra except for medium shadows. Battlefield is on some high some medium settings which is fine for me. The temperature usually runs cooler than what is recommended and the fan noise is barely audible and my tower is right next to me on my desk. The mail in rebate has taken some time, but as long as you do the right steps you will get it in 6-8 weeks after approval. I have had two EVGA cards and both has performed as or better than expected. Can't wait for it to go on sale again and get a second.

Reviews.title: Absolutely great card.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2014
Reviews.text:
I love this card. I originally built my computer to run this card, but ran out of funds halfway (broke college kid at the time).

It's not the best on the market, but it can run most games on high settings. It chunks out an even 70 fps on Minecraft with over 200 mods and Sonic Ether's Unbelievable Shaders installed. This was while playing minecraft 1.5.

Alas, I have noticed a lot of glitches while playing that I can only attribute to my processor overheating. So before you think this card is somehow inferior because your games aren't playing right, be sure your processor can keep up with it!

Reviews.title: Great product, super quick shipping, lowest price I could find. How can you beat that?
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2012
Reviews.text: I ordered this before Christmas, and despite the increased mail traffic it still got to my house in 2 days! I picked normal shipping (though the shipping source wasn't too far from me...) I've install this card in my computer and it runs great. Hasn't run hot yet. Comes with overclocking software for those that like it. The only thing I still have to find out about is overall durability, but no way to tell that till the card gives out. I have only been running it for about 2 or 3 weeks now, so only time will tell. Other than that it is a terrific card for the money.

Reviews.title: SO FAR SO GOOD
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2011
Reviews.text: This is my second Nvidia Graphic card. The first one was a 8800GT which at that time was one of the best GP you could buy at an affordable price. Sadly it died on me two month ago. It surely worth it for all the time I used it and the excellent performance. I spent two month researchin for the ideal card and after many toughts I decided and I can surely tell you this is the best card I've ever had. Noisless and run all my games smoothly without freezing up all the time. Folow my advice......GO FOR IT!

Reviews.title: Great card, but some manufacturing issues
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2011
Reviews.text:
This card performed wayyyyy better than I expected. It really is a great card for the price. Played 4v4 Starcraft II on Extreme and averaged 60fps and peaked at 110fps.

However, my card has a serious defect that caused it to boot improperly. I would have to reinstall the drivers everytime I turned the computer on or everytime after the computer fell asleep for the graphics card to being functioning again. I will be sending it back tomorrow, but I will be getting another 460 because of the great performance of this card.

data.label: AMD ATI Radeon X1300 Pro 256 MB AGP Card
data.description: The X1300 can accelerate digital imaging tasks, enhance 3D graphics in PC games, output a billion more colors than the competition1, and deliver top performance for high definition video. The X1300 has received ATI's stamp of approval for Microsoft's upcoming Windows Vista¿ operating system3, enabling the machine to summon some serious graphical glitz without affecting system performance.

Reviews.title: Be careful if you need to contact ATI for warranty
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2008
Reviews.text: I bought two video cards which arrived new in a shrink wrapped box. One of the cards had a terrible flicker in it. Tried using it in a second computer, same thing. When I contacted ATI regarding the one year warranty, I was told twice (by their automated system) that the warranty had expired and would not be honored. Apparently the combination of the item number and serial number shows this item to be out of warranty on ATI's computer system and any warranty claim requires that you provide proof of purchase and an override on ATIs part. Just a hassle to go through and I haven't heard back from ATI for the last 10 days.

Reviews.title: ATI Radeon
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2012
Reviews.text:
I'm salvaging every bit of life out of my outdated Dell computer. The ATI Radeon card I purchased allowed me to use higher resolution and play some decent games.

The hardware arrived about a week after I ordered and paid for it. It was used but in good shape. It did not include any software or instructions. I had to find and download the drivers (not so simple because the card is no longer supported by the manufacturer). Once done, the card works just fine.

Reviews.title: Best AGP card on the market
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2009
Reviews.text: This card is the best AGP card on the market, thats not an exaggeration, AGP cards are the old version, and honestly, they are very limited. This card is the best graphics card that you can get for a computer that only has AGP ports (i think the computer would have to be 3, maybe 4 years or older, when AGP was the standard). It can handle any game, and comes with DVI and VGA ports. This is the best product if your computer is older only has AGP.

Reviews.title: Great Price
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2008
Reviews.text: I purchased this card when my old card hit the dust. I couldn't beat the deal I found through Amazon. This is an upgrade to my 9600 Pro. I immediately noticed the difference. I can suddenly see a lot more detail in all of my games and they run just as fast if not faster. This card came out about two years ago as of my purchase, 8/08, so it's not a top of the line card, but for under $50.00 how can you go wrong. I definitely recommend this card.

Reviews.title: Radeon X1300 Pro
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2014
Reviews.text: Arrived on schedule but in poor condition. Bracket was bent not allowing the card to securely snap into agp slot, molex power connector was not connected firmly to board. Because of these issues I was not able to install and use this card, very disappointing. Buying used is always a gamble sometimes you win and sometimes you don't.

Reviews.title: like the card for older games and netflix
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2014
Reviews.text: I've enjoyed the performance of this card since my desktop is a little elderly. It plays older games great and I like the result watching netflix too.

Reviews.title: ATI Radeon X1300 Pro AGP Video Card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2008
Reviews.text: Very good card overall for my use. Good features and supports high resolutions of the LCD monitors. Using the DVI hook up makes it even more seemless. Graphics card has the power to run at least all the programs that I am running with smooth transition.

Reviews.title: Getting out of the past
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2008
Reviews.text: Had been using an old graphics card and was not aware what was out there. The installation was easy and the results were just great. I am not able to see what everybody is talking about.

Reviews.text: Great Deal A+++

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in France on October 5, 2022
Reviews.text: Très bonne carte à tout faire, jeux, graphisme, photos.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in France on July 12, 2022
Reviewed in the United Kingdom on September 17, 2022
Reviews.text: I received a faulty card however, I would not in anyway let this deter you from buying as I did replace it and it is a great little card

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in France on May 5, 2022
Reviews.text:
Le meilleur deal possible pour faire tourner des jeux moyennement exigeants à 60FPS 1080p ou du lourd (RDR2, Cyberpunk 2077) à 50 FPS 1080p. Le ray tracing est généralement trop couteux- baisse à 30-35 FPS max - sauf si le DLSS est là pour rétablir l'équilibre. Ce qui gache un peu le visuel quand meme.
Peu bruyante, en tout cas pas génant dans un environnement normal pour une personne normale avec des attentes normales.
Peu gourmande en courant - elle tourne sur une alim 550W avec un i5. Connectique 8 broches.
Un peu épaisse mais courte. Parfaite dans une config mini ATX.
Rien à redire - juste évidement le prix encore vaguement abusif.
Testée avec un I5 9400f - temp max sur bench 3Dmark pendant quelques heures 75C. Tres raisonnable.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on September 20, 2022
Reviews.text: Schnelle unproblematische Lieferung einer leistungsfähigen Grafikkarte

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on April 12, 2022
Reviews.text:
Habe mir die Phönix 3060 als Ersatz für meine 2060 gekauft und muss sagen das ich genau das bekommen habe was ich erwartet habe.
Ich kann die negativen Berichte hier nicht nachvollziehen man weiss doch vor dem Kauf was man da anklickt, natürlich ist das hier keine vollwertige RTX 3060 ,dennoch hat die Karte einiges zu bieten.

Hier mal ein paar Benchmark-Beispiele um das zu verdeutlichen, ich besitze einen Intel Core i7 10700,habe 32GB Ram verbaut und verwende ne Gaming SSD.

Assassins Creed Valhalla alles auf Max Details in WQHD Auflösung,

Mit der RTX 2060 komme ich hier auf 42FPS, mit der Phönix3060 habe ich 52FPS

Far Cry 6 alles auf Max Details in WQHD Auflösung und mit aktiviertem HD-Texturen.

Mit ner RTX 2060 liege ich bei 32FPS , mit der Phönix3060 komme ich auf satte 58FPS,also fast doppelt so viel.

Cyberpunk 2077 alles auf Ultra Details in WQHD Auflösung ohne aktiviertes DLSS.

Mit der RTX 2060 hatte ich hier 17FPS, mit der Phönix3060 komme ich immerhin auf 32FPS, also flüssig spielbar.

Mein Fazit daher, die Karte hat etwas weniger Leistung als ne "echte" RTX3060, aber sie hat auch Vorteile wie die vollen 12GB DDR6 Grafikspeicher, den kleinen Formfaktor, wodurch sie in Mini und Midisystemen perfekt passt, einen geringeren Stromverbrauch als ne normale 3060 und sie ist auch noch deutlich leiser unter Vollast als meine alte 2060 Karte, lediglich das der Lüfter auch im Leerlauf weiterläuft ist schade, zudem lässt sich die Phönix mit der von Asus erhältlichen Software auch noch ordentlich übertakten ,sodass man noch mehr Leistung rausholen kann.

Hier mal meine Pro und Contras:

Pro:
Kleiner Formfaktor
Geringerer Strombedarf als bei einer vollwertigen 3060
Volle 12 GB Grafikspeicher
Gute Spieleleistung
Recht leise auch unter Vollast durch den grossen Lüfter
Geringe Wärmeentwicklung
Lässt sich noch weit übertakten
Günstiger Preis

Contra:
Leider kein Abschalten des Lüfters im Leerlaufbetrieb ( Idle )
Preis/Leistungsverhältnis könnte noch etwas besser sein

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in France on May 7, 2022
Reviews.text:
Moins de 500€ pour une nvidia de la serie 3000, qui plus est une 3060 avec 12Go, il faut clairement sauter sur l'occasion.
Alors oui 12Go c'est trop car en ce moment les jeux prennent 6 à 8Go max, mais au moins on peut etre serein quand à la pérénité de cette carte quand il va falloir plus de ram disponible (des cartes 16Go sortent).
Pour ma part j'avais une 1050 2go donc il fallait oublier tous les jeux plus ou moins récents et donc maintenant je suis en mode ultra tout le temps. Un vrai plaisir.
Ce qui m'étonne surtout c'est que malgré un seul gros ventilateur, la carte sais rester discrête, en tout cas plus que mon ancienne 1050 qui avait pourtant 2 ventilateurs.
Livraison ultrarapide avec presque 1 semaine d'avance. Je suis super content.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in France on April 5, 2022
Reviews.text:
Carte graphique à première vue très bien et suffisante pour jouer couplée à un R7 3700X.

L'installation dans le PC est facile avec ses dimensions réduites (et son poids aussi du coup) comparée à la RX 470 qu'elle remplace.

Windows 10 à automatiquement téléchargé et installé les pilotes Nvidia lors du 1er démarrage (ce qui l'a obligé d'ailleurs à attendre quelques minutes avec un écran noir) donc c'est du Plug & Play de ce côté là mais par habitude j'ai désinstallé les pilotes AMD qui restait et téléchargé les pilotes Nvidia depuis leur site pour être sûr d'avoir une version à jour et l'app Geforce.

Ce n'est pas mentionné dans la description, mais la version de la RTX 3060 vendue par le vendeur Asus eShop est accompagnée d'une souris offerte. Ça correspond en fait à l'offre de cette carte cataloguée sur le site officiel d'Asus qui renvoie vers cette page Amazon quand on veut l'acheter

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Spain on September 20, 2022
Reviews.text:
O preço é alto mas também aguenta com praticamente tudo que é jogo no máximo, incluindo Ray Tracing a 1080p com DLSS a 60-75fps.
Em Windows, os drivers são super optimizados e não têm problemas nenhuns com nenhum jogo (incluindo os que usam engines antigos) nem em ambiente desktop (o problema de lag no scroll em video decoding no Chrome/Edge aparentemente é do próprio browser e deverá ser corrigido no futuro. Workaround atual é mudar o Angle rendering para DX9 na chrome flags).
Tem uma capacidade de OC supreendente sendo possível espremer quase mais 10% de desempenho ficando muito próxima duma RX 6600 XT.
Os 12GB serão muito úteis nos jogos que estarão para vir. Já existe pelo menos um jogo que pede 10GB para colocar as texturas no máximo.
Suporta Resizable Bar de fábrica que permite tirar mais desempenho em certos jogos.
O Geforce Experience aplica automaticamente as definições ótimas da gráfica para cada jogo.

Já a ASUS poderia ter feito um melhor trabalho a afinar a gráfica. O dissipador e as ventoinhas parecem ser muito eficientes mas achei demasiado barulhenta por defeito. As ventoinhas aumentam demasiado a rotação com uma temperatura que é claramente baixa e fazem muito barulho. A gráfica aguenta temperaturas mais altas sem problema algum. Nada que o GPU Tweak não resolva. Com o ajuste certo fica bastante silenciosa mas quando algum jogo puxa ao máximo, começa a ouvir-se bem. Ao pegar na mesma achei-a um pouco mais leve que o normal e os plásticos não pareciam os melhores mas tem um bom look.

Os únicos pontos negativos é o preço e na UI dos drivers da Nvidia que continua com dois paineis separados, sendo que um deles ainda tem um design antigo do tempo do XP e é lento a operar, mas as opções importantes estão lá todas.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in France on October 10, 2022
Reviews.text:
c'est la deuxième fois consécutive que je commande cette carte graphique.
car la 1ère fois ce n'est pas le bon article que j'ai reçu (1 boite de 1kg de sucre en morceaux).
l'article correspond à mes attentes, graphisme, bruit, nickel.
seul hic pour la première j'ai toujours la demande de remboursement depuis le 23 septembre.
j'ai renvoyé le sucre et il a été livré le 28 septembre, et je n'ai toujours pas été remboursé; pour le moment cette carte me coute le double de son prix. merci Amazon

Ich habe jetzt einen absolut leissen PC beim Gaming. Außer ich schalte bei Cyberpunk 2077 das Raytracing an oder stelle bei Tiny Tinas WOnderland und Borderlands 3 die Grafik auf Ultra. Dann wird es lauter, aber bleibt angenehm. Ich hab sehr empfindasame Ohren, da ich hohe Tonlagen besonders laut höre. Bin vollkommen zufrieden mit Preis und Leistung.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on October 13, 2022
Reviews.text:
The graphic card overall is really good.

I've tested it for a few weeks and I can say that it works very well.
The design is cool so if you have a custom build it will add more personality to your setup.
What I didn't like at first was the size of it all though it it should be small it's pretty big so consider getting a bigger case if you have a small one.

What I recommend.
Don't buy it unless you already have a good pc, you need a decent processor and at least 16 ram with a fast ssd to get all of the graphic card.

Reviews.title: Great budget card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2022
Reviews.text:
Old man Dad on a budget here. Purchased this to upgrade from onboard graphics when stadia was announced that they were cancelling.

Slapped it in, loaded up Elder Scrolls Online and can say I'm pleased with the card. I run it on the high setting no problem. It can handle ultra but the framerate drops below my comfort but it can run it.

For a budget card it works well for me. Would recommend.

(I'm running a 10th gen core i5 with only 16gb of ram...still the card performs better than expected)

Reviews.title: I NEEDED A CARD TO CRUISE AROUND THE INTERNET WITHOUT ISSUE AND THIS IS IT!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2022
Reviews.text:
I just needed a basic video card to cruise around the internet without being stifled by lame performance of a cheap video card. While this card is a tad expensive it is not priced at the ridiculously insane prices of the middle to high end gaming video cards in 2022. This GPU has done the job of letting me go anywhere on the internet without video lag.

I had a more expensive NVIDIA GPU in my system with otherwise state of the art hardware. The newest most power Ryzen 9 \ 5900 CPU, fast memory and a 750 watt power supply. The NVIDIA GPU ran like hot garbage on my Ubuntu system. Ubuntu has a nasty sepia color scheme that saturates the entire OS and everything in it. It is not only ugly but painful to look at due to my vision issues.

I did not know for sure at the time but, I hoped a new video card from someone other than NVIDIA might perform better. Turns out this AMD designed GPU got rid of the nasty sepia tint. This video card creates a simple un-tinted OS that is a pleasure to use. The card is not BIG and uses only the power supplied by the GPU slot.

The card has some energy saver garbage installed that turns the card off if you power down your monitor. I took a star off for the energy saver mess. There really are no other issues. This is a great card to use on a Linux\Ubuntu system that is not used for hard core gaming.

Reviews.title: Great for what it is
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2022
Reviews.text:
I recently built my first gaming pc in 20 years. I ordered everything but the graphics card, and when I went to research and price them... Whoa! Man have things changed in 20 years! Needless to say I needed something until I could afford a good graphics card. Enter MaxSun Radeon RX550. This card actually impressed me. Not only was I able to get my system up and running, I was also able to play a few of my favorite games, like BeamNG.drive. Granted, the settings were on Low and some on Medium, and the FPS wasn't optimal, but it was definitely playable.

While I wouldn't recommend this as a primary card for gaming, it makes a great backup.
